apache.eli5: Itâ€™s one of the oldest and most popular programs that helps deliver websites to your browser.
apache.boss: Apache is a widely used open-source web server software that delivers content over the internet using HTTP and HTTPS.
apache.sysadmin: Apache HTTP Server is a modular, process-based web server that supports .htaccess rules, virtual hosts, reverse proxy, and load balancing. It's part of the LAMP stack.
apache.use_case: Used to serve a WordPress site on a traditional LAMP server setup.

litespeed.eli5: Itâ€™s like Apacheâ€™s faster cousinâ€”does the same job but quicker and more efficient.
litespeed.boss: LiteSpeed is a high-performance commercial web server known for its speed and compatibility with Apache configurations.
litespeed.sysadmin: LiteSpeed supports .htaccess, mod_rewrite, and uses an event-driven architecture for high concurrency. It includes built-in caching and security features.
litespeed.use_case: Used to power high-traffic e-commerce websites with faster page loads and reduced server load.

node server.eli5: Itâ€™s like a waiter that uses JavaScript to serve your websiteâ€™s content to visitors.
node server.boss: A Node server runs JavaScript on the backend to handle web requests and serve dynamic content.
node server.sysadmin: Node.js servers use non-blocking I/O and event-driven architecture. Common frameworks include Express for handling routing and middleware.
node server.use_case: Used to create a REST API that handles authentication and returns JSON data.

static hosting.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting your websiteâ€™s files in a folder and letting people open themâ€”no fancy backend needed.
static hosting.boss: Static hosting serves HTML, CSS, JS, and media files directly to the browser without server-side processing.
static hosting.sysadmin: Static hosts like Netlify, Vercel, and GitHub Pages serve pre-built files from a CDN, often using JAMstack architectures.
static hosting.use_case: Used to host a portfolio site with no database or server-side logic.

serverless.eli5: Itâ€™s like renting tiny helpers who run your code only when needed, instead of owning a whole computer.
serverless.boss: Serverless is a cloud computing model where backend logic runs on demand, without managing server infrastructure.
serverless.sysadmin: Serverless platforms (e.g., AWS Lambda, Cloudflare Workers) run stateless functions in response to events. Billing is per execution, and scaling is automatic.
serverless.use_case: Used to process form submissions on a static site without maintaining a backend server.

edge function.eli5: Itâ€™s like a mini brain that runs code close to your location so the website loads faster.
edge function.boss: Edge functions execute code at data centers closer to users, reducing latency and improving performance.
edge function.sysadmin: Edge functions are serverless scripts deployed to CDN edge nodes. They handle tasks like redirects, headers, or authentication before reaching the origin.
edge function.use_case: Used to personalize content by region before serving it from a static site.

cloudflare workers.eli5: Theyâ€™re tiny programs that run near your location to make websites faster and smarter.
cloudflare workers.boss: Cloudflare Workers are serverless functions that run at Cloudflareâ€™s edge network, enabling fast and secure custom logic.
cloudflare workers.sysadmin: Workers execute JavaScript or WASM in isolated V8 environments. They support routing, caching, API calls, and middleware at the edge.
cloudflare workers.use_case: Used to rewrite URLs and handle A/B testing at the edge for a global website.

lambda function.eli5: Itâ€™s a bit of code that wakes up, does its job, and goes back to sleepâ€”like a helpful gnome.
lambda function.boss: AWS Lambda lets you run functions on-demand in the cloud without managing servers.
lambda function.sysadmin: Lambda runs code in response to events (HTTP, S3, etc.) in a containerized runtime. Supports many languages and integrates with AWS services.
lambda function.use_case: Used to resize uploaded images in S3 automatically upon upload.

render.eli5: Itâ€™s a one-stop shop to host your website or backend without needing to know how servers work.
render.boss: Render is a cloud platform that deploys websites, APIs, databases, and cron jobs with simple automation.
render.sysadmin: Render supports static sites, Docker containers, and web services. Offers managed SSL, autoscaling, cron jobs, and Git integration.
render.use_case: Used to deploy a full-stack Node and PostgreSQL app with zero server setup.

vercel.eli5: Itâ€™s like a turbo button for deploying React and frontend apps with almost no setup.
vercel.boss: Vercel is a frontend cloud platform designed for fast deployment and hosting of modern web apps.
vercel.sysadmin: Vercel auto-builds from Git, optimizes with edge functions, supports Next.js natively, and offers CDN, SSL, and analytics.
vercel.use_case: Used to deploy a Next.js blog with edge caching and automatic previews.

netlify.eli5: Itâ€™s a magic button for turning your website code into a live site.
netlify.boss: Netlify is a platform that hosts static sites and serverless functions, automating builds and deployments.
netlify.sysadmin: Netlify integrates with Git, runs CI/CD pipelines, deploys to CDN, and supports edge functions, redirects, and Netlify CMS.
netlify.use_case: Used to host a JAMstack portfolio with continuous deployment from GitHub.

heroku.eli5: Itâ€™s a place where you drop your app code and it just worksâ€”no server setup needed.
heroku.boss: Heroku is a cloud platform that simplifies deploying and scaling apps by abstracting server management.
heroku.sysadmin: Heroku uses dynos (containers) to run apps. It supports Git-based deployments, Postgres, Redis, config vars, and auto-scaling.
heroku.use_case: Used by startups to quickly deploy prototypes and internal tools without infrastructure knowledge.

firebase hosting.eli5: Itâ€™s Googleâ€™s way of letting you show your website to the world, fast and secure.
firebase hosting.boss: Firebase Hosting is a Google service for deploying fast, secure static and dynamic web apps globally.
firebase hosting.sysadmin: Firebase Hosting offers CDN-backed SSL hosting for HTML/CSS/JS and supports custom domains, caching, and Cloud Functions.
firebase hosting.use_case: Used to host a single-page app with custom domain and secure HTTPS out of the box.

digitalocean app platform.eli5: Itâ€™s like a launchpad for your websiteâ€”just push your code and it runs.
digitalocean app platform.boss: DigitalOcean App Platform is a platform-as-a-service (PaaS) for deploying apps and static sites without managing servers.
digitalocean app platform.sysadmin: Supports Git push deployments, autoscaling, managed SSL, PostgreSQL, and Docker. Built on Kubernetes for scalability.
digitalocean app platform.use_case: Used to deploy a Node.js API with PostgreSQL and auto HTTPS in minutes.

cloudflare.eli5: Itâ€™s like a bodyguard and speed booster for websites.
cloudflare.boss: Cloudflare is a CDN and security service that protects and accelerates websites through global edge delivery.
cloudflare.sysadmin: Cloudflare offers DNS, CDN, WAF, DDoS protection, SSL, Workers, and Zero Trust services. Sits in front of your site as a reverse proxy.
cloudflare.use_case: Used to protect a website from DDoS attacks and reduce latency with global caching.

fastly.eli5: Itâ€™s like Cloudflareâ€™s speed-obsessed cousin that helps big websites load lightning fast.
fastly.boss: Fastly is a high-performance CDN and edge cloud platform used by enterprises for low-latency delivery and edge logic.
fastly.sysadmin: Fastly offers edge caching, image optimization, WAF, and real-time log streaming. VCL scripting allows request manipulation at the edge.
fastly.use_case: Used to serve a video-heavy news site with real-time purging and edge rules.

akamai.eli5: Itâ€™s like a giant network of helpers making sure websites donâ€™t crash and stay fast around the world.
akamai.boss: Akamai is a global CDN and cybersecurity provider trusted by large enterprises for content delivery and protection.
akamai.sysadmin: Akamai provides DNS, edge servers, DDoS mitigation, and application acceleration with advanced caching and routing.
akamai.use_case: Used by banks and media companies for high availability, low latency, and security at global scale.

image optimization.eli5: Itâ€™s like shrinking your pictures so your website loads faster but still looks good.
image optimization.boss: Image optimization reduces file size without sacrificing quality, improving site speed and user experience.
image optimization.sysadmin: Involves compression (lossy/lossless), resizing, format conversion (WebP, AVIF), and lazy loading to reduce load time and bandwidth.
image optimization.use_case: Used to convert hero images to WebP and lazy load them on a homepage for faster load times.

edge caching.eli5: Itâ€™s like keeping a copy of your website close to where people live so it loads faster.
edge caching.boss: Edge caching stores website content on servers around the world to speed up delivery and reduce latency.
edge caching.sysadmin: CDNs cache content at edge nodes near users, reducing round-trips to origin. TTL and cache headers control freshness.
edge caching.use_case: Used to store static assets like CSS and JS closer to users globally for a React app.

asset pipeline.eli5: Itâ€™s like an assembly line for your websiteâ€™s codeâ€”it cleans, shrinks, and packs everything before shipping.
asset pipeline.boss: An asset pipeline automates processing of CSS, JS, and images to prepare them for fast web delivery.
asset pipeline.sysadmin: It includes steps like minification, transpilation, concatenation, fingerprinting, and bundling using tools like Webpack, Gulp, or Vite.
asset pipeline.use_case: Used in a Rails app to compress and version images, CSS, and JS files before deployment.

http caching.eli5: Itâ€™s like your browser taking a photo of a page so it doesnâ€™t have to ask for it again next time.
http caching.boss: HTTP caching saves web resources on the browser or CDN to improve load speed and reduce bandwidth.
http caching.sysadmin: Controlled via headers like Cache-Control, ETag, Expires. Can be private (browser) or shared (CDN/intermediaries).
http caching.use_case: Used to cache CSS files for 30 days to avoid re-downloading on every visit.

service worker.eli5: Itâ€™s a helper that runs in the background and lets websites work even when youâ€™re offline.
service worker.boss: A service worker is a script that runs in the background of the browser to enable offline access and background sync.
service worker.sysadmin: Service workers intercept network requests, cache assets, and enable progressive web apps (PWAs). They work independently of web pages.
service worker.use_case: Used to enable offline viewing of a news siteâ€™s last-read articles.

http/2.eli5: Itâ€™s a newer, faster way for websites to talk to your browserâ€”like upgrading from a walkie-talkie to a phone.
http/2.boss: HTTP/2 improves performance with multiplexing, header compression, and server push features.
http/2.sysadmin: HTTP/2 allows concurrent streams over a single TCP connection, reduces latency with HPACK, and supports binary framing.
http/2.use_case: Used to serve a website with multiple JS and image files more efficiently.

http/3.eli5: Itâ€™s the newest way the internet sends infoâ€”faster and more secure, even on spotty connections.
http/3.boss: HTTP/3 builds on HTTP/2 using QUIC protocol for lower latency and better performance.
http/3.sysadmin: HTTP/3 uses QUIC over UDP with TLS 1.3 built-in. It improves handshake time, connection migration, and resilience to packet loss.
http/3.use_case: Used to serve a high-traffic web app with faster loading in poor network conditions.

tls.eli5: Itâ€™s like wrapping your message in a lockbox so no one can peek on its way to the website.
tls.boss: TLS (Transport Layer Security) encrypts data between browsers and servers to protect privacy and security.
tls.sysadmin: TLS uses asymmetric encryption for key exchange and symmetric encryption for data. Supports protocols like HTTPS, SMTP, and VPN tunneling.
tls.use_case: Used to secure login credentials sent to a banking website.

ssl certificate.eli5: Itâ€™s like a secret handshake that proves a website is safe to talk to.
ssl certificate.boss: An SSL certificate is a digital credential that enables encrypted communication between a browser and a website.
ssl certificate.sysadmin: SSL certificates use public key infrastructure (PKI) to verify server identity and encrypt data. They're required for HTTPS and issued by CAs.
ssl certificate.use_case: Used to secure an e-commerce siteâ€™s checkout page and display the padlock icon in the browser.

let's encrypt.eli5: Itâ€™s a free service that gives websites a lock symbol and makes them secure.
let's encrypt.boss: Letâ€™s Encrypt is a nonprofit certificate authority that provides free SSL/TLS certificates for HTTPS.
let's encrypt.sysadmin: Letâ€™s Encrypt uses the ACME protocol to automate domain validation and certificate issuance. Certificates are typically valid for 90 days.
let's encrypt.use_case: Used to secure a personal blog with automatic SSL renewal using Certbot.

compression.eli5: Itâ€™s like squishing your website files so they load faster.
compression.boss: Compression reduces the size of data sent over the internet, improving page load speed and efficiency.
compression.sysadmin: Web servers use Gzip or Brotli to compress responses. Compression is controlled via the `Content-Encoding` HTTP header.
compression.use_case: Used to compress HTML, CSS, and JS files before serving them to browsers.

gzip.eli5: Itâ€™s a way to shrink your website files like a vacuum bag for clothes.
gzip.boss: Gzip is a popular file compression format used to reduce web page and asset sizes for faster delivery.
gzip.sysadmin: Gzip compresses data at the server before sending to the client. Supported by all modern browsers and controlled via web server config.
gzip.use_case: Used to reduce HTML payload size by over 70% for faster site loading.

brotli.eli5: Itâ€™s a newer, smarter way to squish files even smaller than Gzip.
brotli.boss: Brotli is a modern compression algorithm developed by Google that achieves better compression ratios than Gzip.
brotli.sysadmin: Brotli uses context modeling and entropy coding for high compression. Itâ€™s supported by most browsers and NGINX/Apache.
brotli.use_case: Used to compress JavaScript and CSS files for a production web build.

etag.eli5: Itâ€™s like a name tag for a web file that helps your browser know if it changed or not.
etag.boss: ETag (Entity Tag) is an HTTP header used for efficient caching by validating whether a resource has changed.
etag.sysadmin: ETags are hash-like identifiers sent with responses. Clients can send `If-None-Match` to validate cache freshness without re-downloading.
etag.use_case: Used to reduce bandwidth by validating image freshness during repeat visits.

cache-control.eli5: Itâ€™s a set of rules that tells your browser how long to keep stuff before asking again.
cache-control.boss: Cache-Control is an HTTP header that defines how and for how long resources should be cached.
cache-control.sysadmin: It supports directives like `max-age`, `no-cache`, `public`, and `private`. Influences browser and CDN caching behavior.
cache-control.use_case: Used to prevent caching of sensitive pages like `/login` while caching static files for 1 year.

status code.eli5: Itâ€™s a number the website sends to your browser to say how things wentâ€”like 'all good' or 'not found'.
status code.boss: HTTP status codes are numeric messages from the server that indicate the result of a web request.
status code.sysadmin: Codes are grouped by type: 2xx (success), 3xx (redirects), 4xx (client errors), 5xx (server errors). Key for debugging and logging.
status code.use_case: Used to show a 404 error page when a user visits a non-existent URL.

cache api.eli5: Itâ€™s like giving websites a backpack to carry things theyâ€™ll need again later, even offline.
cache api.boss: The Cache API is a browser API that lets web apps store and retrieve network requests for offline or performance use.
cache api.sysadmin: Exposed in service workers, the Cache API allows storing responses keyed by request. It's central to building PWAs.
cache api.use_case: Used to store API responses in a weather app for use when the device is offline.

devtools.eli5: Itâ€™s like a toolkit inside your browser that lets you peek behind the curtain of any website.
devtools.boss: DevTools are built-in browser tools used to inspect, debug, and optimize websites.
devtools.sysadmin: Chrome, Firefox, and Edge DevTools include tabs for inspecting HTML/CSS, network traffic, console logs, performance, and accessibility.
devtools.use_case: Used to debug layout issues and network errors on a slow-loading page.

network tab.eli5: It shows all the behind-the-scenes stuff your browser loadsâ€”like pictures, scripts, and fonts.
network tab.boss: The Network Tab in DevTools tracks all network activity, showing how and when resources are loaded.
network tab.sysadmin: Provides insights on request timing, size, status codes, headers, and caching. Useful for diagnosing performance and fetch errors.
network tab.use_case: Used to identify slow-loading scripts that delay first paint.

console.eli5: Itâ€™s like a message board where the website tells you whatâ€™s going right or wrong.
console.boss: The Console in DevTools displays messages from the website and is used to debug errors or run commands.
console.sysadmin: Displays logs, warnings, and errors via `console.log`, `console.error`, etc. Supports interactive JS execution.
console.use_case: Used to inspect JavaScript errors and view output during development.

elements panel.eli5: Itâ€™s like x-ray visionâ€”you can click and change anything on the page, just for you.
elements panel.boss: The Elements panel lets you view and modify the structure and styles of a webpage in real time.
elements panel.sysadmin: Shows the live DOM and applied CSS. Developers can inspect elements, test style changes, and debug layout issues.
elements panel.use_case: Used to test padding and color changes directly in the browser.

performance tab.eli5: Itâ€™s like a stopwatch and magnifying glass for your website to see what slows it down.
performance tab.boss: The Performance tab in DevTools helps analyze how long each part of a website takes to load or run.
performance tab.sysadmin: Provides flame charts, FPS, scripting time, paint duration, and layout shifts to diagnose performance bottlenecks.
performance tab.use_case: Used to identify long JavaScript execution during page load on a slow device.

lighthouse.eli5: Itâ€™s a robot that checks how good your website is and gives you a scorecard.
lighthouse.boss: Lighthouse is a tool that audits web pages for performance, accessibility, SEO, and best practices.
lighthouse.sysadmin: Lighthouse runs in Chrome or CLI and generates a report with metrics like LCP, CLS, and opportunities for improvement.
lighthouse.use_case: Used to evaluate and improve a mobile siteâ€™s load speed and SEO score.

pagespeed insights.eli5: Itâ€™s a tool from Google that tells you how fast your website is and how to make it better.
pagespeed insights.boss: PageSpeed Insights analyzes a siteâ€™s load performance and provides suggestions to optimize user experience.
pagespeed insights.sysadmin: Provides field and lab data including Core Web Vitals. Based on Lighthouse and CrUX dataset.
pagespeed insights.use_case: Used to improve a homepageâ€™s mobile score by reducing render-blocking scripts.

core web vitals.eli5: Itâ€™s a report card that shows how smooth and fast your website feels to real people.
core web vitals.boss: Core Web Vitals are Googleâ€™s metrics for measuring real-world user experience, especially load, interaction, and visual stability.
core web vitals.sysadmin: Includes LCP (loading), FID (interactivity), CLS (visual stability). Used in performance scoring and SEO ranking.
core web vitals.use_case: Used to optimize a blogâ€™s LCP by lazy-loading images below the fold.

fcp.eli5: Itâ€™s how long it takes before the first thing shows up on your screen.
fcp.boss: FCP (First Contentful Paint) measures how quickly the browser renders the first visible element.
fcp.sysadmin: FCP is recorded in performance APIs and tools like Lighthouse. Lower FCP means faster perceived load time.
fcp.use_case: Used to benchmark how fast a marketing site starts showing content.

lcp.eli5: Itâ€™s how long before the biggest part of the page finishes loadingâ€”like a big picture or heading.
lcp.boss: LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) tracks when the main content of a page becomes visible.
lcp.sysadmin: Part of Core Web Vitals. Measures time from navigation to render of the largest visible element in the viewport.
lcp.use_case: Used to identify image load delays on homepage banners affecting SEO.

critical css.eli5: Itâ€™s the CSS needed to show the top part of your page fastâ€”everything else can wait.
critical css.boss: Critical CSS is the minimum CSS required to render above-the-fold content quickly.
critical css.sysadmin: Extracted and inlined in HTML to speed up FCP/LCP. Reduces render-blocking and improves perceived performance.
critical css.use_case: Used to improve load speed by inlining styles needed for the first screen of a landing page.

defer script.eli5: It tells the browser, 'Donâ€™t stop loading the pageâ€”run this script after youâ€™re done.'
defer script.boss: Using `defer` on script tags delays JavaScript execution until after HTML is parsed, improving page load.
defer script.sysadmin: The `defer` attribute prevents blocking render while preserving script order. Itâ€™s ideal for non-critical JS files.
defer script.use_case: Used to defer analytics scripts to avoid slowing down page rendering.

favicon.eli5: Itâ€™s the little picture you see on your browser tab for a website.
favicon.boss: A favicon is a small icon displayed in browser tabs, bookmarks, and address bars to represent a website.
favicon.sysadmin: Typically an ICO or PNG file linked via `<link rel='icon'>`. Can also support SVG or multiple sizes for device compatibility.
favicon.use_case: Used to brand a blog by showing a unique icon in the browser tab.

manifest.json.eli5: Itâ€™s like an appâ€™s business cardâ€”it tells your phone how to install and display it.
manifest.json.boss: `manifest.json` is a file that tells browsers how to treat a website like an installable app.
manifest.json.sysadmin: Defines app name, icons, colors, display mode, and start URL for PWAs. Linked in `<head>` to enable Add to Home Screen.
manifest.json.use_case: Used to make a weather app installable on Android as a PWA.

radarr.eli5: Itâ€™s like a robot that finds and downloads your favorite movies automatically.
radarr.boss: Radarr is an open-source tool for automating movie downloads, organization, and monitoring.
radarr.sysadmin: Radarr monitors RSS feeds and indexers, integrates with download clients (e.g., qBittorrent, NZBGet), and renames/moves files based on metadata.
radarr.use_case: Used to automatically fetch and organize new 4K movie releases in a Plex library.

borgbackup.eli5: Itâ€™s like a super-smart copy machine that only saves what changed to keep things small and fast.
borgbackup.boss: BorgBackup is a deduplicating backup program that encrypts and compresses data efficiently.
borgbackup.sysadmin: Borg uses content-defined chunking for deduplication, supports AES encryption, and compresses data with zlib, lz4, or zstd. CLI-based.
borgbackup.use_case: Used to back up a homelab server nightly with deduplication and remote SSH targets.

robots.txt.eli5: Imagine a 'do not enter' sign on a door that tells friendly robots (like Google) where they're not allowed to go in your house (website).
robots.txt.boss: robots.txt is a small text file on a website that gives search engines instructions on which pages or sections to skip or avoid indexing.
robots.txt.sysadmin: robots.txt is a plain text file located at the root of a domain, using the Robots Exclusion Protocol to specify user-agent-specific access rules, often to prevent indexing of non-public or duplicate content.
robots.txt.use_case: Blocking Googlebot from indexing staging or development areas of a website.

sitemap.xml.eli5: Think of it like a treasure map that tells search engines where all the rooms in your website are and how to get to them.
sitemap.xml.boss: sitemap.xml is an XML file that lists all the important URLs on a website to help search engines crawl and index content more effectively.
sitemap.xml.sysadmin: sitemap.xml is an XML-based protocol used to define the full structure of a website, including URL priority, update frequency, and last modification dates, aiding in SEO and crawl efficiency.
sitemap.xml.use_case: Submitting a sitemap.xml to Google Search Console to speed up indexing of a new blog.

google search console.eli5: Itâ€™s like a report card from Google that tells you how your website is doing in search results.
google search console.boss: Google Search Console is a free tool by Google that provides insights into how a website performs in search, including visibility, errors, and indexing issues.
google search console.sysadmin: Google Search Console offers a suite of SEO diagnostic and monitoring tools, enabling submission of sitemaps, tracking of crawl errors, search analytics, and structured data validation.
google search console.use_case: Using Search Console to troubleshoot why product pages arenâ€™t appearing in Google results.

bing webmaster tools.eli5: Itâ€™s like Google Search Console but for Bingâ€”it tells you how your site shows up in Bing search results.
bing webmaster tools.boss: Bing Webmaster Tools helps website owners understand their siteâ€™s performance in Bing, offering similar tools as Google Search Console.
bing webmaster tools.sysadmin: Bing Webmaster Tools provides URL inspection, crawl statistics, and SEO reporting to enhance indexing and performance in the Bing search engine.
bing webmaster tools.use_case: Submitting a siteâ€™s sitemap.xml to Bing to improve its presence in Bing search.

accessibility.eli5: Like putting ramps and braille signs on a website so everyone, no matter their abilities, can use it.
accessibility.boss: Accessibility ensures that websites and digital tools are usable by people with disabilities, including visual, auditory, or motor impairments.
accessibility.sysadmin: Accessibility involves implementing standards like WCAG to ensure that web content is perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust across assistive technologies.
accessibility.use_case: Designing a product page that works well with screen readers for visually impaired users.

screen reader.eli5: Itâ€™s like a talking robot that reads the screen out loud so blind users know what's there.
screen reader.boss: A screen reader is software that converts digital content into speech or braille, helping visually impaired users interact with websites and apps.
screen reader.sysadmin: Screen readers parse semantic HTML and ARIA landmarks to provide audio-based navigation for blind and low-vision users.
screen reader.use_case: Testing a website with a screen reader like NVDA to verify that all interactive elements are accessible.

contrast ratio.eli5: Itâ€™s how much a text color stands out from the backgroundâ€”like black words on white paper versus gray on gray.
contrast ratio.boss: Contrast ratio measures the difference in brightness between text and background to ensure readability, especially for users with visual impairments.
contrast ratio.sysadmin: Contrast ratio is calculated from luminance values between foreground and background colors, and must meet WCAG standards (e.g., 4.5:1 for normal text).
contrast ratio.use_case: Using a contrast checker to ensure button text is legible for all users.

focus ring.eli5: A glowing outline that shows which button or link youâ€™re about to click using your keyboard.
focus ring.boss: Focus rings visually indicate which element on the page is selected when navigating with a keyboard, helping with accessibility.
focus ring.sysadmin: Focus rings are CSS outlines or highlights applied to focused elements, aiding keyboard users in maintaining navigation context.
focus ring.use_case: Styling form fields with a visible focus ring to help keyboard users know where they are.

tab index.eli5: Itâ€™s like a line number that tells the keyboard where to jump next when you press the tab key.
tab index.boss: Tab index defines the order in which elements receive keyboard focus, helping users navigate forms and pages without a mouse.
tab index.sysadmin: The `tabindex` attribute controls focus order; positive values alter navigation sequence, zero keeps natural order, and -1 removes focus from tab sequence.
tab index.use_case: Reordering form inputs so the tab key moves in a logical order on mobile devices.

keyboard navigation.eli5: Using arrow keys or Tab instead of a mouse to move around a website.
keyboard navigation.boss: Keyboard navigation allows users to interact with web content using keys like Tab, Enter, and Arrow keysâ€”essential for accessibility.
keyboard navigation.sysadmin: Keyboard navigation depends on HTML semantics, focus management, and JavaScript event handling to support tabbing, skipping, and activating UI elements.
keyboard navigation.use_case: Ensuring a custom dropdown menu is fully operable with keyboard shortcuts alone.

skip link.eli5: Itâ€™s a shortcut button that lets people jump straight to the main content instead of going through all the menus first.
skip link.boss: A skip link is a hidden link that appears when tabbing, letting users bypass navigation and jump to key page content.
skip link.sysadmin: Skip links are anchor tags with `href` targets to main content regions, revealed on focus to support screen readers and keyboard users.
skip link.use_case: Adding a skip link to a government website to improve screen reader usability.

alt attribute.eli5: It's like a photo's caption that tells blind people what the picture shows when they can't see it.
alt attribute.boss: The alt attribute provides a text description of images for screen readers and also displays if the image fails to load.
alt attribute.sysadmin: The `alt` attribute in HTML is used to describe image content for assistive technologies and to support SEO and fallback rendering.
alt attribute.use_case: Adding descriptive alt attributes to product images on an e-commerce site to support screen readers.

aria roles.eli5: Theyâ€™re like name tags that help screen readers understand what each part of a page is supposed to do.
aria roles.boss: ARIA roles define the purpose of web elements, especially dynamic ones, so assistive tools can better understand the interface.
aria roles.sysadmin: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) roles are added to HTML elements to define roles, states, and properties for assistive technologies.
aria roles.use_case: Adding `role=button` to a clickable div so screen readers announce it correctly.

web analytics.eli5: Itâ€™s like counting how many people walk into a store and what they do while browsing.
web analytics.boss: Web analytics tools collect data about website traffic and user behavior to help improve content, SEO, and conversions.
web analytics.sysadmin: Web analytics platforms track events, sessions, and user behavior using JavaScript snippets and cookies for reporting and optimization.
web analytics.use_case: Using web analytics to discover users are dropping off after the checkout page loads slowly.

google analytics.eli5: It tells you who visited your website, when they came, and what they clicked onâ€”like a digital guestbook.
google analytics.boss: Google Analytics is a free tool for tracking user behavior, traffic sources, and conversions on a website.
google analytics.sysadmin: Google Analytics uses a JavaScript tracker to collect pageviews, sessions, and event data, sent to Google's servers for analysis and reporting.
google analytics.use_case: Using Google Analytics to track how many users complete a purchase funnel.

plausible analytics.eli5: Itâ€™s a simpler, privacy-friendly tool that tells you how many people visit your siteâ€”without spying on them.
plausible analytics.boss: Plausible Analytics is a privacy-focused alternative to Google Analytics, offering clean, cookie-free tracking.
plausible analytics.sysadmin: Plausible Analytics is a lightweight JavaScript-based web analytics tool that avoids cookies, supports EU privacy laws, and can be self-hosted.
plausible analytics.use_case: Switching to Plausible Analytics to comply with GDPR and eliminate cookie banners.

matomo.eli5: Itâ€™s like a private Google Analytics that you can run on your own server and control completely.
matomo.boss: Matomo is an open-source web analytics platform that gives full control over data collection, storage, and reporting.
matomo.sysadmin: Matomo offers self-hosted or cloud analytics with detailed visitor tracking, goal conversion, heatmaps, and GDPR compliance features.
matomo.use_case: Using Matomo in an enterprise environment to store visitor analytics locally for compliance reasons.

event tracking.eli5: Itâ€™s like keeping count of every time someone clicks a button, watches a video, or fills out a form on your site.
event tracking.boss: Event tracking records user actions on a website to understand engagement beyond simple page views.
event tracking.sysadmin: Event tracking uses JavaScript or tag managers to log user-triggered actions (clicks, scrolls, video plays) for analytical reporting.
event tracking.use_case: Setting up event tracking to see how many people click the â€˜Downloadâ€™ button.

page view.eli5: Every time someone opens a web page, thatâ€™s one page viewâ€”like turning a page in a book.
page view.boss: A page view is recorded when a user loads a page on your website; itâ€™s a basic metric of site traffic.
page view.sysadmin: A page view occurs when a browser loads or reloads a document; most analytics tools trigger this via a JavaScript snippet.
page view.use_case: Analyzing which blog posts receive the most page views per week.

bounce rate.eli5: If someone walks into a store and immediately walks out, thatâ€™s a bounceâ€”and websites track that too.
bounce rate.boss: Bounce rate shows the percentage of users who visit one page and leave without interacting further.
bounce rate.sysadmin: Bounce rate is calculated when a single-page session ends without any further tracked interactions (events or clicks).
bounce rate.use_case: Using bounce rate to identify poorly engaging landing pages.

session duration.eli5: Itâ€™s how long someone hangs out on your site before leavingâ€”like timing a guestâ€™s visit.
session duration.boss: Session duration measures how long a user spends on your website during a single visit.
session duration.sysadmin: Session duration is computed from the time between the first and last user interaction tracked during a session.
session duration.use_case: Checking average session duration to assess how long visitors engage with content.

conversion rate.eli5: Itâ€™s the number of people who do what you hoped they wouldâ€”like signing up or buying somethingâ€”out of everyone who visited.
conversion rate.boss: Conversion rate is the percentage of website visitors who complete a desired goal, such as a signup or purchase.
conversion rate.sysadmin: Conversion rate = (Number of conversions Ã· Total sessions) Ã— 100; it's key for evaluating funnel performance and A/B tests.
conversion rate.use_case: Monitoring conversion rates during a marketing campaign to see if changes lead to more sales.

heatmap.eli5: Itâ€™s like a thermal camera for your websiteâ€”it shows where people click, move, or hover the most.
heatmap.boss: Heatmaps visually represent user interaction data, like clicks or scrolling behavior, to improve site design and UX.
heatmap.sysadmin: A heatmap overlays data visualizations onto web pages to track user interactions, often using client-side event logging.
heatmap.use_case: Using heatmaps to optimize the homepage layout based on user click patterns.

a/b testing.eli5: Itâ€™s like trying two versions of a lemonade stand sign to see which one brings in more customers.
a/b testing.boss: A/B testing compares two versions of a webpage or feature to see which performs better based on user behavior.
a/b testing.sysadmin: A/B testing splits traffic between variant A and B, tracking conversion or event metrics to evaluate statistical significance.
a/b testing.use_case: Running A/B tests on two signup button styles to see which gets more clicks.

cookies.eli5: Theyâ€™re tiny notes your browser keeps to remember who you are when you come back to a site.
cookies.boss: Cookies are small text files stored in a userâ€™s browser to remember login info, preferences, and activity.
cookies.sysadmin: Cookies are HTTP header-based storage mechanisms used to persist session data, preferences, and tracking identifiers on client browsers.
cookies.use_case: Using cookies to keep a user logged in across sessions.

first-party cookie.eli5: Itâ€™s like a store giving you a loyalty cardâ€”it only works at that one store.
first-party cookie.boss: First-party cookies are created by the website you're visiting to remember preferences, logins, or settings.
first-party cookie.sysadmin: First-party cookies are set by the domain shown in the browser's address bar and are typically used for session persistence and user preferences.
first-party cookie.use_case: Remembering a user's preferred language when they return to your website.

third-party cookie.eli5: Itâ€™s like a stranger watching what stores you visit so they can show you ads later.
third-party cookie.boss: Third-party cookies are created by domains other than the one you're visiting and are often used for ad tracking.
third-party cookie.sysadmin: Third-party cookies are set by embedded scripts or services from other domains (like ad networks), often triggering privacy concerns and restrictions.
third-party cookie.use_case: Tracking user behavior across websites for retargeted advertising.

secure cookie.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting your cookie in a locked box that only opens on secure (HTTPS) roads.
secure cookie.boss: A secure cookie is only sent over HTTPS connections, protecting it from eavesdropping.
secure cookie.sysadmin: Secure cookies have the `Secure` attribute set, ensuring transmission only over encrypted HTTPS to mitigate sniffing attacks.
secure cookie.use_case: Using secure cookies for session tokens to avoid exposure over unencrypted connections.

httponly cookie.eli5: Itâ€™s a cookie that only your browser can seeâ€”not websites or sneaky scripts.
httponly cookie.boss: HttpOnly cookies canâ€™t be accessed by JavaScript, helping protect against XSS attacks.
httponly cookie.sysadmin: An HttpOnly cookie is set with the `HttpOnly` flag, preventing access via client-side scripts, enhancing session security.
httponly cookie.use_case: Securing authentication tokens by marking them as HttpOnly to prevent theft via JavaScript.

samesite cookie.eli5: It's a cookie that refuses to travel to other websitesâ€”like a homebody that stays put.
samesite cookie.boss: SameSite cookies help limit cross-site tracking by restricting when cookies are sent to other domains.
samesite cookie.sysadmin: SameSite is a cookie attribute (`Strict`, `Lax`, or `None`) that controls cross-site request behavior to prevent CSRF attacks.
samesite cookie.use_case: Setting `SameSite=Lax` on login cookies to avoid cross-site request forgery.

local storage.eli5: Itâ€™s like a small notepad your browser keeps for each website to remember stuff, even when you leave.
local storage.boss: Local storage lets websites store data on your browser that doesnâ€™t disappear when you close the page.
local storage.sysadmin: LocalStorage is a Web Storage API providing persistent key-value storage in the browser with no expiration.
local storage.use_case: Saving theme preference or user settings between sessions without using cookies.

session storage.eli5: Itâ€™s a chalkboard that gets erased when you close the browser tab.
session storage.boss: Session storage holds website data temporarily and clears it once the browser tab is closed.
session storage.sysadmin: SessionStorage is part of the Web Storage API that stores key-value pairs scoped to a single session and tab.
session storage.use_case: Storing temporary form data while filling out a multi-page signup flow.

indexeddb.eli5: Itâ€™s a mini filing cabinet in your browser where websites can store more complex data.
indexeddb.boss: IndexedDB is a browser-based database that lets websites store large amounts of structured data locally.
indexeddb.sysadmin: IndexedDB is a low-level API for storing structured data (like JSON or blobs) using object stores and indexes for offline-ready apps.
indexeddb.use_case: Using IndexedDB to cache app data for offline use in a progressive web app.

media queries.eli5: They let your website wear different clothes depending on screen sizeâ€”like jeans for a phone and a suit for a desktop.
media queries.boss: Media queries are CSS rules that adjust a websiteâ€™s layout and styles based on the device's screen size or type.
media queries.sysadmin: Media queries use the `@media` rule in CSS to apply conditional styling based on viewport size, resolution, orientation, and more.
media queries.use_case: Creating different layouts for mobile and desktop using CSS media queries.

touch events.eli5: They help websites know when youâ€™re poking or swiping your screen instead of clicking a mouse.
touch events.boss: Touch events let websites respond to finger gestures on touchscreens, like taps, swipes, or pinches.
touch events.sysadmin: Touch Events API provides access to input from touch-enabled devices via events like `touchstart`, `touchmove`, and `touchend`.
touch events.use_case: Adding swipe navigation to a mobile web gallery using touch events.

device pixel ratio.eli5: Itâ€™s how many tiny dots your screen uses to draw one â€˜regularâ€™ dotâ€”more dots = sharper image.
device pixel ratio.boss: Device Pixel Ratio (DPR) compares physical screen pixels to CSS pixels, affecting how crisp content appears.
device pixel ratio.sysadmin: DPR is the ratio of physical pixels to device-independent pixels, often used for responsive images and scaling UI elements.
device pixel ratio.use_case: Serving high-resolution images to retina displays using the deviceâ€™s pixel ratio.

performance optimization.eli5: Itâ€™s like cleaning your room so visitors donâ€™t trip over stuffâ€”your website runs faster and smoother.
performance optimization.boss: Performance optimization improves website speed and responsiveness to enhance user experience and search rankings.
performance optimization.sysadmin: Performance optimization involves reducing render-blocking resources, minimizing asset size, optimizing network requests, and improving runtime execution.
performance optimization.use_case: Reducing page load time by lazy-loading images and minifying scripts.

lazy loading.eli5: It means loading stuff only when you need itâ€”like grabbing snacks from the fridge when you're hungry, not all at once.
lazy loading.boss: Lazy loading delays loading of non-essential content, like images or videos, until itâ€™s visible on screen.
lazy loading.sysadmin: Lazy loading defers fetching or rendering DOM elements until triggered by viewport intersection or scrolling events to save bandwidth.
lazy loading.use_case: Improving initial load speed by lazy loading product images below the fold.

image compression.eli5: Itâ€™s like zipping your pictures so they load faster but still look nice.
image compression.boss: Image compression reduces file size to speed up website loading without noticeably losing quality.
image compression.sysadmin: Image compression uses lossy or lossless algorithms (like WebP, MozJPEG) to minimize file size for faster transfer and rendering.
image compression.use_case: Compressing product photos to reduce page weight and improve mobile performance.

minification.eli5: Itâ€™s like shortening your grocery list by removing all the extra spaces and commentsâ€”same info, smaller package.
minification.boss: Minification shrinks code files by removing spaces, comments, and unused code to boost load speed.
minification.sysadmin: Minification removes unnecessary characters from CSS, JS, or HTML using tools like UglifyJS or Terser to optimize performance.
minification.use_case: Minifying CSS and JS files before deploying a production website.

debounce.eli5: Itâ€™s like waiting for someone to stop talking before you replyâ€”prevents too many reactions too fast.
debounce.boss: Debouncing limits how often a function runs, making apps faster and smoother by reducing unnecessary calls.
debounce.sysadmin: Debounce is a programming technique that ensures a function executes only after a defined delay since the last call, often used in input events.
debounce.use_case: Debouncing a search input so it only fetches results after the user stops typing.

throttle.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting a speed limit on how often something can happenâ€”even if you keep asking, itâ€™ll only respond so fast.
throttle.boss: Throttling ensures that a function runs at a consistent rate, preventing performance issues from rapid triggers.
throttle.sysadmin: Throttling enforces a limit on how frequently a function can be called over timeâ€”unlike debounce, it ensures periodic execution.
throttle.use_case: Throttling scroll events to avoid janky performance during heavy user interaction.

preload.eli5: Itâ€™s like setting out ingredients before cookingâ€”things are ready before you need them.
preload.boss: Preload is a hint to the browser to fetch important resources early to speed up rendering.
preload.sysadmin: Using `<link rel='preload'>`, developers can instruct the browser to prioritize loading specific assets like fonts or scripts before rendering begins.
preload.use_case: Preloading fonts to prevent flash of unstyled text (FOIT) during initial page load.

prefetch.eli5: Itâ€™s like packing snacks in case you get hungry laterâ€”it loads stuff you might need soon.
prefetch.boss: Prefetching lets a browser download resources it might need later, improving speed for future pages.
prefetch.sysadmin: Using `<link rel='prefetch'>`, a browser loads resources in idle time based on expected future navigation or use.
prefetch.use_case: Prefetching the next article's script to speed up navigation in a blog.

lxd.eli5: Itâ€™s like having little apartments (containers) inside your computer that act like mini-computers.
lxd.boss: LXD is a container manager for running and managing system containers with virtual machine-like capabilities.
lxd.sysadmin: LXD is a REST API-driven manager for LXC containers, offering user-friendly commands and support for full system containers and VMs.
lxd.use_case: Running multiple isolated Ubuntu environments on a single host using LXD.

kubernetes.eli5: Itâ€™s like a robot manager that keeps lots of little apps running smoothly across many computers.
kubernetes.boss: Kubernetes is an open-source platform that automates deploying, scaling, and managing containerized applications.
kubernetes.sysadmin: Kubernetes orchestrates container workloads across clusters, managing pods, services, volumes, and deployments using declarative configs and controllers.
kubernetes.use_case: Using Kubernetes to manage scalable microservices across multiple cloud servers.

k3s.eli5: Itâ€™s a smaller, simpler version of Kubernetes that fits on your Raspberry Pi.
k3s.boss: K3s is a lightweight Kubernetes distribution designed for resource-constrained devices and edge computing.
k3s.sysadmin: K3s is a single-binary Kubernetes distribution optimized for IoT, edge, and CI/CD, reducing dependencies and resource usage.
k3s.use_case: Running k3s on a home lab to deploy small-scale container apps with minimal overhead.

microk8s.eli5: Itâ€™s a pocket-sized version of Kubernetes for quick testing and small environments.
microk8s.boss: MicroK8s is a minimal, easy-to-install Kubernetes distribution ideal for development and edge devices.
microk8s.sysadmin: MicroK8s is a Canonical-supported, snap-based Kubernetes deployment targeting developers, IoT, and lightweight clusters.
microk8s.use_case: Spinning up a MicroK8s cluster on a laptop for local testing of Kubernetes manifests.

samba.eli5: Itâ€™s like giving your Linux computer the ability to share folders with Windows computers.
samba.boss: Samba is software that lets Linux systems share files and printers with Windows over a network.
samba.sysadmin: Samba implements SMB/CIFS protocols, enabling interoperability with Windows file and printer sharing, Active Directory, and network browsing.
samba.use_case: Using Samba on a NAS to share a folder with Windows machines in a home network.

replicaset.eli5: Itâ€™s like a clone machine in Kubernetes that makes sure you always have a certain number of identical workers.
replicaset.boss: A ReplicaSet in Kubernetes ensures a specified number of identical pod copies are always running.
replicaset.sysadmin: ReplicaSet is a Kubernetes controller that maintains a stable set of replica pods by monitoring and adjusting the number based on desired state.
replicaset.use_case: Using a ReplicaSet to ensure three instances of a web service are always available in a cluster.

csrf.eli5: Itâ€™s like someone tricking your browser into pressing a button on a site while you're still logged in.
csrf.boss: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) is an attack that tricks users into performing actions on a website without their intent.
csrf.sysadmin: CSRF exploits the trust a site has in a userâ€™s browser by forging unauthorized requests, often mitigated using CSRF tokens or SameSite cookies.
csrf.use_case: Adding CSRF tokens to form submissions in a banking app to prevent unauthorized transfers.

subresource integrity.eli5: Itâ€™s like checking the fingerprint of a file before using it to make sure it wasnâ€™t tampered with.
subresource integrity.boss: Subresource Integrity (SRI) ensures that third-party scripts or stylesheets havenâ€™t been altered before loading them into your site.
subresource integrity.sysadmin: SRI uses cryptographic hash attributes in `<script>` or `<link>` tags to verify the integrity of externally loaded resources.
subresource integrity.use_case: Adding SRI hashes to CDN-hosted JavaScript libraries to prevent malicious code injection.

hsts.eli5: It tells browsers, 'Always use the secure door (HTTPS) from now on.'
hsts.boss: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) forces browsers to use HTTPS connections only, protecting users from downgrade attacks.
hsts.sysadmin: HSTS is an HTTP response header (`Strict-Transport-Security`) that instructs browsers to enforce HTTPS-only communication with a domain.
hsts.use_case: Configuring HSTS on a website to prevent users from accidentally visiting the HTTP version.

referrer policy.eli5: It controls how much of your websiteâ€™s 'where I came from' info gets shared with others.
referrer policy.boss: Referrer Policy is a browser setting that controls how much referral information is passed when navigating between pages or sites.
referrer policy.sysadmin: Set via the `Referrer-Policy` header, it dictates whether full, partial, or no referrer URLs are sent in requests for privacy and security.
referrer policy.use_case: Using `Referrer-Policy: strict-origin` to hide query strings when users navigate away from your site.

permissions policy.eli5: Itâ€™s like telling your browser which tools (like camera or location) itâ€™s allowed to use on a website.
permissions policy.boss: Permissions Policy allows websites to control which features like camera, mic, or fullscreen are allowed to run in the browser.
permissions policy.sysadmin: Formerly Feature-Policy, it's an HTTP header or meta tag restricting access to powerful browser features like geolocation or clipboard.
permissions policy.use_case: Restricting iframe access to geolocation using `Permissions-Policy: geolocation=()`.

secure headers.eli5: Theyâ€™re like instructions on your front door telling visitors how to behave safely.
secure headers.boss: Secure headers are HTTP response headers that help protect websites from common attacks like XSS, clickjacking, and content sniffing.
secure headers.sysadmin: Secure headers include HSTS, CSP, X-Frame-Options, Referrer-Policy, and others that enforce security controls at the browser level.
secure headers.use_case: Using a middleware to automatically set secure headers in a Node.js app.

version control.eli5: Itâ€™s like having a time machine for your codeâ€”you can rewind, fast forward, or branch off to try new things.
version control.boss: Version control systems track changes to code over time, allowing teams to collaborate and revert mistakes easily.
version control.sysadmin: Version control manages source code history using tools like Git, enabling branching, merging, tagging, and rollback.
version control.use_case: Using version control to track changes and collaborate on a web development project.

git.eli5: Git helps you save your work and go back if you mess upâ€”like checkpoint saves in a video game.
git.boss: Git is a distributed version control system that helps developers track, share, and manage code changes.
git.sysadmin: Git stores snapshots of file states, supports branching and merging, and enables decentralized workflows through commits and repositories.
git.use_case: Using Git to manage feature development in separate branches before merging into production.

github.eli5: Itâ€™s like social media for codeâ€”where developers share, review, and work on code together.
github.boss: GitHub is a platform for hosting Git repositories with tools for collaboration, CI/CD, and project management.
github.sysadmin: GitHub offers Git-based source control with web UI, issue tracking, pull requests, GitHub Actions, and integration with third-party tools.
github.use_case: Hosting an open-source library on GitHub and using pull requests for contributions.

gitlab.eli5: Itâ€™s like GitHubâ€™s cousin that also helps with building and testing your code automatically.
gitlab.boss: GitLab is a DevOps platform combining Git repository hosting with built-in CI/CD and issue tracking.
gitlab.sysadmin: GitLab provides source control, CI/CD pipelines, container registry, and project planning features in a single interface.
gitlab.use_case: Using GitLab to host private repositories and automate builds with GitLab CI.

bitbucket.eli5: Itâ€™s another place to store your code and work on it with friends, like GitHub or GitLab.
bitbucket.boss: Bitbucket is a code hosting and collaboration platform by Atlassian that supports Git and Mercurial.
bitbucket.sysadmin: Bitbucket offers Git repository hosting with Jira integration, CI/CD (Bitbucket Pipelines), and permissions management.
bitbucket.use_case: Using Bitbucket for source control in an organization that already uses Jira for project tracking.

commit.eli5: Itâ€™s like saving a snapshot of your project so you can go back to it later.
commit.boss: A commit saves a set of changes in version control, acting as a checkpoint in the projectâ€™s history.
commit.sysadmin: A Git commit records staged changes in the repository along with a message and unique hash ID.
commit.use_case: Writing meaningful commit messages to document progress during development.

branch.eli5: Itâ€™s like making a copy of your project so you can try new ideas without messing up the original.
branch.boss: Branches allow teams to work on features or fixes in isolation before merging them into the main project.
branch.sysadmin: A branch in Git is a pointer to a commit, enabling concurrent development and isolated testing of changes.
branch.use_case: Creating a new branch to develop a login feature separately from the main codebase.

merge.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting two versions of a story together into one final copy.
merge.boss: Merging combines code changes from different branches into a single unified version.
merge.sysadmin: Git merge integrates commits from a source branch into a target branch, preserving history and resolving conflicts.
merge.use_case: Merging a feature branch into `main` after successful testing.

pull request.eli5: Itâ€™s like asking your team, 'Can you check and add my changes to the main story?'
pull request.boss: A pull request is a request to review and merge code changes from one branch into another, often with comments and approvals.
pull request.sysadmin: Pull requests in GitHub or GitLab facilitate code review, discussion, and testing before merging branches.
pull request.use_case: Submitting a pull request for code review after finishing a new feature.

ci/cd.eli5: Itâ€™s like a robot that tests and ships your code every time you make a change.
ci/cd.boss: CI/CD automates the building, testing, and deployment of code changes to speed up development and reduce errors.
ci/cd.sysadmin: CI/CD stands for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment/Deliveryâ€”pipelines that automate code validation and deployment across environments.
ci/cd.use_case: Using CI/CD to automatically test and deploy code to staging after each push to GitHub.

github actions.eli5: Theyâ€™re like little robots that do jobs for you when something happens in your GitHub project.
github actions.boss: GitHub Actions automate workflows like testing and deployment directly from your GitHub repositories.
github actions.sysadmin: GitHub Actions run configurable YAML workflows triggered by repository events, supporting build/test/deploy automation via runners and containers.
github actions.use_case: Using GitHub Actions to run unit tests every time someone submits a pull request.

netlify deploys.eli5: Itâ€™s like auto-uploading your updated website every time you make a change.
netlify deploys.boss: Netlify Deploys automatically publish your site whenever you push new code to a connected Git repo.
netlify deploys.sysadmin: Netlify listens for Git events and runs build scripts to deploy static or Jamstack sites with preview URLs and atomic updates.
netlify deploys.use_case: Triggering a Netlify deploy every time changes are pushed to the `main` branch.

vercel previews.eli5: Every time you make a change, it gives you a sneak peek before showing it to the world.
vercel previews.boss: Vercel Previews provide temporary URLs for each pull request or branch so teams can review changes before going live.
vercel previews.sysadmin: Vercel auto-deploys preview environments from Git branches or PRs, enabling visual testing with custom domains and rollback.
vercel previews.use_case: Using Vercel Previews to show stakeholders the staging version of a new landing page.

static site generator.eli5: Itâ€™s like baking a cake ahead of time so itâ€™s ready to serve fastâ€”your website is pre-made, not built on demand.
static site generator.boss: Static site generators turn content and templates into ready-to-serve HTML pages, boosting performance and security.
static site generator.sysadmin: Static site generators like Hugo or Jekyll compile markdown and templates into HTML at build time, often used in Jamstack.
static site generator.use_case: Using Eleventy to generate a fast-loading personal blog with no backend server.

build time.eli5: Itâ€™s the time your site spends getting dressed and ready before going out to the internet.
build time.boss: Build time is when a static site or app is compiled or assembled before deployment to a server or CDN.
build time.sysadmin: Build time refers to the process where source code, templates, and assets are compiled into a deployable format, often via CI/CD pipelines.
build time.use_case: Monitoring build time in Netlify to speed up large blog site deployments.

incremental static regeneration.eli5: Itâ€™s like updating only the parts of your website that change, instead of rebuilding the whole thing.
incremental static regeneration.boss: Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR) lets static websites update individual pages after deployment without a full rebuild.
incremental static regeneration.sysadmin: ISR is a feature in frameworks like Next.js allowing statically generated pages to be re-rendered on-demand or on a timer, combining static speed with dynamic flexibility.
incremental static regeneration.use_case: Using ISR to regenerate only blog post pages when content updates in a headless CMS.

server-side rendering.eli5: Itâ€™s like the chef making your burger before you walk in, instead of giving you raw ingredients.
server-side rendering.boss: Server-side rendering (SSR) builds web pages on the server and sends the finished HTML to the browser, improving SEO and initial load speed.
server-side rendering.sysadmin: SSR renders content on each request via backend logic, commonly used in frameworks like Next.js or Nuxt for dynamic data and SEO advantages.
server-side rendering.use_case: Using SSR to improve SEO for a product page that displays dynamic inventory data.

client-side rendering.eli5: Itâ€™s like a make-your-own-sundae barâ€”you get the ingredients, and your browser does the assembling.
client-side rendering.boss: Client-side rendering (CSR) builds web pages in the userâ€™s browser, allowing for smoother interactions but slower first loads.
client-side rendering.sysadmin: CSR delivers a basic HTML shell and relies on JavaScript (usually via SPA frameworks) to render content on the client after load.
client-side rendering.use_case: Using React for CSR to build a dynamic dashboard that updates live data after load.

hybrid rendering.eli5: Itâ€™s like a restaurant where some meals are made ahead and others cooked fresh when you orderâ€”best of both worlds.
hybrid rendering.boss: Hybrid rendering combines server-side and client-side rendering to optimize both speed and interactivity.
hybrid rendering.sysadmin: In frameworks like Next.js, hybrid rendering allows per-route control over SSR, CSR, and static generation depending on the pageâ€™s content type.
hybrid rendering.use_case: Using hybrid rendering to pre-render marketing pages while dynamically rendering user dashboards.

jamstack.eli5: Itâ€™s like a pre-packed lunchâ€”you prepare everything ahead so itâ€™s fast and ready to go.
jamstack.boss: Jamstack is a modern web architecture that uses pre-rendered static content served via CDNs, backed by APIs and JavaScript.
jamstack.sysadmin: Jamstack (JavaScript, APIs, Markup) decouples the frontend from the backend, using static site generators, headless CMSs, and serverless functions for performance and scalability.
jamstack.use_case: Building a fast-loading blog using Jamstack with a headless CMS and Netlify for deployment.

web fonts.eli5: Theyâ€™re fancy text styles your website downloads so it can look cooler than plain old fonts.
web fonts.boss: Web fonts are downloadable typefaces that improve design consistency across devices and browsers.
web fonts.sysadmin: Web fonts are served via CSS `@font-face` or external services like Google Fonts to deliver typography independent of system defaults.
web fonts.use_case: Using web fonts to apply brand-consistent typography on a landing page.

google fonts.eli5: Itâ€™s a free online font library your website can use to make text look stylish.
google fonts.boss: Google Fonts provides a library of web-safe fonts that designers and developers can integrate into websites for free.
google fonts.sysadmin: Google Fonts hosts open-source font files via CDN, used by linking CSS stylesheets or embedding `@import` in stylesheets.
google fonts.use_case: Embedding Google Fonts into a portfolio site for consistent typography across browsers.

font display.eli5: Itâ€™s how a website decides whether to show fallback text or wait for your fancy font to load.
font display.boss: Font display controls how web fonts load and renderâ€”instantly with fallback or delayed until fully ready.
font display.sysadmin: The `font-display` CSS property determines whether text uses fallback fonts, blocks rendering, or swaps in custom fonts when available.
font display.use_case: Using `font-display: swap` to prevent blank text while a web font loads.

fout.eli5: Itâ€™s when your site shows the backup font for a second before switching to the pretty one.
fout.boss: Flash of Unstyled Text (FOUT) is a momentary appearance of fallback fonts before the custom font loads.
fout.sysadmin: FOUT occurs when text is rendered using a fallback font until the custom web font is loaded, often mitigated using `font-display: swap`.
fout.use_case: Accepting FOUT behavior on mobile to prioritize quick content visibility.

foit.eli5: Itâ€™s when your website hides all text until the fancy font finishes loadingâ€”like waiting to change clothes before showing up.
foit.boss: Flash of Invisible Text (FOIT) happens when a browser hides text until the custom font loads, causing a temporary blank area.
foit.sysadmin: FOIT is caused by `font-display: block`, where browsers delay rendering text until the web font is fully available.
foit.use_case: Reducing FOIT by setting `font-display: fallback` in font styles.

mobile web.eli5: Itâ€™s just the internetâ€”but designed to look good and work smoothly on your phone.
mobile web.boss: Mobile web refers to websites optimized for viewing and interaction on smartphones and tablets.
mobile web.sysadmin: Mobile web uses responsive design, viewport settings, and mobile-first CSS/media queries to ensure usability across screen sizes.
mobile web.use_case: Designing a product landing page to load quickly and render well on mobile browsers.

viewport.eli5: Itâ€™s the window your phone or browser uses to look at a websiteâ€”different sizes mean different views.
viewport.boss: Viewport defines the visible area of a webpage within the browser window, especially important for mobile responsiveness.
viewport.sysadmin: The viewport is controlled via the `<meta name='viewport'>` tag, affecting scaling and layout on different device screens.
viewport.use_case: Using the viewport meta tag to enable proper scaling on smartphones.

gpu passthrough.eli5: Itâ€™s like letting a virtual computer borrow your graphics card to play games or do video editing.
gpu passthrough.boss: GPU passthrough allows a virtual machine to directly access a physical GPU for improved graphics performance.
gpu passthrough.sysadmin: GPU passthrough uses technologies like VT-d and IOMMU to assign a physical GPU to a VM, bypassing the host OS.
gpu passthrough.use_case: Running Windows in a VM with GPU passthrough for gaming on a Linux host.

nested virtualization.eli5: Itâ€™s like running a computer inside a computer thatâ€™s inside another computerâ€”super Inception style.
nested virtualization.boss: Nested virtualization enables running a virtual machine inside another virtual machine for testing or dev environments.
nested virtualization.sysadmin: Nested virtualization leverages hypervisor extensions (like Intel VT-x or AMD-V) to allow a VM to host additional VMs.
nested virtualization.use_case: Testing Proxmox inside a VM on a cloud provider that supports nested virtualization.

vswitch.eli5: Itâ€™s like a digital power strip for connecting virtual computers together on the same network.
vswitch.boss: A vSwitch (virtual switch) is software that connects virtual machines to each other and the physical network.
vswitch.sysadmin: vSwitches simulate Ethernet switching at the hypervisor level, enabling inter-VM communication and external network access via bridges.
vswitch.use_case: Using a vSwitch in VMware to isolate internal traffic between test VMs.

snapshots.eli5: Theyâ€™re like save points in a video gameâ€”you can go back to them if something breaks.
snapshots.boss: Snapshots capture the exact state of a virtual machine or filesystem at a point in time for recovery.
snapshots.sysadmin: Snapshots preserve VM memory, disk state, and settings for rollback, backup, or cloning, often used in hypervisors and ZFS.
snapshots.use_case: Taking a snapshot before applying system updates on a production VM.

vm templates.eli5: Theyâ€™re like pre-built blueprints for new virtual computersâ€”just copy and go.
vm templates.boss: VM templates are preconfigured virtual machines used to quickly deploy new VMs with consistent settings.
vm templates.sysadmin: A VM template is a base image with pre-installed OS and settings, allowing efficient provisioning and standardization of VMs.
vm templates.use_case: Using VM templates to deploy multiple Ubuntu VMs with the same config in Proxmox.

cloning.eli5: Itâ€™s like making a twin of your virtual computer to use for testing or backups.
cloning.boss: Cloning creates an identical copy of a VM or disk, useful for testing, scaling, or backups.
cloning.sysadmin: Cloning duplicates a VM, including its storage and config, either as a full or linked clone, depending on the platform.
cloning.use_case: Cloning a base VM to quickly spin up multiple isolated test environments.

ha.eli5: It makes sure your services stay up and runningâ€”even if something crashes.
ha.boss: High Availability (HA) ensures systems automatically recover from failure, minimizing downtime.
ha.sysadmin: HA uses redundancy, failover mechanisms, and clustering to maintain service uptime during hardware or software failures.
ha.use_case: Setting up HA for Docker containers using Keepalived and a floating IP.

docker.eli5: Itâ€™s like a magic lunchboxâ€”you pack up an app and everything it needs to run, and it works anywhere.
docker.boss: Docker packages apps into containers with their dependencies so they can run consistently across environments.
docker.sysadmin: Docker uses containerization to isolate applications in lightweight, portable units with their runtime, libraries, and configs.
docker.use_case: Running a WordPress site in a Docker container on your local machine.

docker compose.eli5: Itâ€™s like a recipe for your appâ€”it tells Docker what to cook and how to serve everything together.
docker compose.boss: Docker Compose simplifies managing multi-container apps with a single YAML file defining services and configurations.
docker compose.sysadmin: Docker Compose reads a `docker-compose.yml` file to spin up multiple services with shared networks, volumes, and environment configs.
docker compose.use_case: Using Docker Compose to run a web app, database, and cache in one command.

podman.eli5: Itâ€™s like Dockerâ€™s quieter cousinâ€”it runs containers but doesnâ€™t need a big boss program running in the background.
podman.boss: Podman is a daemonless container engine compatible with Docker that emphasizes security and rootless containers.
podman.sysadmin: Podman runs OCI containers and pods without requiring a daemon, supporting rootless execution, systemd integration, and Docker CLI compatibility.
podman.use_case: Using Podman to run containers in rootless mode on a secure server.

lxc.eli5: Itâ€™s like giving each app its own little jail cell with its own kitchen and bathroom.
lxc.boss: LXC is a lightweight virtualization method that runs multiple isolated Linux systems on a single host.
lxc.sysadmin: LXC (Linux Containers) provides OS-level virtualization using cgroups and namespaces to isolate environments.
lxc.use_case: Using LXC to run an Ubuntu container alongside a CentOS one on the same host.

haproxy.eli5: Itâ€™s like a smart traffic cop that directs cars (users) to the right lane (server).
haproxy.boss: HAProxy is a reliable open-source load balancer that distributes traffic across multiple servers.
haproxy.sysadmin: HAProxy is a high-performance TCP/HTTP load balancer and reverse proxy with advanced routing, health checks, and SSL termination.
haproxy.use_case: Using HAProxy to balance traffic between multiple web servers behind a single IP.

jellyfin.eli5: Itâ€™s like your own private Netflix that you run at home and control yourself.
jellyfin.boss: Jellyfin is a free, open-source media server that lets users organize and stream movies, TV shows, and music.
jellyfin.sysadmin: Jellyfin offers self-hosted media library management with support for transcoding, user profiles, and web-based streaming.
jellyfin.use_case: Setting up Jellyfin on a Raspberry Pi to stream your local movie collection to smart TVs.

plex.eli5: Itâ€™s like a digital DVD shelf that you can watch from anywhereâ€”even on your phone.
plex.boss: Plex is a media server that organizes your personal media and streams it to various devices with a polished interface.
plex.sysadmin: Plex offers centralized media library management, transcoding, remote access, and integration with Plexâ€™s online content services.
plex.use_case: Using Plex to stream your personal movie collection from a NAS to a smart TV and mobile devices.

emby.eli5: Itâ€™s another home media serverâ€”like Jellyfin or Plexâ€”but with some features behind a paywall.
emby.boss: Emby is a media server for managing and streaming personal content, offering both free and premium features.
emby.sysadmin: Emby provides cross-platform media management, user profiles, and transcoding, with optional paid features like DVR and app support.
emby.use_case: Hosting Emby on a home server to stream family videos to multiple smart TVs.

zfs snapshot.eli5: Itâ€™s like a magical photo of your data that you can use to go back in time if something breaks.
zfs snapshot.boss: ZFS snapshots are instant, space-efficient copies of your data that can be used for backups or rollbacks.
zfs snapshot.sysadmin: ZFS snapshots capture block-level changes in the filesystem, enabling rollback, replication, and backup consistency with minimal overhead.
zfs snapshot.use_case: Creating ZFS snapshots before applying updates to a file server for rollback protection.

bonding.eli5: Itâ€™s like tying two internet cables together to get more speed or backup in case one breaks.
bonding.boss: Network bonding combines multiple network interfaces into one for increased bandwidth or redundancy.
bonding.sysadmin: Bonding uses link aggregation techniques (like LACP or active-backup) to combine NICs at the OS level for performance or failover.
bonding.use_case: Bonding two Ethernet ports on a NAS for faster transfers and failover protection.

installable app.eli5: Like saving a website to your phone's home screen so it works almost like a regular app.
installable app.boss: An installable app is a web-based application that users can add to their device's home screen for faster, app-like access.
installable app.sysadmin: Installable apps refer to Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) that utilize a web app manifest and service worker to allow users to install them on their devices, enabling features like offline usage and push notifications.
installable app.use_case: A user installs a budgeting PWA on their phone to manage finances offline without going through the app store.

add to home screen.eli5: It's like pinning your favorite website to your phone for quick access.
add to home screen.boss: A feature allowing users to save web apps to their home screen for an app-like experience.
add to home screen.sysadmin: This feature is part of Progressive Web Apps (PWAs), utilizing a manifest and service worker to create a shortcut icon on mobile or desktop devices, enabling quick launches and full-screen operation.
add to home screen.use_case: A news site prompts users to 'Add to Home Screen' for faster daily updates with fewer taps.

background sync.eli5: Itâ€™s like sending a message while offline, and your phone automatically sends it once youâ€™re back online.
background sync.boss: Background Sync lets web apps schedule tasks to complete later when a device regains connectivity.
background sync.sysadmin: A service worker API that allows deferred actions (like sending POST data) to execute when the device reconnects to the internet, maintaining app functionality offline.
background sync.use_case: A user fills out a support form on a web app offline, and it's submitted automatically once they reconnect.

home lab.eli5: Like building your own mini data center at home to play with tech stuff safely.
home lab.boss: A home lab is a private setup of servers, networking, and software used for learning, testing, or running personal projects.
home lab.sysadmin: A self-managed environment where IT professionals or hobbyists use virtualization, containerization, and automation to simulate production scenarios or host services for experimentation.
home lab.use_case: A sysadmin uses a home lab running Proxmox to test out an Ansible deployment strategy before rolling it to production.

rackmount server.eli5: A big, flat computer that slides into a tech closet like a DVD into a player.
rackmount server.boss: Rackmount servers are flat, horizontal systems designed to be mounted in standardized server racks for organized IT infrastructure.
rackmount server.sysadmin: A 1U-4U form factor server that mounts in a 19-inch rack, offering scalability and centralized management in data centers or home labs.
rackmount server.use_case: A user mounts a used Dell PowerEdge in their home lab rack to host VMs using ESXi.

mini pc.eli5: A tiny computer that fits in your hand but does almost everything a big one can.
mini pc.boss: Mini PCs are compact computers used for basic workloads, media centers, or light server tasks.
mini pc.sysadmin: Small-form-factor systems with low power consumption and enough resources to act as edge devices, media servers, or lightweight virtualization nodes.
mini pc.use_case: Using a Mini PC as a low-power Plex server for home streaming.

nuc.eli5: A super tiny computer made by Intel that still packs a punch.
nuc.boss: Intel's NUC (Next Unit of Computing) is a compact PC often used in home labs, kiosks, and media centers.
nuc.sysadmin: Intel NUCs are ultra-small-form-factor PCs that offer configurable CPU/RAM/storage options, ideal for silent, energy-efficient computing in confined spaces.
nuc.use_case: Deploying Home Assistant OS on an Intel NUC to control an entire smart home setup.

diy nas.eli5: Building your own digital closet to store and share files with your household.
diy nas.boss: A DIY NAS is a custom-built storage server for backups, media, or file sharing, often using open-source software.
diy nas.sysadmin: User-built network-attached storage using commodity hardware and software like TrueNAS, often for media, backups, or VM storage in home labs.
diy nas.use_case: Someone builds a DIY NAS using TrueNAS SCALE and old PC parts to store family videos and photos.

external drive.eli5: A pocket-sized box that holds your files and plugs into your computer with a cable.
external drive.boss: An external drive is a portable storage device used to back up data or transfer files between systems.
external drive.sysadmin: USB, Thunderbolt, or eSATA storage media (HDD or SSD) used for backups, data recovery, or temporary off-host storage.
external drive.use_case: Using a 2TB external drive to back up a laptop before upgrading the OS.

raid.eli5: Think of multiple hard drives working together like a teamâ€”some boost speed, others add safety.
raid.boss: RAID is a method of combining multiple drives to improve performance, redundancy, or both.
raid.sysadmin: Redundant Array of Independent Disks (RAID) is a data storage method that distributes or mirrors data across multiple drives using levels like RAID 0, 1, 5, 6, and 10.
raid.use_case: A small business uses RAID 5 in their NAS for performance and fault tolerance.
