raidz.eli5: A special kind of RAID used by ZFS that's like putting guards in your file vault.
raidz.boss: RAIDZ is a ZFS-specific RAID type that combines redundancy and efficient storage for fault tolerance.
raidz.sysadmin: ZFS RAIDZ is a parity-based software RAID similar to RAID 5/6, providing single, double, or triple parity (RAIDZ1, 2, 3) with variable block sizes and integrated checksumming.
raidz.use_case: A homelabber uses RAIDZ2 in TrueNAS to safely store large family media collections.

zfs.eli5: A smart storage system that protects your files from getting messed up.
zfs.boss: ZFS is an advanced file system that offers data integrity, compression, snapshots, and built-in RAID.
zfs.sysadmin: ZFS (Zettabyte File System) is a robust file system and volume manager supporting copy-on-write, self-healing, snapshots, and RAIDZ levels for storage pools.
zfs.use_case: Using ZFS with RAIDZ on a TrueNAS SCALE server to host media and VM backups.

btrfs.eli5: A filing cabinet that tracks everything and can undo mistakes.
btrfs.boss: Btrfs is a modern Linux file system with features like snapshots, compression, and RAID-like functionality.
btrfs.sysadmin: Btrfs (B-tree FS) is a copy-on-write file system for Linux with support for snapshots, checksums, subvolumes, and native RAID capabilities.
btrfs.use_case: Setting up a low-power Debian NAS with Btrfs to enable weekly snapshots and rollback features.

afp.eli5: A special way older Macs used to share files like neighbors passing notes.
afp.boss: AFP is Apple's legacy file-sharing protocol used mainly with older macOS systems.
afp.sysadmin: Apple Filing Protocol (AFP) is a network protocol from Apple for file services on macOS, now deprecated in favor of SMB.
afp.use_case: An old MacBook connects to a Time Capsule over AFP to restore Time Machine backups.

iscsi.eli5: Makes a hard drive in another room look like itâ€™s plugged into your computer.
iscsi.boss: iSCSI lets a computer use storage over a network as if it were a local disk.
iscsi.sysadmin: Internet Small Computer System Interface (iSCSI) transports SCSI commands over IP networks, allowing clients to mount block storage remotely.
iscsi.use_case: A Proxmox VM uses an iSCSI target from a NAS as its primary disk.

jumbo frames.eli5: Like sending fewer but bigger boxes to move more stuff at once.
jumbo frames.boss: Jumbo frames are oversized network packets that improve performance in high-speed LANs by reducing packet overhead.
jumbo frames.sysadmin: Jumbo frames are Ethernet frames with payloads larger than 1500 bytes, typically set to 9000 bytes, reducing CPU usage during data transfers like iSCSI or backups.
jumbo frames.use_case: Enabling jumbo frames on a NAS and Proxmox node to speed up VM storage access over a 10GbE network.

managed switch.eli5: A smart traffic controller for your network that lets you decide who goes where.
managed switch.boss: A managed switch gives admins control over network traffic, VLANs, and monitoring features.
managed switch.sysadmin: Managed switches offer administrative control over LAN features like VLAN tagging, QoS, link aggregation, SNMP, and port mirroring via CLI or web UI.
managed switch.use_case: Using a managed switch to create isolated VLANs for smart home devices and guest Wi-Fi.

unmanaged switch.eli5: A plug-and-play power strip for your internet cablesâ€”no buttons or settings.
unmanaged switch.boss: An unmanaged switch automatically connects devices in a network without any configuration.
unmanaged switch.sysadmin: Unmanaged switches are basic Ethernet switches with no configuration interface, ideal for simple plug-and-play LAN connectivity.
unmanaged switch.use_case: Adding an unmanaged switch in a living room to connect a TV, game console, and media box to Ethernet.

poe switch.eli5: A power strip for network stuff that sends internet *and* electricity through one wire.
poe switch.boss: A PoE switch delivers both data and power over Ethernet cables to devices like cameras and access points.
poe switch.sysadmin: Power over Ethernet (PoE) switches supply DC power alongside data over Cat5e/Cat6 cables, commonly used for IP cameras, VoIP phones, and access points.
poe switch.use_case: Using a PoE switch to power and connect multiple IP cameras without extra power bricks.

mesh wi-fi.eli5: A team of Wi-Fi helpers spread around your house to make sure the signal reaches everywhere.
mesh wi-fi.boss: Mesh Wi-Fi uses multiple access points to create a seamless, strong signal throughout a building or home.
mesh wi-fi.sysadmin: Mesh Wi-Fi systems use multiple interconnected nodes that route wireless traffic dynamically, improving coverage and reliability without relying solely on a central router.
mesh wi-fi.use_case: A family installs a 3-node mesh Wi-Fi system to fix weak signals in their basement and attic.

dhcp reservation.eli5: Saving a parking spot just for your printer so it always gets the same number (IP).
dhcp reservation.boss: DHCP reservation ensures a device always gets the same IP address without setting it manually.
dhcp reservation.sysadmin: DHCP reservation binds a MAC address to a specific IP within the DHCP scope, ensuring consistent network behavior while still managed by the DHCP server.
dhcp reservation.use_case: Assigning a reserved IP to a smart TV so it's easier to manage in the firewall and DNS.

dynamic dns.eli5: Itâ€™s like telling the post office your address changed every time you move, so your mail always finds you.
dynamic dns.boss: Dynamic DNS updates your domain name automatically when your home or office IP address changes.
dynamic dns.sysadmin: Dynamic DNS (DDNS) services monitor WAN IP changes and automatically update DNS records to maintain consistent hostname access for dynamic IPs.
dynamic dns.use_case: A user runs a home server and uses Dynamic DNS to access it remotely even when their ISP changes the public IP.

dmz.eli5: A sandbox area between your home and the internet where risky stuff can play without affecting the rest.
dmz.boss: A DMZ is a special network zone that exposes certain services to the internet while keeping your main network secure.
dmz.sysadmin: A Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) is a subnet that separates externally-facing services from internal LAN resources, often protected by firewalls on both sides.
dmz.use_case: Hosting a public web server in a DMZ so that if it gets compromised, your internal smart home remains protected.

openwrt.eli5: It's like giving your router a brain upgrade to make it smarter and more useful.
openwrt.boss: OpenWRT is a customizable, open-source router firmware that unlocks advanced networking features.
openwrt.sysadmin: OpenWRT is a Linux-based firmware for embedded routers and network devices, offering granular control over routing, firewalling, VPN, QoS, and package management.
openwrt.use_case: A power user flashes OpenWRT on their TP-Link router to set up VLANs and run an ad-blocker.

vyos.eli5: A supercharged router you control with commands, like building your own GPS for internet traffic.
vyos.boss: VyOS is an open-source network operating system used to build advanced firewalls, routers, and VPN servers.
vyos.sysadmin: VyOS is a Debian-based network OS offering CLI-driven configuration for routing, NAT, VPN, VLAN, and firewall rules, often used in virtual environments and bare-metal appliances.
vyos.use_case: A homelabber deploys VyOS as a virtual router in Proxmox to segment traffic across VLANs and handle WireGuard VPN.

proxmox.eli5: It's like a control panel for running lots of pretend computers on one real one.
proxmox.boss: Proxmox is a virtualization platform that allows you to run multiple virtual machines and containers on a single server.
proxmox.sysadmin: Proxmox VE (Virtual Environment) is an open-source virtualization management platform that supports KVM virtual machines, LXC containers, ZFS, clustering, and HA.
proxmox.use_case: A homelabber uses Proxmox to run a mix of VMs and containers for their home automation stack.

vmware esxi.eli5: A powerful program that lets one computer pretend to be many, like hosting a hotel full of digital guests.
vmware esxi.boss: VMware ESXi is enterprise-grade virtualization software that runs multiple operating systems on one physical server.
vmware esxi.sysadmin: VMware ESXi is a bare-metal hypervisor that runs virtual machines directly on hardware, offering robust management via vCenter and deep integration with enterprise ecosystems.
vmware esxi.use_case: A company uses VMware ESXi to host Windows Server VMs in a secure, high-performance data center.

xcp-ng.eli5: Like Proxmox, but built from Citrix techâ€”great for running lots of virtual machines on one box.
xcp-ng.boss: XCP-ng is an open-source virtualization platform based on XenServer, used for running VMs with advanced features.
xcp-ng.sysadmin: XCP-ng is a turnkey virtualization hypervisor built on Xen, supporting features like live migration, backups, and integration with Xen Orchestra.
xcp-ng.use_case: An SMB runs XCP-ng with Xen Orchestra to manage Linux and Windows VMs across several physical hosts.

hyper-v.eli5: Microsoftâ€™s way of letting one computer run many others inside it.
hyper-v.boss: Hyper-V is Microsoftâ€™s virtualization platform for running and managing multiple virtual machines on Windows systems.
hyper-v.sysadmin: Hyper-V is a native hypervisor for Windows, providing Type 1 virtualization, VM checkpoints, virtual networking, and integration with Windows Server tools.
hyper-v.use_case: A technician uses Hyper-V on Windows Server to spin up isolated test environments for internal apps.

virtualbox.eli5: A virtual playroom where you can safely test new operating systems without messing up your computer.
virtualbox.boss: VirtualBox is a free virtualization tool that runs different operating systems on your PC.
virtualbox.sysadmin: Oracle VM VirtualBox is a cross-platform, Type 2 hypervisor that enables local VMs with snapshot, shared folder, and network emulation support.
virtualbox.use_case: A student uses VirtualBox to run Ubuntu on their Windows laptop for learning Linux.

kvm.eli5: Itâ€™s Linuxâ€™s way of letting one computer pretend to be lots of others.
kvm.boss: KVM is a built-in virtualization feature in Linux used to run virtual machines.
kvm.sysadmin: Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) is a Linux kernel module that enables hardware-accelerated virtualization via QEMU and libvirt.
kvm.use_case: A sysadmin uses KVM to host a fleet of isolated Linux VMs on a single Ubuntu server.

qemu.eli5: A tool that helps your computer pretend itâ€™s using different hardware or even a different CPU.
qemu.boss: QEMU is a virtualization tool that emulates hardware and allows running different operating systems or processor types.
qemu.sysadmin: Quick EMUlator (QEMU) is a user-space emulator and virtualizer that provides hardware emulation for x86, ARM, and other architectures, often used with KVM.
qemu.use_case: Running an ARM-based Linux image on an x86 laptop using QEMU for development.

pcie passthrough.eli5: Letting a virtual machine borrow a real part of your computer, like a video card.
pcie passthrough.boss: PCIe passthrough allows a VM to use a real hardware device directly, like a GPU or network card.
pcie passthrough.sysadmin: PCI Express passthrough (via VT-d/IOMMU) maps a physical PCIe device to a guest VM for near-native performance, often used for GPU virtualization.
pcie passthrough.use_case: Assigning a GPU to a Windows VM for gaming or video rendering inside Proxmox.

adguard home.eli5: A personal ad blocker that works for your whole house.
adguard home.boss: AdGuard Home is a network-level ad and tracker blocker you run locally.
adguard home.sysadmin: AdGuard Home is a self-hosted DNS server with filtering, parental controls, and tracking protection, acting as a local resolver for LAN clients.
adguard home.use_case: Installing AdGuard Home on a Raspberry Pi to block ads and trackers across all household devices.

unbound dns.eli5: Like having your own phone book so you donâ€™t have to ask Google every time.
unbound dns.boss: Unbound is a privacy-focused DNS resolver that works without sending requests to third-party servers.
unbound dns.sysadmin: Unbound is a validating, recursive, caching DNS resolver that supports DNSSEC and runs locally or on LAN for improved speed and privacy.
unbound dns.use_case: Pairing Unbound with AdGuard Home to reduce reliance on upstream DNS providers.

wireguard.eli5: A fast and simple internet tunnel that keeps your stuff safe from snoopers.
wireguard.boss: WireGuard is a modern VPN protocol known for being fast, secure, and easy to set up.
wireguard.sysadmin: WireGuard is a cryptographically secure VPN protocol with minimal codebase, fast handshake, and kernel integration, ideal for modern deployments.
wireguard.use_case: Using WireGuard to securely connect a phone and laptop to a home lab from anywhere.

openvpn.eli5: A trusty old internet tunnel that keeps your online stuff private.
openvpn.boss: OpenVPN is a flexible, open-source VPN solution used for secure remote access and site-to-site links.
openvpn.sysadmin: OpenVPN is a robust SSL/TLS-based VPN protocol supporting routing, bridging, and authentication via certificates or credentials.
openvpn.use_case: A company uses OpenVPN to let remote workers securely access internal servers.

tailscale.eli5: A magical tool that makes your devices feel like they're all on the same Wi-Fiâ€”even when theyâ€™re not.
tailscale.boss: Tailscale creates secure, private networks between your devices using WireGuard and easy setup.
tailscale.sysadmin: Tailscale uses WireGuard under the hood to form a mesh VPN with NAT traversal and device authorization via OAuth providers, perfect for zero-config secure networking.
tailscale.use_case: A user installs Tailscale on all devices to access their home lab and NAS remotely without port forwarding.

zerotier.eli5: A secret clubhouse network your devices can joinâ€”no matter where they are in the world.
zerotier.boss: ZeroTier creates virtual networks over the internet that feel like local LANs, ideal for remote access or hybrid infrastructure.
zerotier.sysadmin: ZeroTier is a hybrid SD-WAN and VPN solution offering Layer 2/3 networking over the internet, using encrypted peer-to-peer links and virtual network controllers.
zerotier.use_case: Using ZeroTier to access a home Home Assistant instance from a phone while traveling.

cloudflare tunnel.eli5: A magic door that lets the internet talk to your home computer without opening your front gate.
cloudflare tunnel.boss: Cloudflare Tunnel (formerly Argo Tunnel) lets you securely expose local services to the internet without port forwarding.
cloudflare tunnel.sysadmin: Cloudflare Tunnel creates a secure outbound connection from your server to Cloudflare, enabling access to local apps via public domain names with DDoS protection and authentication.
cloudflare tunnel.use_case: Hosting a personal dashboard behind Cloudflare Tunnel to avoid exposing your IP or opening firewall ports.

cloudflare zero trust.eli5: A bodyguard that checks ID before anyone gets near your private apps.
cloudflare zero trust.boss: Cloudflare Zero Trust protects internal applications using identity verification and access controls without needing a VPN.
cloudflare zero trust.sysadmin: Cloudflare Zero Trust is a security model that enforces user-based access to resources through Cloudflare Access, integrating identity providers and device posture policies.
cloudflare zero trust.use_case: Restricting access to internal dev tools using Google login and device posture checks via Cloudflare Zero Trust.

nginx proxy manager.eli5: Itâ€™s like a receptionist who sends guests to the right room while remembering everyoneâ€™s names.
nginx proxy manager.boss: NGINX Proxy Manager is a web-based interface that simplifies setting up reverse proxies, SSL, and redirects using NGINX.
nginx proxy manager.sysadmin: NGINX Proxy Manager is a Docker-based front end to NGINX, allowing users to configure reverse proxies, manage SSL certs via Let's Encrypt, and redirect traffic without editing config files.
nginx proxy manager.use_case: Using NGINX Proxy Manager to route external traffic to Home Assistant with automatic SSL certificates.

traefik.eli5: A super-smart traffic cop that directs web traffic to the right service automatically.
traefik.boss: Traefik is a modern reverse proxy and load balancer that automatically detects and routes requests to apps.
traefik.sysadmin: Traefik is a dynamic edge router designed for microservices, with built-in support for Docker, Kubernetes, Let's Encrypt, metrics, and automatic configuration discovery.
traefik.use_case: Deploying Traefik with Docker to automatically reverse-proxy containers as they spin up.

caddy.eli5: A helpful butler who gets your website online with security and polish, all by himself.
caddy.boss: Caddy is a modern web server with automatic HTTPS and simple configuration, popular for self-hosted sites.
caddy.sysadmin: Caddy is a Go-based web server and reverse proxy that includes automatic TLS via Let's Encrypt, HTTP/2 support, and human-friendly config files.
caddy.use_case: Hosting a Hugo blog using Caddy with automatic SSL and no manual cert renewal.

wildcard certificate.eli5: One key that unlocks every door on your website, no matter the room name.
wildcard certificate.boss: A wildcard SSL certificate secures all subdomains of a domain with a single certificate.
wildcard certificate.sysadmin: A wildcard certificate uses an asterisk (*) to secure multiple subdomains (e.g., *.example.com) under one certificate, useful for dynamic or multi-service hosting.
wildcard certificate.use_case: Using a wildcard cert to secure dashboard.example.com, vault.example.com, and blog.example.com with one SSL.

self-signed certificate.eli5: Making your own ID card instead of getting one from a trusted agency.
self-signed certificate.boss: A self-signed SSL certificate is created and trusted by the owner, not a public authorityâ€”usually for internal or testing use.
self-signed certificate.sysadmin: Self-signed certificates are X.509 certs signed with their own private key, not issued by a CA, and require manual trust installation on clients.
self-signed certificate.use_case: Using a self-signed cert to encrypt a local-only admin interface for a NAS server.

acme client.eli5: A helper that talks to the certificate service to get your website a lock badge (SSL).
acme client.boss: An ACME client automates getting SSL certificates from services like Letâ€™s Encrypt.
acme client.sysadmin: An ACME client (Automatic Certificate Management Environment) communicates with a certificate authority to validate domain ownership and request/renew SSL certificates automatically.
acme client.use_case: Using an ACME client in Docker to auto-renew certs for multiple subdomains.

certbot.eli5: A robot that fetches and installs the lock icon for your website (SSL).
certbot.boss: Certbot is a tool that helps automate free SSL certificate issuance from Letâ€™s Encrypt.
certbot.sysadmin: Certbot is an EFF-developed ACME client that facilitates domain validation and auto-installation of Let's Encrypt SSL/TLS certificates on web servers.
certbot.use_case: Setting up Certbot to automatically issue HTTPS certs for a personal blog hosted on NGINX.

dropbox api.eli5: Itâ€™s a way for other apps to open your Dropbox and work with your files (if you say itâ€™s okay).
dropbox api.boss: The Dropbox API allows developers to integrate Dropbox storage into their apps for file access and sync.
dropbox api.sysadmin: Dropbox API is a RESTful interface for accessing Dropbox features like file uploads, downloads, sharing, and metadata within third-party apps or automations.
dropbox api.use_case: Using the Dropbox API in n8n to automatically save voiceovers to a shared Dropbox folder.

container.eli5: Like putting an app in a lunchbox so it always works the same, no matter where you take it.
container.boss: A container packages software and its dependencies into one unit so it can run reliably anywhere.
container.sysadmin: Containers are lightweight, portable runtime environments that encapsulate an application, its libraries, and configuration files using OS-level virtualization (e.g., Docker, LXC).
container.use_case: Using containers to run a self-hosted app like Vaultwarden without affecting the host system.

image.eli5: Itâ€™s like a frozen mealâ€”ready to run once heated (started).
image.boss: An image is the blueprint for a containerâ€”it includes everything needed to create and run one.
image.sysadmin: A container image is a snapshot of a file system and app code, used to launch containers. It includes binaries, libraries, and metadata for runtime execution.
image.use_case: Pulling a Docker image for NGINX to quickly spin up a web server in a container.

volume.eli5: A separate folder where containers can safely keep their stuff even if restarted.
volume.boss: A volume is storage outside the container that keeps data safe even when the container is deleted or restarted.
volume.sysadmin: Volumes are persistent storage abstractions managed by container platforms to store data outside the containerâ€™s ephemeral filesystem, ensuring data durability.
volume.use_case: Mapping a volume to store PostgreSQL data when running the containerized database.

bind mount.eli5: Letting a container use a real folder on your computer, like sharing a drawer.
bind mount.boss: A bind mount directly connects a folder on the host to a container for live file access.
bind mount.sysadmin: Bind mounts map a specific directory from the host filesystem into a container at runtime, useful for development or accessing host data directly.
bind mount.use_case: Using a bind mount to live-edit web files inside a container from your local system.

network mode.eli5: Itâ€™s how your container talks to the internetâ€”like choosing a walkie-talkie channel.
network mode.boss: Network mode defines how a container connects to networksâ€”shared, isolated, or bridged.
network mode.sysadmin: Network mode in containers defines the networking stack, such as 'bridge', 'host', or 'none', impacting how the container communicates internally or externally.
network mode.use_case: Setting a container to host network mode to use the same IP as the host system for a local dashboard.

healthcheck.eli5: It's like a daily checkup to see if an app inside a container is still working.
healthcheck.boss: A healthcheck is a test that tells if a containerized app is still healthy and responding.
healthcheck.sysadmin: Healthchecks define custom commands in container runtimes to periodically test container availability, often used for orchestration or auto-restart.
healthcheck.use_case: Configuring a healthcheck in Docker Compose to ensure a web app restarts if it fails.

port mapping.eli5: Like putting a mailbox label so internet traffic knows which container to reach.
port mapping.boss: Port mapping exposes a containerâ€™s internal service to the outside world through a specified port.
port mapping.sysadmin: Port mapping routes traffic from a host port to a containerâ€™s internal port, allowing access to containerized services like web apps.
port mapping.use_case: Mapping port 8080 on your PC to port 80 inside a web container so others can access it.

entrypoint.eli5: Itâ€™s the main command the container runs when it wakes up.
entrypoint.boss: Entrypoint defines what a container does when it startsâ€”itâ€™s the default command.
entrypoint.sysadmin: The entrypoint specifies the executable run inside the container at launch, acting as the primary process for the container lifecycle.
entrypoint.use_case: Defining an entrypoint script in a Dockerfile to initialize and launch an app.

alpine image.eli5: A tiny, super light container image that only has the basics.
alpine image.boss: An Alpine image is a minimal Linux-based container image used for fast, secure deployments.
alpine image.sysadmin: Alpine is a security-focused, ultra-lightweight Linux distro commonly used as a base container image due to its 5MB footprint and musl/libc compatibility.
alpine image.use_case: Using an Alpine image as a base to keep Docker containers lean and fast.

multi-arch image.eli5: A smart container that works on different computersâ€”like PCs or Raspberry Pisâ€”without extra setup.
multi-arch image.boss: Multi-arch images can run on different hardware types, making deployment easier across devices.
multi-arch image.sysadmin: Multi-architecture container images use manifests to support multiple CPU platforms (e.g., x86_64, ARM64), enabling platform-agnostic pulls.
multi-arch image.use_case: Deploying the same container image to both a Raspberry Pi and a cloud server using Docker's multi-arch support.

portainer.eli5: A dashboard that lets you control all your containers with buttons instead of typing commands.
portainer.boss: Portainer is a web interface that simplifies managing Docker containers and servers.
portainer.sysadmin: Portainer is a lightweight management UI for Docker, Kubernetes, and Swarm that enables container lifecycle control, volume/network setup, and stack deployments.
portainer.use_case: Running Portainer to manage a 3-node Docker cluster from one central dashboard.

cockpit.eli5: Like a control panel for your Linux computer with buttons instead of command lines.
cockpit.boss: Cockpit is a web-based GUI that lets you manage Linux systems easily, without needing to use terminal commands.
cockpit.sysadmin: Cockpit is a remote-friendly, browser-accessible interface for managing Linux servers, offering modules for system logs, networking, storage, containers, and system updates.
cockpit.use_case: Using Cockpit to reboot, view logs, and manage users on a headless Fedora server.

webmin.eli5: A website you use to control your Linux server like a remote control.
webmin.boss: Webmin is a web-based interface for managing Linux systemsâ€”like users, updates, and servicesâ€”without needing terminal access.
webmin.sysadmin: Webmin is a Perl-based system administration tool with a modular web UI for Unix-based systems, supporting user management, cron jobs, services, and package updates.
webmin.use_case: Managing Samba shares and configuring cron jobs on a Debian server using Webmin.

ansible.eli5: Itâ€™s like having a robot do your computer chores over the network.
ansible.boss: Ansible automates IT tasks like setting up servers, deploying apps, and managing configurationsâ€”all from one command.
ansible.sysadmin: Ansible is an agentless automation tool using YAML playbooks to orchestrate configuration management, software provisioning, and application deployment via SSH.
ansible.use_case: Running an Ansible playbook to configure firewall rules on all home lab servers.

terraform.eli5: Itâ€™s like building a house with Lego instructionsâ€”but for servers in the cloud.
terraform.boss: Terraform lets you define and build infrastructureâ€”like servers or networksâ€”using code instead of clicking around.
terraform.sysadmin: Terraform is an Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tool using HCL to manage cloud and on-prem resources declaratively across providers like AWS, Azure, and Proxmox.
terraform.use_case: Using Terraform to spin up a complete cloud network with subnets and VMs in under a minute.

packer.eli5: A tool that bakes your software into a nice ready-to-use computer image.
packer.boss: Packer creates machine images automatically, so you can reuse and deploy them anywhere.
packer.sysadmin: Packer is a HashiCorp tool that automates the creation of machine images (AMI, VMDK, ISO, etc.) across platforms using configuration files and shell scripts.
packer.use_case: Using Packer to build a preconfigured Ubuntu image for Proxmox and AWS.

vagrant.eli5: Itâ€™s like a magic suitcase that unpacks the same computer environment every time you open it.
vagrant.boss: Vagrant makes it easy to spin up and destroy development environments quickly and consistently.
vagrant.sysadmin: Vagrant is a tool for building and managing reproducible virtualized dev environments via simple Vagrantfiles, often using VirtualBox or libvirt.
vagrant.use_case: Using Vagrant to test a web server stack on a virtual Ubuntu box without affecting your system.

saltstack.eli5: Itâ€™s like Ansibleâ€™s cousin who prefers talking to servers with an agent already installed.
saltstack.boss: SaltStack is a configuration management tool for automating infrastructure and keeping systems in sync.
saltstack.sysadmin: SaltStack (Salt) is a Python-based automation and configuration system using a master/minion architecture with remote execution, event-driven orchestration, and YAML states.
saltstack.use_case: A sysadmin uses Salt to enforce NTP configuration across 50 Linux machines.

chef.eli5: Chef is like a recipe book that tells your servers how to cook up the right configuration.
chef.boss: Chef automates infrastructure by treating configuration as code, ensuring servers are set up consistently.
chef.sysadmin: Chef is a Ruby-based configuration management platform that applies 'cookbooks' to nodes to enforce state, using a client-server or local mode.
chef.use_case: Using Chef cookbooks to deploy and manage a LAMP stack on cloud VMs.

puppet.eli5: You write the rules and Puppet makes sure your servers always follow them.
puppet.boss: Puppet ensures that servers are configured and stay configured the way you want, using automation.
puppet.sysadmin: Puppet is a declarative configuration management tool using a client-server model, where the Puppet agent applies manifests sent from the master to enforce system state.
puppet.use_case: A company uses Puppet to ensure firewall settings and users are consistent across 100 servers.

ubuntu server.eli5: Itâ€™s the server version of Ubuntu that doesnâ€™t have the flashy windowsâ€”just gets stuff done.
ubuntu server.boss: Ubuntu Server is a popular, free Linux distribution used to run server applications in data centers or home labs.
ubuntu server.sysadmin: Ubuntu Server is a headless variant of the Ubuntu OS, optimized for performance and security in server roles, offering LTS releases and cloud integrations.
ubuntu server.use_case: Installing Ubuntu Server on a NUC to host a local Git server and Docker stack.

debian.eli5: A stable and reliable version of Linux thatâ€™s like the grandparent of many other versions.
debian.boss: Debian is a popular open-source Linux operating system known for stability and long-term support.
debian.sysadmin: Debian is a widely-used Linux distro based on the Linux kernel with .deb package management, known for its conservative update cycle and use as a base for Ubuntu and others.
debian.use_case: Running Debian on a VPS to host a custom web application with low resource usage.

almalinux.eli5: A free version of the same Linux used in many companies, made to replace CentOS.
almalinux.boss: AlmaLinux is an open-source, enterprise-grade Linux distro built to be compatible with Red Hat Enterprise Linux.
almalinux.sysadmin: AlmaLinux is a binary-compatible rebuild of RHEL maintained by the community, often used in cloud and enterprise environments post-CentOS.
almalinux.use_case: Using AlmaLinux in a production LAMP stack for a self-hosted enterprise CRM.

rocky linux.eli5: A free, stable Linux made to keep things running smoothlyâ€”like CentOS used to do.
rocky linux.boss: Rocky Linux is an open-source enterprise OS designed as a stable replacement for CentOS after its shift to a rolling-release model.
rocky linux.sysadmin: Rocky Linux is a RHEL-compatible Linux distribution maintained by the Rocky Enterprise Software Foundation, offering binary-level compatibility and long-term support for server deployments.
rocky linux.use_case: A business deploys Rocky Linux across its web servers to maintain compatibility with existing CentOS tools.

centos stream.eli5: The newer, faster-moving cousin of CentOS that shows what Red Hat is cooking next.
centos stream.boss: CentOS Stream is a Linux distro that previews the next version of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, used for early development and testing.
centos stream.sysadmin: CentOS Stream is a continuously delivered Linux distribution that sits between Fedora and RHEL, offering a rolling release ahead of stable RHEL versions.
centos stream.use_case: A developer tests upcoming RHEL changes by deploying apps on CentOS Stream before official release.

truenas scale.eli5: Itâ€™s a smart storage box that can also run apps and containersâ€”like a super-powered filing cabinet.
truenas scale.boss: TrueNAS SCALE is an open-source NAS operating system that supports Docker containers and Kubernetes in addition to traditional storage services.
truenas scale.sysadmin: TrueNAS SCALE is a Debian-based NAS OS with support for ZFS, containerization via Docker and Kubernetes, clustering, and Linux-based services.
truenas scale.use_case: Running Nextcloud and Plex on a TrueNAS SCALE box while also managing large ZFS storage pools.

truenas core.eli5: A digital vault for storing and protecting your files, built for reliability.
truenas core.boss: TrueNAS CORE is a free, BSD-based NAS OS used to manage storage with advanced features like snapshots and replication.
truenas core.sysadmin: TrueNAS CORE is a FreeBSD-based storage OS with a web UI, built-in ZFS support, jail-based plugins, and replication for backup and HA storage.
truenas core.use_case: Using TrueNAS CORE to manage a home backup system with hourly snapshots and SMB shares.

unraid.eli5: Itâ€™s like a Lego table where you can mix apps, files, and backups without everything falling apart.
unraid.boss: Unraid is a flexible NAS and virtualization platform for home and small businesses that combines storage, Docker, and VMs in one OS.
unraid.sysadmin: Unraid is a Linux-based OS that allows mixed-drive NAS setups with parity, Docker container hosting, and KVM virtual machines via a web interface.
unraid.use_case: Hosting Plex, Home Assistant, and backups on a single Unraid server using Docker and disk shares.

openmediavault.eli5: A simple way to turn an old computer into a network file cabinet.
openmediavault.boss: OpenMediaVault is an open-source NAS operating system for managing storage, users, and backups with a web UI.
openmediavault.sysadmin: OpenMediaVault (OMV) is a Debian-based NAS platform with plugin support, SMB/NFS shares, and Docker/Podman integration.
openmediavault.use_case: Using OMV to create a home media and file server with an easy-to-use interface.

freebsd.eli5: Itâ€™s like Linuxâ€™s lesser-known cousin thatâ€™s super stable and runs quietly in the background.
freebsd.boss: FreeBSD is a Unix-like operating system known for its stability, security, and use in firewalls, routers, and NAS devices.
freebsd.sysadmin: FreeBSD is a free Unix-like OS derived from BSD with features like jails, ZFS support, and fine-grained security, often used in networking and embedded environments.
freebsd.use_case: Running FreeBSD as a base OS for TrueNAS CORE on a ZFS-powered home server.

pi-hole.eli5: A blocker box that stops ads and trackers before they reach your devices.
pi-hole.boss: Pi-hole is a network-wide ad and tracker blocker that filters DNS requests for all devices on your network.
pi-hole.sysadmin: Pi-hole is a DNS-level sinkhole that filters queries using blocklists to prevent ad and tracking domains, commonly deployed on Raspberry Pi or Docker.
pi-hole.use_case: Installing Pi-hole on a Raspberry Pi to stop ads across phones, TVs, and smart devices on the home network.

gitops.eli5: Using your version control system (like Git) as the boss of your infrastructure.
gitops.boss: GitOps is a DevOps approach that uses Git as the source of truth for automating infrastructure and deployments.
gitops.sysadmin: GitOps is an operational framework that uses Git repositories to manage and trigger declarative infrastructure changes, often integrated with Kubernetes.
gitops.use_case: Using GitOps to deploy and rollback Kubernetes manifests by simply committing changes to a Git repo.

ssh key.eli5: A digital key that lets you unlock your server without typing your password.
ssh key.boss: An SSH key is a secure way to log into servers without using passwords, often used for automation and security.
ssh key.sysadmin: SSH keys use public/private key pairs for secure, encrypted authentication to remote servers over SSH, eliminating the need for password-based logins.
ssh key.use_case: Setting up SSH key authentication to log into all lab servers without retyping your password.

port knocking.eli5: A secret knock to open a digital door that looks locked to everyone else.
port knocking.boss: Port knocking adds a hidden layer of security by requiring a sequence of connection attempts to open access to services.
port knocking.sysadmin: Port knocking is a firewall access control method that opens a port only after a specific sequence of network requests, enhancing stealth and limiting attack surfaces.
port knocking.use_case: Using port knocking to protect SSH by making it accessible only after a coded port sequence is sent.

fail2ban.eli5: A watchdog that blocks people after too many wrong password tries.
fail2ban.boss: Fail2Ban watches logs and blocks IPs that look suspiciousâ€”like too many login failures.
fail2ban.sysadmin: Fail2Ban scans service logs for authentication failures or suspicious activity, then adds firewall rules to block the source IP temporarily or permanently.
fail2ban.use_case: Running Fail2Ban on a server to ban IPs that repeatedly try incorrect SSH logins.

rclone.eli5: A power tool that helps you move files between cloud drives like Google Drive and Dropbox.
rclone.boss: Rclone is a command-line tool to copy and sync files between cloud providers or local drives.
rclone.sysadmin: Rclone is a Go-based utility that supports syncing, mounting, and encrypting files across cloud storage platforms, SFTP, WebDAV, and local filesystems.
rclone.use_case: Syncing a backup folder from a NAS to Google Drive nightly using Rclone.

rsync.eli5: A super-smart copier that only sends the parts of files that changed.
rsync.boss: Rsync is a fast and efficient tool for syncing files between computers or storage devices.
rsync.sysadmin: Rsync is a differential file synchronization tool that compares and transfers only changed data blocks, optimizing bandwidth and time for backups and sync tasks.
rsync.use_case: Using rsync to mirror a local folder to an external drive every night.

crontab.eli5: A to-do list that your computer runs on a scheduleâ€”even if you forget.
crontab.boss: Crontab is how Linux systems schedule tasks to run automatically at set times.
crontab.sysadmin: Crontab is a table of time-based job schedules for the cron daemon, allowing users to run scripts, backups, or maintenance at recurring intervals.
crontab.use_case: Setting a crontab entry to run a backup script at 2am daily.

cronjob.eli5: A task that your computer remembers to do on its own, like watering your digital plants.
cronjob.boss: A cronjob is an automated task that runs at regular intervals, like backups or updates.
cronjob.sysadmin: Cronjobs are scheduled scripts or commands defined in user or system crontabs, executed by the cron daemon based on time expressions.
cronjob.use_case: Running a cronjob to automatically sync logs from a server every hour.

systemd timer.eli5: A smarter alarm clock that works with Linuxâ€™s new scheduling system.
systemd timer.boss: Systemd timers replace cron for managing scheduled tasks using modern features and better control.
systemd timer.sysadmin: Systemd timers are scheduling units in systemd that trigger service units based on calendar expressions or monotonic timers, offering logging and dependency management.
systemd timer.use_case: Using a systemd timer to restart a containerized service every morning before business hours.

dns-01 challenge.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting a note on your domain name to prove you own itâ€”so you can get a security certificate.
dns-01 challenge.boss: The DNS-01 challenge verifies domain ownership by checking a special DNS record you add temporarily.
dns-01 challenge.sysadmin: DNS-01 is an ACME challenge type where the domain owner creates a TXT DNS record with a validation token, proving control for issuing SSL certificates via tools like Certbot.
dns-01 challenge.use_case: Automating wildcard certificate renewal for your domain using the DNS-01 challenge.

http-01 challenge.eli5: You put a file on your website that says â€˜yes, I own thisâ€™ so a service can give you HTTPS.
http-01 challenge.boss: The HTTP-01 challenge validates your control over a domain by checking for a specific file hosted on your web server.
http-01 challenge.sysadmin: HTTP-01 is an ACME challenge that verifies domain control by requesting a token file at `http://domain/.well-known/acme-challenge`, commonly used for Let's Encrypt.
http-01 challenge.use_case: Using HTTP-01 to automatically issue a Let's Encrypt cert for a website hosted with NGINX.

elastic stack.eli5: A toolkit that lets you search, store, and visualize your computer logs and data like magic.
elastic stack.boss: The Elastic Stack (ELK) collects, stores, and analyzes data in real-timeâ€”great for monitoring systems and troubleshooting.
elastic stack.sysadmin: Elastic Stack (ELK) includes Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana for ingesting, indexing, and visualizing logs and metrics across infrastructure.
elastic stack.use_case: Using the Elastic Stack to view and filter logs from multiple Docker containers and servers.

fluentd.eli5: A helpful log messenger that collects messages from apps and delivers them to the right place.
fluentd.boss: Fluentd collects logs from various sources and forwards them to tools like Elasticsearch or cloud storage.
fluentd.sysadmin: Fluentd is an open-source data collector that unifies logging layers across systems by parsing, buffering, and forwarding data in real-time.
fluentd.use_case: Using Fluentd to forward application logs to Elasticsearch for centralized analysis.

logrotate.eli5: Itâ€™s a cleanup crew for your log filesâ€”making sure they donâ€™t get too big.
logrotate.boss: Logrotate keeps system logs manageable by rotating, compressing, or deleting old files based on rules.
logrotate.sysadmin: Logrotate is a log management utility that automates the rotation, compression, and removal of logs on a schedule to control disk usage and file clutter.
logrotate.use_case: Rotating NGINX logs weekly and keeping only the last four using logrotate.

vm backup.eli5: Saving a snapshot of your pretend computer so you can bring it back later if something breaks.
vm backup.boss: VM backups create copies of virtual machines to restore in case of failure or updates gone wrong.
vm backup.sysadmin: VM backup involves capturing snapshots or full disk images of virtual machines using hypervisor tools or third-party solutions, supporting consistency, scheduling, and restore capabilities.
vm backup.use_case: Backing up all VMs in a Proxmox node to a NAS on a nightly schedule.

deployment.eli5: Putting a finished app out there so peopleâ€”or devicesâ€”can use it.
deployment.boss: Deployment is the process of pushing software or updates to production so it's live and usable.
deployment.sysadmin: Deployment refers to the automated or manual release of application code or infrastructure changes into production environments, often using CI/CD pipelines or scripts.
deployment.use_case: Using GitHub Actions to automatically deploy a web app after pushing code to the main branch.

arch linux.eli5: Itâ€™s a build-it-yourself Linux where you choose every pieceâ€”like adult LEGO.
arch linux.boss: Arch Linux is a minimalist, do-it-yourself Linux distro aimed at advanced users who want full control over their system.
arch linux.sysadmin: Arch Linux is a rolling-release, x86-64 optimized Linux distribution that provides minimal base installs and extensive documentation via the Arch Wiki, appealing to power users.
arch linux.use_case: Installing Arch Linux on a workstation to build a lightweight desktop with only essential packages.

opensuse.eli5: A friendly version of Linux that comes with powerful tools and a green lizard mascot.
opensuse.boss: openSUSE is a stable and community-driven Linux OS used for workstations, servers, and developers.
opensuse.sysadmin: openSUSE is a Linux distribution with tools like YaST for system configuration, offering both stable (Leap) and rolling (Tumbleweed) release models.
opensuse.use_case: Using openSUSE Leap on a workstation for development with built-in YaST configuration tools.

lidarr.eli5: Like a smart music manager that grabs your favorite albums automatically.
lidarr.boss: Lidarr is an automation tool that finds, downloads, and organizes music collections from multiple sources.
lidarr.sysadmin: Lidarr is a self-hosted Usenet and BitTorrent music downloader that integrates with indexers, download clients, and media servers to manage music libraries.
lidarr.use_case: Using Lidarr to monitor new album releases and automatically download FLAC versions to your Plex library.

bazarr.eli5: A subtitle fairy that adds words to your moviesâ€”without asking.
bazarr.boss: Bazarr automatically downloads and manages subtitles for your media collection.
bazarr.sysadmin: Bazarr is a companion tool for Sonarr and Radarr that monitors video libraries and fetches matching subtitles from online sources.
bazarr.use_case: Running Bazarr to automatically download subtitles for foreign films in your Plex collection.

qbittorrent.eli5: A program that lets you share and download files from other peopleâ€”like a digital swap meet.
qbittorrent.boss: qBittorrent is a free and open-source BitTorrent client for downloading and uploading files via peer-to-peer networks.
qbittorrent.sysadmin: qBittorrent is a Qt-based BitTorrent client with features like RSS support, IP filtering, and a built-in search engine, often used in automated media pipelines.
qbittorrent.use_case: Using qBittorrent with Sonarr to automatically download and manage TV shows.

deluge.eli5: Another way to download big files by connecting to lots of people who already have them.
deluge.boss: Deluge is a lightweight BitTorrent client used for peer-to-peer file sharing and automation.
deluge.sysadmin: Deluge is a modular, Python-based BitTorrent client supporting headless daemon mode, plugins, and integration with automation tools like Radarr or Sonarr.
deluge.use_case: Deploying Deluge in a Docker container with a web UI to manage torrents remotely.

rtorrent.eli5: A nerdy version of a torrent program you run from the command line.
rtorrent.boss: rTorrent is a command-line BitTorrent client designed for speed and remote automation.
rtorrent.sysadmin: rTorrent is a terminal-based BitTorrent client written in C++, often paired with ruTorrent for a web UI and integrated into seedbox or media workflows.
rtorrent.use_case: Running rTorrent on a headless server with ruTorrent to manage torrent downloads over the web.

nzbget.eli5: A robot that grabs TV shows and movies from special forums (Usenet).
nzbget.boss: NZBGet is a fast, efficient downloader for Usenet binary content using NZB files.
nzbget.sysadmin: NZBGet is a lightweight Usenet downloader optimized for low-resource systems, supporting SSL, categories, post-processing, and automation.
nzbget.use_case: Using NZBGet with Lidarr to automatically download music files from Usenet.

sabnzbd.eli5: A friendly downloader for grabbing stuff from Usenet and putting it in the right folder.
sabnzbd.boss: SABnzbd is an open-source Usenet downloader that handles NZB files and automates the download process.
sabnzbd.sysadmin: SABnzbd is a Python-based Usenet client with a browser interface and post-processing support, integrating with automation tools like Radarr and Sonarr.
sabnzbd.use_case: Running SABnzbd in Docker to handle automatic downloads from Usenet with Sonarr.

jackett.eli5: A middleman that helps your apps search lots of torrent sites without knowing how they work.
jackett.boss: Jackett acts as a universal indexer proxy, letting your media automation tools search dozens of torrent sites.
jackett.sysadmin: Jackett translates queries from tools like Sonarr and Radarr into tracker-specific API calls, enabling torrent indexer access from a single endpoint.
jackett.use_case: Connecting Jackett to Sonarr to access private torrent trackers not natively supported.

ombi.eli5: A friendly request board where your family can ask for new movies and shows.
ombi.boss: Ombi provides a user-friendly interface for requesting content in your media library, syncing with Plex, Radarr, and Sonarr.
ombi.sysadmin: Ombi is a self-hosted request management system that integrates with Plex and media automation apps to handle and track content requests from users.
ombi.use_case: Running Ombi so housemates can request movies that Radarr will automatically download.

tautulli.eli5: It shows whoâ€™s been watching what on your media serverâ€”and when.
tautulli.boss: Tautulli tracks usage statistics, play history, and activity from Plex Media Server.
tautulli.sysadmin: Tautulli is a monitoring tool for Plex that provides analytics, notifications, and history logs of media playback and user activity.
tautulli.use_case: Using Tautulli to see how often each user watches your Plex library and get alerts when streams are started.

prowlarr.eli5: Itâ€™s like Jackettâ€™s cooler cousin who knows how to talk to both torrent and Usenet sites.
prowlarr.boss: Prowlarr is a unified indexer manager for media automation tools like Sonarr and Radarr.
prowlarr.sysadmin: Prowlarr is an indexer management app that integrates with popular media automation tools, supporting torrent and Usenet indexers with built-in API compatibility.
prowlarr.use_case: Replacing Jackett with Prowlarr to manage both torrent and Usenet indexers from one dashboard.

influxdb.eli5: A special notebook that writes down changes over time, like temperatures or CPU usage.
influxdb.boss: InfluxDB is a time-series database used to store and analyze metrics like system load, temperatures, or network traffic.
influxdb.sysadmin: InfluxDB is a purpose-built database optimized for handling timestamped data, supporting high-ingest workloads, retention policies, and Flux or InfluxQL queries.
influxdb.use_case: Using InfluxDB to store server resource metrics collected by Telegraf and visualize them in Grafana.

telegraf.eli5: A sensor collector that gathers info from your devices and sends it to a database.
telegraf.boss: Telegraf collects system and service metrics and ships them to time-series databases like InfluxDB.
telegraf.sysadmin: Telegraf is a plugin-driven metrics collector written in Go that supports input/output for InfluxDB, Prometheus, and other databases via agents or service integrations.
telegraf.use_case: Installing Telegraf on all Docker hosts to push CPU and disk metrics into InfluxDB.

netdata.eli5: A live dashboard that shows your computerâ€™s heartbeat in colorful charts.
netdata.boss: Netdata monitors system performance in real time with beautiful graphs and alerts.
netdata.sysadmin: Netdata is a real-time performance monitoring tool with zero-configuration dashboards for servers, containers, applications, and network interfaces.
netdata.use_case: Running Netdata to visualize CPU, RAM, and disk usage on a home server with zero setup.

glances.eli5: It gives you a quick glance at everything your computer is doingâ€”all in one place.
glances.boss: Glances is a system monitoring tool that summarizes CPU, memory, disk, and network usage in a terminal or web dashboard.
glances.sysadmin: Glances is a Python-based monitoring CLI that aggregates metrics using psutil, with optional web interface and export to time-series databases.
glances.use_case: Using Glances in a terminal to check system health while running Ansible playbooks.

node exporter.eli5: A helper that gathers Linux system stats so Prometheus can read them.
node exporter.boss: Node Exporter collects hardware and OS metrics for monitoring with Prometheus.
node exporter.sysadmin: Node Exporter is a Prometheus metrics exporter that exposes Linux system stats (CPU, RAM, disk, etc.) via HTTP endpoints for scraping.
node exporter.use_case: Installing Node Exporter on all servers to track system performance with Prometheus and Grafana.

snmp exporter.eli5: It speaks SNMP and tells Prometheus what all your network gadgets are doing.
snmp exporter.boss: SNMP Exporter translates SNMP data from network devices into metrics that Prometheus can understand.
snmp exporter.sysadmin: SNMP Exporter polls SNMP-enabled devices (e.g., switches, firewalls) and exposes the collected data as Prometheus metrics via scrape endpoints.
snmp exporter.use_case: Using SNMP Exporter to collect traffic and uptime data from managed switches into Grafana dashboards.

uptime kuma.eli5: A watchdog that checks if your websites or services are still alive and barking.
uptime kuma.boss: Uptime Kuma is a self-hosted monitoring tool that tracks service and website uptime with notifications.
uptime kuma.sysadmin: Uptime Kuma is a lightweight uptime monitoring dashboard with HTTP, TCP, and DNS checks, plus push alert support for Discord, Telegram, and email.
uptime kuma.use_case: Running Uptime Kuma to track public services and get alerts when containers crash or restart.

librenms.eli5: Itâ€™s like a traffic camera for your entire networkâ€”watching and alerting when things go wrong.
librenms.boss: LibreNMS is a network monitoring system that gives visibility into devices and alerts you to issues.
librenms.sysadmin: LibreNMS is a PHP-based, SNMP-compatible network monitoring system with auto-discovery, alerting, and API support for routers, switches, servers, and wireless devices.
librenms.use_case: Using LibreNMS to monitor network traffic and device health across your home lab and receive alerts on port failures.

smokeping.eli5: A tool that checks how fast your internet respondsâ€”and if it hiccups along the way.
smokeping.boss: SmokePing measures and graphs your network latency and packet loss over time.
smokeping.sysadmin: SmokePing is a latency monitoring tool that uses ICMP (ping) to track response time, jitter, and packet loss, rendering visual graphs for network diagnostics.
smokeping.use_case: Running SmokePing to track latency spikes and packet loss during work hours across your home network.

zigbee2mqtt.eli5: It helps smart devices that speak Zigbee talk to your smart home brain over Wi-Fi.
zigbee2mqtt.boss: Zigbee2MQTT lets you connect Zigbee devices to your smart home via MQTT, without relying on proprietary hubs.
zigbee2mqtt.sysadmin: Zigbee2MQTT is a bridge that allows Zigbee-based smart devices to communicate through MQTT brokers by interfacing with a Zigbee coordinator dongle.
zigbee2mqtt.use_case: Using Zigbee2MQTT with a USB coordinator to control smart plugs and sensors via Home Assistant.

z-wave js.eli5: Itâ€™s the interpreter that helps Z-Wave smart devices understand what your smart home is asking.
z-wave js.boss: Z-Wave JS is a modern JavaScript-based library and integration layer for controlling Z-Wave smart home devices.
z-wave js.sysadmin: Z-Wave JS is a Node.js-based driver and API layer enabling smart home platforms like Home Assistant to communicate with Z-Wave devices using serial controllers.
z-wave js.use_case: Using Z-Wave JS with a USB stick to pair locks, motion sensors, and dimmers inside Home Assistant.

mosquitto.eli5: A post office that delivers tiny messages between your smart devices.
mosquitto.boss: Mosquitto is a lightweight MQTT broker used to pass messages between smart devices and services.
mosquitto.sysadmin: Eclipse Mosquitto is an open-source MQTT broker that supports the publish/subscribe model, commonly used in IoT and home automation networks.
mosquitto.use_case: Running Mosquitto in Docker to relay sensor data between Zigbee2MQTT and Home Assistant.

mariadb.eli5: A big digital notebook that apps use to store their stuffâ€”like users, posts, or settings.
mariadb.boss: MariaDB is an open-source database server often used to store websites, apps, or service data.
mariadb.sysadmin: MariaDB is a MySQL-compatible relational database management system (RDBMS) offering improved performance, features, and open governance after MySQL's acquisition by Oracle.

mysql.eli5: One of the most popular tools for storing and organizing data like a big spreadsheet for apps.
mysql.boss: MySQL is a widely-used open-source database server powering websites, apps, and services.
mysql.sysadmin: MySQL is a relational database management system (RDBMS) supporting SQL queries, ACID compliance, and integration with PHP and other web technologies.
mysql.use_case: Running MySQL for a self-hosted CRM system that requires structured, relational data storage.

gitea.eli5: Itâ€™s like your own mini GitHub that you can run at home.
gitea.boss: Gitea is a lightweight, self-hosted Git service for managing code repositories with a web interface.
gitea.sysadmin: Gitea is a painless, Go-based Git server with features like issue tracking, pull requests, and CI hooks, designed for lightweight self-hosted deployments.
gitea.use_case: Hosting a private Git repository for a development project on a Raspberry Pi using Gitea.

gogs.eli5: Itâ€™s the smaller sibling of Giteaâ€”also a home for your code.
gogs.boss: Gogs is a self-hosted Git service built for efficiency and minimal resource use.
gogs.sysadmin: Gogs (Go Git Service) is a compact, open-source Git platform written in Go, offering a web interface, user management, and Git hosting via HTTP/SSH.
gogs.use_case: Deploying Gogs on a VPS to manage source control without relying on public Git services.

kill-a-watt.eli5: A gadget you plug in to see how much electricity your devices are eating.
kill-a-watt.boss: Kill-A-Watt is a device that measures electrical usage, helping track power consumption and cost.
kill-a-watt.sysadmin: Kill-A-Watt is a plug-in energy monitor that displays voltage, current, wattage, and kWh usage to evaluate device power consumption and efficiency.

rack fan controller.eli5: Itâ€™s the thermostat for your server rackâ€”it keeps things cool automatically.
rack fan controller.boss: A rack fan controller monitors rack temperature and controls fan speeds to keep hardware cool and safe.
rack fan controller.sysadmin: Rack fan controllers regulate airflow by adjusting fan speeds based on temperature sensors, often used in server enclosures to maintain optimal thermal conditions.
rack fan controller.use_case: Installing a rack fan controller to keep network gear from overheating in a closed cabinet.

noise level monitor.eli5: Itâ€™s like a microphone that tells you how loud your room isâ€”great for keeping the peace.
noise level monitor.boss: A noise level monitor measures sound levels in an area, often for comfort, compliance, or automation.
noise level monitor.sysadmin: Noise level monitors use decibel sensors to track ambient sound, often integrated with smart home systems for triggering automations or alerts.
noise level monitor.use_case: Using a noise sensor to dim lights automatically when the room gets too loud after bedtime.

zigbee dongle.eli5: A USB stick that lets your computer talk to Zigbee smart devices.
zigbee dongle.boss: A Zigbee dongle is a USB radio adapter used to connect Zigbee devices to your home automation system.
zigbee dongle.sysadmin: Zigbee dongles act as coordinators for Zigbee networks, interfacing with software like Zigbee2MQTT or ZHA over USB serial connections.

usb hub.eli5: A power strip for USBâ€”so you can plug in more devices at once.
usb hub.boss: A USB hub expands the number of USB ports available on your computer or server.
usb hub.sysadmin: USB hubs allow multiple devices to connect via one USB port, often with power delivery and compatibility for devices like Zigbee dongles or flash drives.

serial console.eli5: Itâ€™s a special plug that lets you talk directly to a computer, even if it wonâ€™t turn on properly.
serial console.boss: A serial console allows direct access to a deviceâ€™s operating system via a physical or emulated serial port.
serial console.sysadmin: Serial consoles are command-line interfaces accessed via RS-232 or USB for managing servers, routers, and appliances during boot or when network access fails.
serial console.use_case: Connecting to a network switch via serial console to reconfigure IP settings after a network failure.

console cable.eli5: A special wire that lets you talk to a device thatâ€™s not on the networkâ€”like direct messaging a router.
console cable.boss: Console cables connect your computer to network hardware for direct configuration or recovery.
console cable.sysadmin: Console cables (like RJ45-to-USB or serial-to-USB) provide terminal access to routers, switches, and firewalls via serial console ports for initial setup or troubleshooting.

out-of-band management.eli5: A secret backdoor to your serversâ€”so you can fix them even if they crash.
out-of-band management.boss: Out-of-band management lets you control hardware remotely even when the OS is down.
out-of-band management.sysadmin: Out-of-band management uses dedicated interfaces (e.g., IPMI, iDRAC, ILO) to access servers below the OS level for power control, BIOS access, and diagnostics.

ipmi.eli5: Itâ€™s like a remote control for your serverâ€”even when itâ€™s powered off.
ipmi.boss: IPMI is a protocol that lets you manage and monitor servers remotely at the hardware level.
ipmi.sysadmin: The Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) provides hardware-level control for servers via a baseboard management controller (BMC), including remote boot, logs, and sensors.
ipmi.use_case: Accessing IPMI to mount an ISO and reinstall the OS on a headless server.

idrac.eli5: Itâ€™s Dellâ€™s magic window into a server, even if the server itself is broken.
idrac.boss: iDRAC is Dellâ€™s remote management system that gives full control of its servers from anywhere.
idrac.sysadmin: Integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) enables full out-of-band management, including virtual media, power cycling, sensor monitoring, and BIOS access.
idrac.use_case: Using iDRAC to restart a crashed Dell server and boot from a recovery ISO remotely.

ilo.eli5: Itâ€™s HPâ€™s version of a remote control for their servers.
ilo.boss: ILO (Integrated Lights-Out) is HPâ€™s server management interface for out-of-band control and diagnostics.
ilo.sysadmin: HPEâ€™s Integrated Lights-Out (iLO) provides remote server management with access to power, virtual media, hardware logs, and BIOS settings, similar to IPMI.

cloud sync.eli5: Itâ€™s like a two-way backpack that keeps your files in sync between your home and the cloud.
cloud sync.boss: Cloud sync lets you back up or mirror local files to cloud storage providers automatically.
cloud sync.sysadmin: Cloud sync tools synchronize files between local storage and cloud platforms (e.g., S3, Wasabi), supporting scheduling, versioning, and encryption.
cloud sync.use_case: Syncing nightly backups from a TrueNAS system to Backblaze B2 using Cloud Sync tasks.

backblaze b2.eli5: A super-cheap cloud locker for all your important files.
backblaze b2.boss: Backblaze B2 is an affordable cloud storage solution used for backups and data archiving.

wasabi.eli5: A hot cloud vault that stores files affordably without surprise bills.

wasabi.sysadmin: Wasabi is an S3-compatible cloud object storage provider with predictable pricing, commonly used for offsite backups and archival.
wasabi.use_case: Using Wasabi to store 30-day rolling backups from a home NAS with no extra download costs.

amazon s3.eli5: A giant digital warehouse where you can store anythingâ€”from photos to databases.
amazon s3.boss: Amazon S3 is Amazonâ€™s cloud storage service for storing files, backups, and large-scale data.
amazon s3.sysadmin: Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) is a scalable object storage platform with fine-grained access controls, versioning, lifecycle rules, and widespread tool support.
amazon s3.use_case: Using Amazon S3 as the backend storage for a static website and automated database backups.

google drive api.eli5: Itâ€™s how apps can talk to your Google Drive to upload, download, or organize files.
google drive api.boss: The Google Drive API lets developers programmatically access and manage files in a userâ€™s Google Drive.
google drive api.sysadmin: Google Drive API is a RESTful interface enabling read/write access to Drive files, folder creation, permissions, and automation within custom applications or integrations.

cidr.eli5: Itâ€™s how computers group and count IP addresses efficiently, like making neat address labels.
cidr.boss: CIDR is a way of organizing IP addresses into blocks using slash notation for easier routing.
cidr.sysadmin: Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) uses a suffix (e.g., /24) to represent IP ranges, replacing classful networking and enabling subnetting and route aggregation.

postgresql.eli5: A smart, reliable digital notebook that never loses your stuff and understands complex questions.
postgresql.boss: PostgreSQL is a powerful, open-source relational database used by many enterprise apps for reliable data storage.
postgresql.sysadmin: PostgreSQL is a feature-rich, ACID-compliant RDBMS with support for advanced queries, JSON, stored procedures, full-text search, and extensions like PostGIS and TimescaleDB.

sqlite.eli5: A tiny, simple database that lives in one fileâ€”no server needed.
sqlite.boss: SQLite is a lightweight, file-based database ideal for mobile apps, small tools, and local storage.
sqlite.sysadmin: SQLite is a self-contained RDBMS that stores data in a single disk file, supports SQL queries, and requires no configuration or server process.

mongodb.eli5: Instead of storing data in rows and tables, it uses flexible blocksâ€”like digital LEGO.
mongodb.boss: MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in JSON-like documents, great for fast and flexible applications.
mongodb.sysadmin: MongoDB is a document-oriented NoSQL database that stores BSON objects, supports replication and sharding, and is ideal for unstructured or dynamic schema data.

redis.eli5: Itâ€™s like a super-fast sticky note board for computers that need to remember things quickly.
redis.boss: Redis is a blazing-fast, in-memory database often used for caching, messaging, or real-time apps.
redis.sysadmin: Redis is an in-memory key-value store that supports strings, hashes, lists, and pub/sub messaging, widely used for caching and ephemeral data storage.

timescaledb.eli5: A smart calendar notebook built on PostgreSQL, perfect for tracking things that change over time.
timescaledb.boss: TimescaleDB adds time-series capabilities to PostgreSQL, making it ideal for storing metrics, logs, or sensor data.
timescaledb.sysadmin: TimescaleDB is a PostgreSQL extension optimized for time-series data, offering compression, retention policies, and fast queries over large volumes of timestamped data.
timescaledb.use_case: Storing smart sensor data from Home Assistant in TimescaleDB for easy analysis and visualization with Grafana.

hostname.eli5: Itâ€™s like your computerâ€™s name tag so other devices can say hi.
hostname.boss: A hostname is the name assigned to a device on a network to identify it.
hostname.sysadmin: The hostname is a human-readable label assigned to a device, used in DNS resolution and local networking to identify and differentiate systems.
hostname.use_case: Setting a hostname like 'media-server' so you can access your NAS by name instead of IP.

static route.eli5: A map that tells your network exactly how to get somewhereâ€”no guessing allowed.
static route.boss: A static route is a manually set path for network traffic to follow between devices or subnets.
static route.sysadmin: Static routes define fixed paths in a router or hostâ€™s routing table for directing traffic to specific networks without relying on dynamic routing protocols.
static route.use_case: Adding a static route so your smart home VLAN can reach a service hosted on another subnet.

split dns.eli5: Itâ€™s like having two address booksâ€”one for inside your house and one for the outside world.
split dns.boss: Split DNS lets internal users see private IPs while external users see public ones for the same domain.
split dns.sysadmin: Split DNS uses different DNS records for the same domain depending on where the query comes from (internal vs external), often used for self-hosted apps.

local domain.eli5: Your own little internet where you make up the rules and names.
local domain.boss: A local domain is a custom naming system for internal devices not meant to be accessible from the internet.
local domain.sysadmin: Local domains are private DNS zones (e.g., `.home`, `.lan`) managed internally for name resolution in a LAN without relying on public DNS.
local domain.use_case: Using a local domain like `nas.home` so you can access devices in your network by name.

. local tld.eli5: A pretend website ending in `.local` that only works in your house.
. local tld.boss: .local is a special domain suffix used for internal devices that donâ€™t need to be on the internet.
. local tld.sysadmin: .local is a pseudoâ€“top-level domain used by mDNS and system resolvers (like Avahi or Bonjour) to resolve hostnames within a local network automatically.
. local tld.use_case: Accessing `printer.local` without setting up DNS by relying on mDNS.

mdns.eli5: It helps devices in your house find each other by nameâ€”like magic.
mdns.boss: Multicast DNS (mDNS) lets local devices find each other by hostname without a DNS server.
mdns.sysadmin: mDNS (Multicast DNS) resolves `.local` hostnames on local networks by broadcasting queries to all nearby devices, allowing zero-config service discovery.
mdns.use_case: Using mDNS to reach your Raspberry Pi at `raspberrypi.local` without DNS setup.

bonjour.eli5: Appleâ€™s magic trick that lets your devices find each other without setup.
bonjour.boss: Bonjour is Appleâ€™s implementation of zero-config networkingâ€”it helps devices discover each other automatically on local networks.
bonjour.sysadmin: Bonjour is Appleâ€™s service discovery protocol built on mDNS, enabling automatic detection of printers, computers, and services within a local subnet.
bonjour.use_case: Using Bonjour to automatically detect AirPlay speakers and printers on your home network.

vaultwarden.eli5: A password vault you host yourself so no one else holds the keys.
vaultwarden.boss: Vaultwarden is a self-hosted Bitwarden-compatible password manager that stores encrypted credentials securely.
vaultwarden.sysadmin: Vaultwarden is a lightweight Rust-based Bitwarden API server that supports self-hosted password storage with browser and mobile app sync.

bitwarden.eli5: A digital vault that remembers all your passwords so you donâ€™t have to.
bitwarden.boss: Bitwarden is a cloud-based password manager that keeps your logins safe and synced across devices.
bitwarden.sysadmin: Bitwarden is an open-source password manager supporting encrypted vaults, browser extensions, TOTP, and enterprise-level access control, with cloud and self-hosted options.
bitwarden.use_case: Using Bitwarden to manage login credentials across multiple browsers and mobile devices with autofill.

nextcloud.eli5: A personal cloud that lives in your house, not someone elseâ€™s.
nextcloud.boss: Nextcloud is a self-hosted file sharing and collaboration platform that gives you Dropbox-like features without third-party storage.
nextcloud.sysadmin: Nextcloud is a PHP-based self-hosted cloud suite offering file sync, calendar, contacts, office collaboration, and app integrations with strict data privacy controls.

syncthing.eli5: It keeps your files in sync between your devices without using the cloud.
syncthing.boss: Syncthing is a peer-to-peer file synchronization tool for secure, private data sharing between your own devices.
syncthing.sysadmin: Syncthing is an open-source decentralized sync tool that uses TLS-encrypted peer-to-peer connections for continuous file replication without third-party servers.

seafile.eli5: A high-speed file-sharing box you run yourself.
seafile.boss: Seafile is a self-hosted cloud storage platform designed for fast file syncing and sharing.
seafile.sysadmin: Seafile is a high-performance file hosting platform with deduplication, encryption, and built-in file versioning, supporting Linux and Docker deployment.
seafile.use_case: Using Seafile in a small office to sync shared documents with version control and group folders.

resilio sync.eli5: Itâ€™s like magic mail between your devices that doesnâ€™t go through the internet.
resilio sync.boss: Resilio Sync is a peer-to-peer file syncing tool that uses BitTorrent tech to move data securely and quickly.
resilio sync.sysadmin: Resilio Sync uses peer-to-peer protocols and encryption to synchronize files between devices without cloud storage or central servers, ideal for fast, large transfers.
resilio sync.use_case: Using Resilio Sync to back up video footage from multiple remote locations to a central server.

paperless-ngx.eli5: It turns your paper documents into digital onesâ€”and keeps them organized like a filing cabinet.
paperless-ngx.boss: Paperless-ngx is a document management system that scans, OCRs, and stores your files for easy searching and access.
paperless-ngx.sysadmin: Paperless-ngx is a self-hosted DMS with OCR, tag-based organization, metadata extraction, and a web UI for managing scanned or uploaded PDFs.

photoprism.eli5: A private photo album you host yourself that helps you search by people, places, and things.
photoprism.boss: PhotoPrism is a self-hosted photo management app that automatically organizes, tags, and indexes your pictures.
photoprism.sysadmin: PhotoPrism is a privacy-first AI-powered photo library with face recognition, geotagging, duplicate detection, and album creation from local folders or cloud sync.
photoprism.use_case: Using PhotoPrism on a home server to auto-tag, organize, and browse family vacation photos.

immich.eli5: Itâ€™s like your own personal Google Photosâ€”but without the Google part.
immich.boss: Immich is a self-hosted photo and video backup platform for mobile devices with instant upload and organization.
immich.sysadmin: Immich is a TypeScript-based mobile photo backup app that syncs to a self-hosted server, supporting albums, face detection, live photos, and multi-user management.

media server.eli5: Itâ€™s like a jukebox and movie library for your home that streams to your devices.
media server.boss: A media server stores and streams movies, music, and photos to devices like smart TVs or phones.
media server.sysadmin: Media servers host and transcode audio/video content for DLNA, web, and app-based access using platforms like Plex, Jellyfin, or Emby.
media server.use_case: Setting up a media server to stream 4K movies from a NAS to all TVs in the house.

self-hosted email.eli5: Running your own mailbox server so no big company reads your mail.
self-hosted email.boss: Self-hosted email lets you manage email accounts and servers under your own domain instead of using third-party services.
self-hosted email.sysadmin: Self-hosted email setups include SMTP, IMAP, spam filtering, DKIM/DMARC, and webmail interfaces, using tools like Postfix, Dovecot, and Mailcow.

mailcow.eli5: A prebuilt email farm you can host yourself that takes care of mailboxes, spam, and webmail.
mailcow.boss: Mailcow is a full-featured mail server suite with a modern UI, spam protection, and self-hosting capabilities.

mailu.eli5: A smaller, leaner alternative to Mailcow that helps you host your own email server.
mailu.boss: Mailu is a self-hosted email server stack focused on simplicity and Docker-based deployment.
mailu.sysadmin: Mailu is a lightweight mail server suite built on Postfix, Dovecot, and Rspamd, offering webmail, admin UI, and basic DKIM/DMARC setup via Docker.

postfix.eli5: Itâ€™s the mailman that takes your outgoing messages and delivers them.
postfix.boss: Postfix is a mail transfer agent that sends and routes outgoing email.
postfix.sysadmin: Postfix is a high-performance MTA that handles SMTP message delivery, queueing, and relay control, often used in self-hosted and enterprise mail stacks.

dovecot.eli5: Itâ€™s the post office where your email waits for you to read it.
dovecot.boss: Dovecot is a server that stores and serves incoming emails for retrieval by apps like Outlook or Thunderbird.
dovecot.sysadmin: Dovecot is a lightweight IMAP and POP3 server that securely stores email and supports authentication, SSL, and mailbox indexing for fast access.

roundcube.eli5: Itâ€™s like Gmail, but you host it yourself and it only checks your own mail server.
roundcube.boss: Roundcube is a self-hosted webmail app used to access email accounts through a browser.
roundcube.sysadmin: Roundcube is a PHP-based IMAP webmail client that connects to self-hosted mail servers like Dovecot, offering themes, plugins, and multi-account support.

dkim.eli5: Itâ€™s like signing your email with a secret stamp so people know itâ€™s really from you.
dkim.boss: DKIM adds a digital signature to outgoing emails to prove they came from an authorized server.
dkim.sysadmin: DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) uses cryptographic signatures embedded in email headers to validate message authenticity and protect against spoofing.
dkim.use_case: Configuring DKIM in Mailcow so recipients can verify that emails really came from your domain.

dmarc.eli5: It tells mailboxes what to do if your emails look fakeâ€”like ignore, quarantine, or block them.
dmarc.boss: DMARC builds on SPF and DKIM to protect your domain from email spoofing and phishing attacks.
dmarc.sysadmin: Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) is a DNS policy that instructs how to handle emails that fail DKIM/SPF checks and provides reporting capabilities.
aliases: domain-based message authentication reporting and conformance
dmarc.use_case: Setting up a DMARC policy to block spoofed emails claiming to come from your company domain.

rainloop.eli5: A webmail app you host yourselfâ€”clean, simple, and fast.
rainloop.boss: Rainloop is a lightweight webmail client that connects to IMAP email servers using a sleek browser interface.
rainloop.sysadmin: Rainloop is a PHP-based webmail client with IMAP and SMTP support, offering a minimal UI, multi-account support, and simple configuration for self-hosted email environments.
rainloop.use_case: Deploying Rainloop on a VPS to offer a clean web interface for a self-hosted email server.

reverse dns.eli5: Instead of turning a name into a number, it turns a number into a name.
reverse dns.boss: Reverse DNS looks up the domain name associated with an IP addressâ€”often used for email validation or logging.
reverse dns.sysadmin: Reverse DNS (rDNS) uses PTR records to map IP addresses back to domain names, often required for outbound mail servers to avoid being flagged as spam.
reverse dns.use_case: Setting up reverse DNS for your mail server's IP to prevent outgoing emails from being rejected by spam filters.

spf.eli5: A list that says whoâ€™s allowed to send email for your website.
spf.boss: SPF is a DNS record that lists which mail servers are allowed to send email for your domain.
spf.sysadmin: Sender Policy Framework (SPF) is a DNS TXT record that defines authorized SMTP senders for a domain to prevent spoofing and phishing.
spf.use_case: Adding an SPF record to your domain DNS to authorize Mailcow to send emails for your domain.

apc ups.eli5: A battery backup that keeps your stuff running when the power goes out.
