apc ups.boss: An APC UPS protects your equipment from power outages by keeping devices on temporarily and shutting them down cleanly.
apc ups.sysadmin: An APC UPS is an uninterruptible power supply that provides backup power and surge protection, often managed via USB or SNMP for graceful shutdown automation.
apc ups.use_case: Using an APC UPS to provide 10 minutes of runtime and automatic shutdown for your home lab server during outages.

nut.eli5: A tool that talks to your UPS and tells your server when the power's gone.
nut.boss: NUT is software that monitors and manages UPS devices, handling shutdowns during power outages.
nut.sysadmin: Network UPS Tools (NUT) is a suite that supports monitoring and controlling UPS hardware across networks, enabling automation and logging during power events.
nut.use_case: Installing NUT to trigger safe shutdowns on your Proxmox host when the UPS battery runs low.

battery backup.eli5: A battery that jumps in when the lights go out so your stuff doesnâ€™t crash.
battery backup.boss: Battery backups keep devices running during short power outages and prevent data loss from sudden shutdowns.
battery backup.sysadmin: Battery backups (UPS) provide short-term AC power and surge protection to devices, enabling graceful shutdown and protection during blackouts or voltage drops.
battery backup.use_case: Installing a battery backup to prevent NAS corruption during brownouts and enable scheduled shutdowns.

power distribution unit.eli5: Itâ€™s like a fancy power strip that helps organize and control electricity for your servers.
power distribution unit.boss: A PDU is a device that distributes power to multiple components in a server rack.
power distribution unit.sysadmin: Power Distribution Units (PDUs) deliver AC power to rack-mounted equipment, often with monitoring, metering, and remote reboot capabilities via IP.
power distribution unit.use_case: Using a managed PDU to monitor power usage and remotely reboot a frozen rack server.

flame.eli5: A cool homepage that shows buttons to all your apps in one place.
flame.boss: Flame is a customizable start page or dashboard that links to your self-hosted services with icons and metadata.
flame.sysadmin: Flame is a self-hosted dashboard written in Node.js, allowing custom icons, bookmarks, and service monitoring for home lab and containerized services.
flame.use_case: Using Flame as your browser start page to access all your self-hosted apps from one screen.

rss.eli5: A feed that delivers new blog posts or podcast episodes to you automatically.
rss.boss: RSS lets apps fetch updates from websites so you can follow news, blogs, or podcasts in one place.
rss.sysadmin: RSS (Really Simple Syndication) is an XML-based feed format that allows users and applications to receive updates from websites, including blog posts, torrents, or automation triggers.
rss.use_case: Using RSS to monitor a blog and trigger a Telegram alert using n8n when a new post goes live.

webhooks.eli5: Itâ€™s like your app tapping another on the shoulder to say 'Hey, something just happened!'
webhooks.boss: Webhooks send real-time updates from one service to another based on triggers or events.
webhooks.sysadmin: Webhooks are user-defined HTTP callbacks triggered by events, allowing applications to send real-time data to external endpoints for automation or integration.
webhooks.use_case: Using a webhook to notify Discord when a new issue is opened on a Git repo.

webhook relay.eli5: Itâ€™s the mailman that forwards secret notes from outside the house to apps inside.
webhook relay.boss: Webhook Relay receives external webhooks and securely forwards them to services running on your internal network.
webhook relay.sysadmin: Webhook Relay is a tunneling and relay service that accepts external webhooks (e.g., GitHub, Stripe) and forwards them to non-public or local services behind NAT/firewalls.
webhook relay.use_case: Using Webhook Relay to forward webhook alerts from GitHub to your local n8n instance running behind a firewall.

n8n.eli5: A tool that lets you link apps together like Lego blocks to automate tasks.
n8n.boss: n8n is a self-hosted automation tool that connects different services to create custom workflows without coding.
n8n.sysadmin: n8n (pronounced 'n-eight-n') is a Node.js-based workflow automation tool with a visual editor that supports 350+ integrations, webhook triggers, and conditional logic.
n8n.use_case: Using n8n to trigger a Telegram alert when a webhook from a smart home device detects motion.

telegram bot.eli5: A chatbot inside Telegram that can send messages or do tasks for you.
telegram bot.boss: Telegram bots are automated accounts that can send alerts or interact with users in Telegram chats.
telegram bot.sysadmin: Telegram bots are programmable interfaces to Telegramâ€™s messaging platform, allowing push notifications, command handling, and integrations via Telegram Bot API.
telegram bot.use_case: Using a Telegram bot to send a message when a self-hosted service goes offline.

matrix server.eli5: Your own chat server that can talk to other servers and appsâ€”kind of like hosting your own Slack.
matrix server.boss: Matrix is a decentralized messaging protocol, and a Matrix server lets you host your own chat with bridges to other platforms.
matrix server.sysadmin: A Matrix server (e.g., Synapse) is a federated, open standard messaging platform supporting end-to-end encryption, room federation, and integrations with other services like Slack and Discord.
matrix server.use_case: Hosting a Matrix server to manage internal IT support chat and connect with external Slack rooms.

discord webhook.eli5: A special URL that lets apps send messages directly into a Discord channel.
discord webhook.boss: Discord webhooks allow automated messages to be sent into Discord from other services.
discord webhook.sysadmin: Discord webhooks use unique URLs to send JSON payloads directly to channels, enabling alerts, logs, or notifications from other apps or services.
discord webhook.use_case: Using a Discord webhook to post alerts from Grafana when CPU usage spikes on a server.

gotify.eli5: A personal push notification service you run yourselfâ€”like DIY phone alerts.
gotify.boss: Gotify is a self-hosted push notification server for sending alerts from apps or scripts to your phone or browser.
gotify.sysadmin: Gotify is a lightweight, self-hosted server with REST API and mobile app support for sending real-time notifications securely to authorized users.
gotify.use_case: Using Gotify to receive instant alerts from a shell script that monitors your backup job.

pushover.eli5: An app that lets your other apps whisper in your ear when something important happens.
pushover.boss: Pushover is a service for sending push notifications to your devices from scripts, apps, or services.
pushover.sysadmin: Pushover is a cloud-based notification API that allows secure, real-time message delivery to phones and browsers, commonly used for automation alerts.
pushover.use_case: Using Pushover to get notified when your UPS battery drops below 30%.

ntfy.eli5: A texting system for your scripts that doesnâ€™t need cloud accounts or companies.
ntfy.boss: ntfy is a self-hosted notification tool that lets you send messages from scripts to devices via push or polling.
ntfy.sysadmin: ntfy is a lightweight push notification service with MQTT-like pub/sub topics, allowing CLI tools and apps to send messages over HTTP, with support for mobile and web clients.
ntfy.use_case: Using ntfy to notify your phone when a cronjob finishes a daily backup script.

container registry.eli5: A digital warehouse that stores containers so you can grab and run them anywhere.
container registry.boss: A container registry stores container images so they can be deployed easily across environments.
container registry.sysadmin: A container registry is a storage system for OCI or Docker images, supporting push/pull via HTTP API, used in CI/CD and deployment workflows.
container registry.use_case: Using a private container registry to store internal app images built by GitHub Actions.

oci image.eli5: A standardized container package that works the same everywhereâ€”like a shipping container.
oci image.boss: An OCI image is a container format that ensures compatibility and portability across platforms and tools.
oci image.sysadmin: OCI (Open Container Initiative) images follow a standard spec for container layers, configs, and manifests, ensuring interoperability across container runtimes.
oci image.use_case: Publishing OCI-compliant images to GitHub Container Registry for multi-platform support.

minikube.eli5: A toy-sized version of Kubernetes you can play with on your laptop.
minikube.boss: Minikube is a tool that runs a local Kubernetes cluster for testing and development.
minikube.sysadmin: Minikube provisions a single-node Kubernetes cluster locally using VMs or containers, ideal for development, experimentation, and learning Kubernetes.
minikube.use_case: Using Minikube to test Kubernetes manifests before deploying them to production clusters.

namespace.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting your apps in labeled folders so they donâ€™t get mixed up.
namespace.boss: In Kubernetes, a namespace helps organize resources and prevent naming conflicts between apps.
namespace.sysadmin: Namespaces in Kubernetes allow logical separation of resources within a cluster, enabling isolation, RBAC, and resource quotas.
namespace.use_case: Creating separate namespaces for dev, staging, and prod environments in a Minikube cluster.

pod.eli5: A tiny box that holds one or more containers that always stick together.
pod.boss: A pod is the smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes that can contain one or more tightly linked containers.
pod.sysadmin: A Kubernetes pod groups one or more containers with shared network, storage, and configuration, enabling co-scheduled and tightly coupled app components.
pod.use_case: Deploying a pod that runs both an app and a sidecar logging container in Minikube.

web app manifest.eli5: A little file that helps turn a website into something that feels like an app on your phone.
web app manifest.boss: A Web App Manifest is a JSON file that lets websites be installed like apps with custom icons and splash screens.
web app manifest.sysadmin: The Web App Manifest defines a PWA's metadata including name, icons, theme color, and launch behavior, enabling installability and app-like UX on mobile and desktop.
web app manifest.use_case: Adding a Web App Manifest to make your site installable on Android home screens as a PWA.

restic.eli5: A smart backpack for your files that remembers whatâ€™s already packed so it doesnâ€™t duplicate.
restic.boss: Restic is a secure and efficient backup tool that stores encrypted snapshots of your data, great for cloud or local backups.
restic.sysadmin: Restic is a fast, deduplicating, encrypted, and versioned backup CLI tool written in Go, supporting local and remote backends like SFTP, S3, B2, and more.
restic.use_case: Using Restic to back up Docker volumes to an S3 bucket with encryption and versioning.

duplicati.eli5: A tool that zips and encrypts your stuff before sending it to the cloud.
duplicati.boss: Duplicati is a backup solution that encrypts and compresses your files before sending them to cloud or remote storage.
duplicati.sysadmin: Duplicati is a GUI-based backup tool with support for strong encryption, deduplication, scheduling, and backup to cloud services like OneDrive, S3, and WebDAV.
duplicati.use_case: Scheduling nightly encrypted backups of personal files from a NAS to Google Drive using Duplicati.

urbackup.eli5: A friendly robot that makes regular copies of your computerâ€™s files just in case something breaks.
urbackup.boss: UrBackup is a network-based backup solution that handles both image and file backups for multiple clients.
urbackup.sysadmin: UrBackup is a client/server backup system supporting image-based and file-level backups over LAN, with web UI, scheduling, and incremental features.
urbackup.use_case: Running UrBackup on a home server to back up family laptops automatically over Wi-Fi.

proxmox backup server.eli5: A Proxmox tool that takes photos of your VMs and stores them safely.
proxmox backup server.boss: Proxmox Backup Server is a dedicated tool for backing up virtual machines, containers, and data in Proxmox environments.
proxmox backup server.sysadmin: Proxmox Backup Server is an enterprise-class backup solution for Proxmox VE, supporting deduplication, compression, encryption, and fast incremental VM and container backups.
proxmox backup server.use_case: Setting up Proxmox Backup Server on a separate machine to run scheduled VM backups with deduplication.

timeshift.eli5: A time machine for your Linux computerâ€”go back when things break.
timeshift.boss: Timeshift creates system restore points so you can roll back your Linux OS if something goes wrong.
timeshift.sysadmin: Timeshift is a snapshot tool for Linux systems that backs up and restores system files and configurations, often using rsync or Btrfs.
timeshift.use_case: Using Timeshift on a Linux desktop to create a system snapshot before installing kernel updates.

duckdns.eli5: A free duck-themed service that gives your home a name on the internetâ€”even if your IP changes.
duckdns.boss: DuckDNS is a free dynamic DNS service that maps your changing home IP to a fixed hostname.
duckdns.sysadmin: DuckDNS provides dynamic DNS updates via API or scripts, allowing devices behind residential ISPs to maintain accessible hostnames despite IP changes.
duckdns.use_case: Using DuckDNS to access your self-hosted dashboard remotely even when your IP changes.

no-ip.eli5: It gives your home a name on the web, even if your internet address keeps changing.
no-ip.boss: No-IP is a dynamic DNS provider that keeps your domain updated with your changing IP address.
no-ip.sysadmin: No-IP offers DDNS services that map domain names to dynamic IPs, with clients to update DNS records automatically on IP changes.
no-ip.use_case: Using No-IP with your router to keep a domain updated for remote access to a self-hosted media server.

namecheap dns.eli5: Itâ€™s the place where you tell the internet how to find your Namecheap-bought domain.
namecheap dns.boss: Namecheap DNS lets you manage records like A, CNAME, and MX for domains registered with Namecheap.
namecheap dns.sysadmin: Namecheap DNS is a domain management service for configuring A/AAAA, CNAME, TXT, and other DNS records, including dynamic DNS support.
namecheap dns.use_case: Setting a Namecheap DNS A record to point your domain to a self-hosted web app's public IP.

route53.eli5: Amazonâ€™s phonebook for the internetâ€”it helps people find your stuff online.
route53.boss: Route 53 is AWSâ€™s scalable DNS service that helps direct traffic to websites or services.
route53.sysadmin: Amazon Route 53 is a cloud-based DNS and domain management service supporting routing policies, health checks, alias records, and domain registration.
route53.use_case: Using Route 53 to manage DNS and failover for multiple app instances hosted on AWS.

he.net.eli5: A techy place where you can manage domains and tunnels, often used by pros.
he.net.boss: HE.net (Hurricane Electric) is a popular DNS provider and tunnel broker used by network professionals.
he.net.sysadmin: Hurricane Electric (HE.net) offers DNS hosting with dynamic DNS support, IPv6 tunnel brokering, and authoritative name server configuration tools.
he.net.use_case: Using HE.net to host DNS for a domain and create an IPv6 tunnel for a lab environment.

.env file.eli5: A secret recipe card your app reads to know where stuff is and what to use.
.env file.boss: .env files store configuration like passwords and API keys outside the codebase.
.env file.sysadmin: A `.env` file is a plain text config file used to define environment variables for apps, typically loaded with dotenv libraries for local development or deployment.
.env file.use_case: Storing your database password and API key in a .env file to keep sensitive info out of your code.

dotenv.eli5: A helper tool that reads your secret list and gives it to your app.
dotenv.boss: Dotenv is a tool that loads environment variables from a .env file into your app at runtime.
dotenv.sysadmin: Dotenv is a library used in Node.js, Python, and other environments to parse `.env` files and inject variables into `process.env` at runtime.
dotenv.use_case: Using dotenv in a Node.js app to load secrets and configs from a `.env` file securely.

config file.eli5: A settings sheet that tells your app how to behave.
config file.boss: Config files define how software runs, including ports, paths, and credentials.
config file.sysadmin: Config files store key-value settings or structured parameters (YAML, JSON, INI, etc.) used to control application behavior and environment setup.
config file.use_case: Modifying a YAML config file to change the logging level of a Docker containerized app.

.env.template.eli5: A blank version of your appâ€™s settings sheet, so others know what info to fill in.
.env.template.boss: .env.template is a shared example of environment variables so others can configure the app correctly.
.env.template.sysadmin: .env.template files contain placeholder keys for required environment variables, helping teams clone and configure apps with consistent settings.
.env.template.use_case: Including a `.env.template` file in a GitHub repo to show contributors which keys the app needs.

s.m.a.r.t..eli5: Itâ€™s like a built-in health report for your hard drive that tells you when troubleâ€™s coming.
s.m.a.r.t..boss: S.M.A.R.T. is a system that tracks drive health to predict failures.
s.m.a.r.t..sysadmin: Self-Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Technology (S.M.A.R.T.) is built into hard drives and SSDs to log stats like reallocated sectors, power-on hours, and temperature for failure prediction.
s.m.a.r.t..use_case: Using S.M.A.R.T. tools to check if a hard drive is developing bad sectors before it fails.

smart monitoring.eli5: A regular checkup for your drive to make sure itâ€™s still healthy.
smart monitoring.boss: SMART monitoring tools track hard drive health to prevent data loss.
smart monitoring.sysadmin: SMART monitoring tools (like `smartctl` or TrueNAS alerts) poll disk statistics and raise alerts based on thresholds for predictive maintenance.
smart monitoring.use_case: Enabling SMART monitoring in TrueNAS to get notified when a drive starts reporting errors.

drive health.eli5: How happy and safe your hard drive feels right now.
drive health.boss: Drive health shows the status of your hard disk or SSDâ€”warning signs mean itâ€™s time to back up.
drive health.sysadmin: Drive health reflects aggregate SMART stats like reallocated sectors, error rates, and temperature, helping admins detect early warning signs of failure.
drive health.use_case: Checking drive health on a NAS to decide whether a noisy drive needs replacing.

disk temp.eli5: Itâ€™s how warm your hard drive feelsâ€”and too hot is bad news.
disk temp.boss: Disk temperature is monitored to ensure your drives donâ€™t overheat and fail prematurely.
disk temp.sysadmin: Disk temperature is a SMART metric and physical sensor reading used in NAS and servers to maintain cooling thresholds for drive longevity.
disk temp.use_case: Monitoring disk temp in TrueNAS to trigger fan speed adjustments for cooling.

disk utilization.eli5: It shows how busy your hard drive isâ€”kind of like checking how hard itâ€™s working.
disk utilization.boss: Disk utilization measures how much work your drive is doing over time.
disk utilization.sysadmin: Disk utilization tracks read/write activity and throughput, helping identify I/O bottlenecks or saturation during backups or workloads.
disk utilization.use_case: Using Grafana to visualize disk utilization spikes during nightly backup jobs.

i/o wait.eli5: Itâ€™s the time your computer spends waiting for the hard drive to catch up.
i/o wait.boss: I/O wait shows how much your system slows down while waiting for disk activity to finish.
i/o wait.sysadmin: I/O wait is a CPU state indicating the percentage of time the processor is idle, waiting on disk or I/O subsystems to complete operations.
i/o wait.use_case: Monitoring I/O wait to diagnose slowdowns in a VM caused by overloaded disk I/O.

cpu load.eli5: Itâ€™s how busy your computerâ€™s brain is with work.
cpu load.boss: CPU load shows how many tasks are running and waiting on the processorâ€”higher means more stress.
cpu load.sysadmin: CPU load is the average number of processes either running or waiting to run on the CPU over a set time (1m/5m/15m), used to assess system performance and bottlenecks.
cpu load.use_case: Tracking CPU load in Netdata to catch high usage before containers slow down.

swap usage.eli5: When your computer runs out of RAM, it uses a slower backup space called swap.
swap usage.boss: Swap usage shows how much data is being temporarily stored on disk because RAM is full.
swap usage.sysadmin: Swap usage measures how much virtual memory (on disk) is in use due to exhausted physical RAM, potentially causing performance degradation.
swap usage.use_case: Monitoring swap usage in a containerized server to avoid overcommitting memory and triggering OOM kills.

authentication proxy.eli5: A security guard that checks who you are before letting you into the app.
authentication proxy.boss: An authentication proxy sits in front of apps to verify user identity before allowing access.
authentication proxy.sysadmin: An authentication proxy is a reverse proxy that intercepts HTTP requests and handles identity verification using methods like SSO, OAuth, or LDAP before forwarding them to backend apps.
authentication proxy.use_case: Using an authentication proxy to protect internal dashboards with SSO login.

reverse proxy auth.eli5: A middleman that checks your ID before letting you through the gate.
reverse proxy auth.boss: Reverse proxy authentication verifies users at the proxy level before allowing them to reach the app.
reverse proxy auth.sysadmin: Reverse proxy authentication is a method where the proxy enforces login or identity checks (e.g., with headers or JWTs) before routing requests to backend services.
reverse proxy auth.use_case: Setting up NGINX with reverse proxy auth to require login before accessing a self-hosted app.

oauth proxy.eli5: A bouncer that checks your ID with Google (or others) before letting you in.
oauth proxy.boss: An OAuth proxy handles login with services like Google or GitHub before granting access to protected apps.
oauth proxy.sysadmin: An OAuth proxy is a middleware service that uses OAuth2 to authenticate users, often with identity providers like Google or GitHub, then injects identity headers for upstream apps.
oauth proxy.use_case: Using an OAuth proxy to allow access to Grafana only if users sign in with their GitHub account.

start page.eli5: Like a personalized homepage for all your favorite tools and links.
start page.boss: A start page is a customizable web dashboard where users can organize bookmarks, widgets, and tools.
start page.sysadmin: Start pages like Homer or Dashy are self-hosted dashboards that provide quick access to apps, containers, and services through YAML-based configuration.
start page.use_case: Hosting a local start page that links to services like Plex, Portainer, and Home Assistant.

dashy.eli5: A dashboard builder that lets you make your own launchpad for all your stuff.
dashy.boss: Dashy is a customizable dashboard that helps teams and individuals organize and access tools, apps, and services in one place.
dashy.sysadmin: Dashy is a self-hosted YAML-configured dashboard built with Vue, enabling link tiles, icons, status checks, authentication, and dark mode.
dashy.use_case: Deploying Dashy in Docker to monitor and access all services running in a home lab.

homer.eli5: Like a fridge full of magnets and sticky notes, but on your browser.
homer.boss: Homer is a minimalist self-hosted start page for organizing and accessing apps and links.
homer.sysadmin: Homer is a static, single-page dashboard that reads a YAML config file to display categorized links, services, icons, and optional health checks.
homer.use_case: Using Homer to create a clean dashboard for managing containers, monitoring, and storage tools.

heimdall.eli5: A button-filled launchpad that makes all your stuff just one click away.
heimdall.boss: Heimdall is a home dashboard that makes accessing self-hosted services easy and visually appealing.
heimdall.sysadmin: Heimdall is a self-hosted PHP-based app launcher dashboard with optional integrations for app status, icons, and metadata retrieval.
heimdall.use_case: Deploying Heimdall on a Raspberry Pi to quickly access your NAS, Plex, and smart home apps.

fibre channel.eli5: A super-fast pipe used in big computer rooms to move data around.
fibre channel.boss: Fibre Channel is a high-speed network technology used mainly in data centers for connecting servers to storage.
fibre channel.sysadmin: Fibre Channel is a high-bandwidth, low-latency protocol commonly used in SANs (Storage Area Networks) for block-level data transfer, typically via fiber-optic cables.
fibre channel.use_case: Using Fibre Channel in an enterprise SAN to connect ESXi hosts to shared storage arrays.

scsi.eli5: A really old but fast way for computers to talk to drives and scanners.
scsi.boss: SCSI is a long-standing protocol that allows servers and storage devices to communicate efficiently.
scsi.sysadmin: The Small Computer System Interface (SCSI) is a set of standards for connecting and transferring data between computers and peripheral devices, often used in enterprise disks.
scsi.use_case: Attaching a SCSI virtual disk to a VM in Proxmox for high-performance I/O.

s3-compatible storage.eli5: Itâ€™s like a Dropbox box that speaks Amazonâ€™s languageâ€”even if itâ€™s not Amazon.
s3-compatible storage.boss: S3-compatible storage allows tools and apps to store data using the same interface as Amazon S3, even if hosted elsewhere.
s3-compatible storage.sysadmin: S3-compatible storage refers to object storage systems that support the S3 API, allowing use of tools like rclone, Restic, and MinIO regardless of the provider.
s3-compatible storage.use_case: Backing up Docker volumes to a Wasabi bucket using the S3 API via Restic.

virtual machine.eli5: A pretend computer running inside your real computer.
virtual machine.boss: A virtual machine (VM) is software that emulates a full computer system, allowing you to run multiple OSes on one machine.
virtual machine.sysadmin: A virtual machine is a software-defined environment that emulates physical hardware, managed by a hypervisor like KVM or VMware to run isolated operating systems.
virtual machine.use_case: Running a Windows VM on a Linux server to isolate work apps.

snapshot.eli5: Itâ€™s like saving a frozen-in-time picture of your system that you can return to later.
snapshot.boss: A snapshot is a point-in-time backup of a system or data set that can be restored if something goes wrong.
snapshot.sysadmin: A snapshot is a consistent point-in-time image of a volume or VM that can be used for rollback, backup, or cloning, supported by systems like ZFS, LVM, and Proxmox.
snapshot.use_case: Creating a snapshot before updating a VM in case the update fails.

live migration.eli5: Moving a running computer from one place to another without turning it off.
live migration.boss: Live migration lets you move virtual machines between hosts with zero downtime.
live migration.sysadmin: Live migration is the process of moving a running VM between hypervisors without interruption by syncing memory state and minimizing service disruption.
live migration.use_case: Live migrating a VM from one Proxmox node to another during hardware maintenance.

cold migration.eli5: Moving a computer while itâ€™s turned off.
cold migration.boss: Cold migration is the process of moving a stopped virtual machine between hosts.
cold migration.sysadmin: Cold migration transfers a powered-off VM to another hypervisor or datastore, useful when live migration isn't possible due to hardware or compatibility limits.
cold migration.use_case: Performing a cold migration to move a VMâ€™s disk to faster storage overnight.

guest tools.eli5: Helpers inside your pretend computer to make it talk better with the host.
guest tools.boss: Guest tools improve performance and integration between a virtual machine and its host.
guest tools.sysadmin: Guest tools (like QEMU Guest Agent or VMware Tools) enable time syncing, clipboard sharing, shutdown commands, and better performance between VMs and their hypervisors.
guest tools.use_case: Installing guest tools to enable clean shutdown and IP reporting for VMs in Proxmox.

ballooning.eli5: A way for your pretend computer to borrow or return memory based on how busy it is.
ballooning.boss: Ballooning dynamically adjusts a virtual machineâ€™s memory usage based on system demand.
ballooning.sysadmin: Memory ballooning is a hypervisor technique where a guest VM releases unused memory back to the host or requests more as needed, improving RAM utilization.
ballooning.use_case: Using ballooning in Proxmox to prevent RAM overcommit from affecting performance.

container image.eli5: A containerâ€™s recipe bookâ€”it has everything needed to cook up an app.
container image.boss: A container image is a packaged version of an app with all its code and dependencies, ready to run anywhere.
container image.sysadmin: A container image is a read-only filesystem bundle that includes binaries, libraries, and metadata required to launch a container, created via tools like Docker or Buildah.
container image.use_case: Using a lightweight Alpine container image to run a minimal Python script.

buildah.eli5: A toolbox that builds container images without needing Docker.
buildah.boss: Buildah is a container image builder that works without a running Docker daemon.
buildah.sysadmin: Buildah is a CLI tool from Red Hat used to build Open Container Initiative (OCI) images from scratch or Dockerfiles, often integrated into CI/CD pipelines.
buildah.use_case: Using Buildah in a CI pipeline to create and push a secure, minimal container image.

autoscaling.eli5: Itâ€™s like magic grow or shrink powers for your apps when traffic changes.
autoscaling.boss: Autoscaling automatically adjusts the number of resources an app uses based on demand.
autoscaling.sysadmin: Autoscaling enables dynamic scaling of containers, pods, or VMs based on metrics like CPU, memory, or custom thresholds, often controlled by orchestrators like Kubernetes.
autoscaling.use_case: Enabling autoscaling in Kubernetes to handle traffic spikes during product launches.

horizontal pod autoscaler.eli5: It adds more little app copies when people start using them a lot.
horizontal pod autoscaler.boss: HPA automatically creates or removes app pods based on CPU or custom usage.
horizontal pod autoscaler.sysadmin: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) is a Kubernetes controller that adjusts pod counts in a deployment or replica set based on observed metrics like CPU utilization.
horizontal pod autoscaler.use_case: Setting up HPA to spin up more NGINX pods as CPU usage increases during peak hours.

cluster autoscaler.eli5: If your playground gets too crowded, this adds more space automatically.
cluster autoscaler.boss: Cluster Autoscaler adds or removes computing nodes in your cluster based on resource needs.
cluster autoscaler.sysadmin: Cluster Autoscaler is a Kubernetes component that automatically scales the number of nodes in a cluster based on unschedulable pods or underutilized resources.
cluster autoscaler.use_case: Using cluster autoscaler in EKS to spin up new worker nodes during CI builds.

networking.eli5: The wires and invisible waves that help your devices talk to each other.
networking.boss: Networking is the foundation that connects devices, systems, and services across the internet or local areas.
networking.sysadmin: Networking covers protocols, interfaces, routing, switching, firewalls, and services that allow devices and applications to communicate reliably and securely.
networking.use_case: Configuring a home network with VLANs and static routes for different device types.

subnet.eli5: Itâ€™s like assigning your neighborhood its own street numbers to stay organized.
subnet.boss: A subnet divides a larger network into smaller, manageable chunks.
subnet.sysadmin: A subnet is a logical segmentation of an IP network, defined by a subnet mask, used to improve routing efficiency and security.
subnet.use_case: Creating separate subnets for IoT devices and desktops to isolate traffic.

openshift.eli5: A fancy container playground made by Red Hat that adds extra guardrails.
openshift.boss: OpenShift is Red Hatâ€™s enterprise platform for managing containerized applications with added security and tools on top of Kubernetes.
openshift.sysadmin: OpenShift is a Kubernetes distribution by Red Hat that includes a web console, integrated CI/CD, RBAC, monitoring, and S2I builds with enterprise-grade features.
openshift.use_case: Deploying OpenShift to manage microservices with built-in CI pipelines and strict access controls.

authentik.eli5: Itâ€™s like your homeâ€™s bouncer that only lets in people who show the right badge.
authentik.boss: Authentik is an identity provider that manages secure logins and access to apps using modern protocols like OAuth2 and SAML.
authentik.sysadmin: Authentik is a self-hosted identity provider and access proxy supporting OAuth2, OpenID Connect, SAML, and LDAP, with built-in user directory, SSO, and flow-based policies.
authentik.use_case: Deploying Authentik in front of internal dashboards to handle SSO and restrict access by group.

authelia.eli5: A doorman that checks who you are before letting you into your private web apps.
authelia.boss: Authelia is a self-hosted authentication and authorization server that protects internal services with 2FA and SSO.
authelia.sysadmin: Authelia is an authentication and access control server with reverse proxy integration, supporting 2FA, SSO, LDAP, and policy-based rules for securing apps.
authelia.use_case: Using Authelia with NGINX to protect self-hosted apps with 2FA and per-user access control.

keycloak.eli5: Itâ€™s like a digital ID office for all your users and apps to share one login.
keycloak.boss: Keycloak is an open-source identity and access management platform that provides SSO, login flows, and federation across services.
keycloak.sysadmin: Keycloak is a Java-based identity provider supporting OpenID Connect, OAuth2, and SAML, offering user federation, LDAP integration, social login, and admin UI for managing roles and clients.
keycloak.use_case: Using Keycloak to manage logins for internal tools, enforcing group-based access and identity federation with LDAP.

bookstack.eli5: Itâ€™s like your own personal Wikipedia you can organize into shelves and books.
bookstack.boss: BookStack is a self-hosted wiki platform for creating structured documentation with a simple editor.
bookstack.sysadmin: BookStack is a Laravel-based open-source wiki system with a hierarchical structure of Books, Chapters, and Pages, supporting Markdown, WYSIWYG editing, and authentication.
bookstack.use_case: Hosting BookStack in your home lab to document server setups, passwords, and procedures.

wiki.js.eli5: A high-tech notebook you can share online and customize however you want.
wiki.js.boss: Wiki.js is a modern wiki platform with a sleek interface and support for many content types and integrations.
wiki.js.sysadmin: Wiki.js is a Node.js-powered wiki system with support for Markdown, Git-backed storage, authentication providers, and visual editing features.
wiki.js.use_case: Using Wiki.js to manage documentation across teams with GitHub sync and SSO.

hedgedoc.eli5: A shared digital notepad where everyone can type and see changes in real-time.
hedgedoc.boss: HedgeDoc is a collaborative Markdown editor ideal for taking notes and drafting documents live.
hedgedoc.sysadmin: HedgeDoc is a self-hosted collaborative Markdown editor with live preview, real-time sync, and support for presentation mode and embedding media.
hedgedoc.use_case: Hosting HedgeDoc for real-time collaboration during team meetings and documentation sprints.

joplin server.eli5: A safe place to keep all your notes, lists, and ideasâ€”just like your own Evernote.
joplin server.boss: Joplin Server lets you sync notes and notebooks between devices using the open-source Joplin app.
joplin server.sysadmin: Joplin Server is a self-hosted backend for syncing Joplin notes and attachments across clients, using WebDAV-like APIs and end-to-end encryption support.
joplin server.use_case: Deploying Joplin Server in Docker to keep encrypted notes synced across devices.

infrastructure.eli5: Itâ€™s all the digital and physical stuff that makes computers and the internet work.
infrastructure.boss: Infrastructure includes the hardware, software, and network systems that support IT operations.
infrastructure.sysadmin: Infrastructure refers to the foundational physical and virtual resourcesâ€”servers, networking, storage, power, and coolingâ€”required to run enterprise or cloud services.
infrastructure.use_case: Planning the infrastructure for a new office including servers, switches, and racks.

it infrastructure.eli5: The digital skeleton that holds up a companyâ€™s tech systems.
it infrastructure.boss: IT infrastructure is everything tech-related that a business needs to operateâ€”servers, networking, storage, and services.
it infrastructure.sysadmin: IT infrastructure encompasses all physical and virtual componentsâ€”servers, virtualization layers, networking gear, storage, and monitoringâ€”that enable IT services.
it infrastructure.use_case: Auditing IT infrastructure to identify outdated servers and optimize costs.

infrastructure as code.eli5: Writing instructions for building computers and networks like youâ€™d write a recipe.
infrastructure as code.boss: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) means using code to define and manage IT resources automatically.
infrastructure as code.sysadmin: Infrastructure as Code uses declarative or imperative configuration files (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) to provision and manage infrastructure consistently across environments.
infrastructure as code.use_case: Using Terraform to provision a cloud database and Kubernetes cluster as code.

bare metal.eli5: Itâ€™s like renting the whole house instead of just an apartment.
bare metal.boss: Bare metal servers are physical machines that arenâ€™t shared with othersâ€”offering full control and performance.
bare metal.sysadmin: Bare metal refers to non-virtualized physical servers that host operating systems directly, typically used for high-performance, latency-sensitive, or hardware-specific workloads.
bare metal.use_case: Hosting a Proxmox hypervisor directly on bare metal to maximize VM performance.

virtualization.eli5: Pretending one computer is really many computers.
virtualization.boss: Virtualization lets you run multiple operating systems on a single physical machine by creating virtual versions of computers.
virtualization.sysadmin: Virtualization abstracts physical hardware to create isolated virtual machines or containers using hypervisors or kernel features like KVM.
virtualization.use_case: Using virtualization to run Linux and Windows test servers on one physical host.

hypervisor.eli5: A special computer brain that lets one machine pretend to be many.
hypervisor.boss: A hypervisor allows you to run multiple virtual machines on one physical server by separating hardware from software.
hypervisor.sysadmin: A hypervisor is virtualization software that creates and manages virtual machines by abstracting hardware. Examples include KVM, ESXi, and Hyper-V.
hypervisor.use_case: Using a hypervisor to run isolated VM environments for development, QA, and production on the same server.

type 1 hypervisor.eli5: Itâ€™s like a landlord who lives in the buildingâ€”directly managing everything.
type 1 hypervisor.boss: Type 1 hypervisors run directly on hardware and are more efficient for managing VMs in production.
type 1 hypervisor.sysadmin: A Type 1 hypervisor (bare-metal) runs directly on server hardware and hosts guest operating systems without needing a host OS. Examples: VMware ESXi, Xen, Hyper-V.
type 1 hypervisor.use_case: Using a Type 1 hypervisor like Proxmox VE to run multiple virtualized servers efficiently on a rackmount host.

type 2 hypervisor.eli5: A pretend computer running inside your existing one, like a toy inside a toy.
type 2 hypervisor.boss: Type 2 hypervisors run on top of an existing OS and are good for testing and development.
type 2 hypervisor.sysadmin: A Type 2 hypervisor runs as a software layer on an existing OS and allows guest VMs. Examples: VirtualBox, VMware Workstation.
type 2 hypervisor.use_case: Running VirtualBox on your laptop as a Type 2 hypervisor to test Linux distros.

xen.eli5: A powerful engine for running pretend computers, used in big cloud services.
xen.boss: Xen is an open-source hypervisor used to run multiple virtual machines on a physical host.
xen.sysadmin: Xen is a Type 1 hypervisor that uses paravirtualization or hardware-assisted virtualization, popular in cloud platforms like AWS.
xen.use_case: Using Xen in a research lab to run isolated virtual machines with low overhead.

proxmox ve.eli5: A control panel for running lots of pretend computers on one real machine.
proxmox ve.boss: Proxmox VE is a free virtualization platform that helps manage VMs and containers from a browser.
proxmox ve.sysadmin: Proxmox VE is an open-source virtualization environment with KVM, LXC, ZFS, and web UI for managing virtual machines, backups, HA, and clustering.
proxmox ve.use_case: Using Proxmox VE to build a small home lab with VMs and LXC containers running on a single server.

rackmount kit.eli5: A metal shelf that helps you slide your computers neatly into a cabinet.
rackmount kit.boss: A rackmount kit is a hardware accessory that allows servers or devices to be mounted in a standard 19-inch rack.
rackmount kit.sysadmin: Rackmount kits include rails, brackets, and screws that enable secure installation of rack-compatible devices in data center enclosures.
rackmount kit.use_case: Using a rackmount kit to securely install a firewall appliance in a 4U rack enclosure.

colocation.eli5: Itâ€™s like renting space in a tech hotel for your own servers.
colocation.boss: Colocation is hosting your physical servers in a professional data center with power, cooling, and network access.
colocation.sysadmin: Colocation involves placing owned hardware in a third-party data center facility, sharing resources like power, bandwidth, security, and climate control.
colocation.use_case: Using colocation to house your server in a Tier III facility for better uptime and redundant power.

data center.eli5: A giant computer warehouse that keeps important servers running 24/7.
data center.boss: A data center is a secure building that houses computing systems, power, and cooling for businesses and internet services.
data center.sysadmin: Data centers are specialized facilities designed to host IT infrastructure, offering physical security, climate control, redundant power, networking, and fire suppression systems.
data center.use_case: Moving web hosting servers into a regional data center to improve uptime and security.

uptime tier.eli5: A badge that shows how long a data center can stay online, even during problems.
uptime tier.boss: Uptime tiers rank data centers by reliability, from Tier I (basic) to Tier IV (high redundancy).
uptime tier.sysadmin: Uptime Institute defines data center tiers based on redundancy and fault tolerance: Tier I (basic), Tier II (redundant power), Tier III (concurrent maintenance), and Tier IV (fault-tolerant).
uptime tier.use_case: Selecting a Tier III data center for colocation to ensure 99.982% uptime and maintenance flexibility.

redundant power supply.eli5: Two plugs instead of oneâ€”so your server keeps running if one fails.
redundant power supply.boss: A redundant power supply adds a second PSU to a server so it stays online if one fails.
redundant power supply.sysadmin: Redundant power supplies (dual PSUs) provide continuous power by switching to the backup PSU if the primary fails, commonly used in enterprise servers and switches.
redundant power supply.use_case: Installing a redundant PSU in a rackmount NAS to prevent downtime during maintenance or power loss.

cooling unit.eli5: A giant air conditioner that keeps the servers from sweating.
cooling unit.boss: Cooling units control temperature and humidity in data centers to keep equipment running efficiently.
cooling unit.sysadmin: Data center cooling systems (CRAC, in-row cooling, or liquid cooling) maintain optimal temperature and airflow to prevent overheating of high-density racks.
cooling unit.use_case: Monitoring the cooling unit in a server room to maintain a consistent 21Â°C environment for hardware longevity.

cable management.eli5: Keeping your tech spaghetti neatly wrapped and labeled.
cable management.boss: Cable management helps organize wires and connections to improve airflow and prevent confusion.
cable management.sysadmin: Cable management involves using Velcro, trays, labels, and color coding to route and organize network and power cables in racks or server rooms.
cable management.use_case: Color-coding cables and using Velcro wraps to organize patch panels in a 42U rack.

network infrastructure.eli5: All the wires, boxes, and magic that help your computers talk to each other.
network infrastructure.boss: Network infrastructure includes the routers, switches, and cabling that connect devices in an office, home, or data center.
network infrastructure.sysadmin: Network infrastructure encompasses the physical and logical componentsâ€”cabling, switches, routers, firewalls, and protocolsâ€”used to enable secure communication between devices and services.
network infrastructure.use_case: Upgrading the network infrastructure in a small business to support 10GbE connections and VLAN segmentation.

aggregation switch.eli5: A powerful traffic hub that connects many smaller networks into one big stream.
aggregation switch.boss: An aggregation switch combines traffic from multiple access switches for routing or uplink to the core network.
aggregation switch.sysadmin: Aggregation switches sit between access and core layers, consolidating traffic from edge switches and providing uplinks to routers or backbone networksâ€”often with high-speed 10/40/100GbE ports.
aggregation switch.use_case: Using a 10GbE aggregation switch to combine traffic from lab switches into a pfSense router.

network tap.eli5: A tiny spy device that watches all the data flying through a network cable.
network tap.boss: A network tap passively copies network traffic so it can be analyzed without disrupting flow.
network tap.sysadmin: A network tap is a hardware device placed inline between two network devices to mirror traffic to a monitoring tool or IDS without introducing latency or failure risk.
network tap.use_case: Installing a network tap to feed mirrored traffic into a Suricata IDS for inspection.

bmc.eli5: A tiny helper computer inside your server that lets you control itâ€”even when it's off.
bmc.boss: A BMC is a special chip in servers that allows remote monitoring and control, even if the main system is powered down.
bmc.sysadmin: The Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) is a microcontroller on server motherboards providing out-of-band management using protocols like IPMI or Redfish, enabling remote access, power cycling, and sensor monitoring.
bmc.use_case: Using the BMC to remotely reboot a crashed server at a colocation facility.

console server.eli5: A remote keyboard and screen for your serversâ€”even if they crash.
console server.boss: A console server lets IT teams access and manage servers remotely at a low levelâ€”even during reboots or failures.
console server.sysadmin: A console server provides out-of-band access to serial or KVM console ports on infrastructure, enabling remote management, troubleshooting, and rebooting even when systems are unresponsive.
console server.use_case: Using a console server to access the boot screen of a remote router after a failed update.

nas.eli5: A smart hard drive that everyone at home can use to save files.
nas.boss: NAS stands for Network Attached Storageâ€”a dedicated device for storing and sharing files across a network.
nas.sysadmin: A NAS is a self-contained storage system connected via Ethernet, offering shared access to files using SMB, NFS, or FTP, often with RAID and user permissions.
nas.use_case: Backing up family photos and streaming media from a NAS to smart TVs.

san.eli5: A giant digital closet that gives many servers access to the same storage.
san.boss: SAN (Storage Area Network) is a high-speed network that connects servers to storage devices for fast, block-level access.
san.sysadmin: A SAN is a specialized network providing block-level access to shared storage resources, using protocols like iSCSI or Fibre Channel for high performance and redundancy.
san.use_case: Using a SAN in a data center to provide shared storage to VMware hosts with HA.

jbod.eli5: Itâ€™s a pile of drives acting like one big box, but with no safety net.
jbod.boss: JBOD stands for 'Just a Bunch Of Disks'â€”a simple way to combine drives without redundancy.
jbod.sysadmin: JBOD combines multiple physical disks into a single logical volume without RAID or redundancyâ€”often used for flexible storage where performance or fault tolerance isn't required.
jbod.use_case: Using JBOD in a backup server to maximize storage space with old hard drives.

ceph.eli5: A smart brain that spreads your data across many drives so it stays safe and fast.
ceph.boss: Ceph is a distributed storage platform that balances data across nodes and offers fault tolerance.
ceph.sysadmin: Ceph is a scalable, open-source distributed storage system offering object, block, and file storage with replication and self-healing features.
ceph.use_case: Using Ceph in a Proxmox cluster for redundant, self-healing storage across nodes.

glusterfs.eli5: A digital jigsaw puzzle that pieces together drives from different servers into one big folder.
glusterfs.boss: GlusterFS is a scalable storage system that combines multiple disks into a distributed file system.
glusterfs.sysadmin: GlusterFS is a user-space distributed filesystem that aggregates storage from multiple servers into a single mount point with replication, sharding, and failover.
glusterfs.use_case: Using GlusterFS to replicate files across three Raspberry Pis for a fault-tolerant backup system.

fluent bit.eli5: A log delivery truck that collects messages and takes them where they need to go.
fluent bit.boss: Fluent Bit is a lightweight tool for collecting and shipping logs from apps and servers to storage or analytics tools.
fluent bit.sysadmin: Fluent Bit is an open-source log processor and forwarder optimized for resource-constrained environments, supporting input parsing, filtering, and output routing to Elasticsearch, Loki, and others.
fluent bit.use_case: Using Fluent Bit on edge devices to send structured logs to Elasticsearch.

filebeat.eli5: A tiny helper that reads log files and sends them to a log collector.
filebeat.boss: Filebeat collects log files and sends them to Elasticsearch or Logstash for analysis.
filebeat.sysadmin: Filebeat is a lightweight shipper that reads log files and forwards them to Elasticsearch, Logstash, or Kafka, often used as part of the Elastic Stack.
filebeat.use_case: Deploying Filebeat to forward app logs from Docker containers to an Elastic Stack dashboard.

logstash.eli5: A smart filter that cleans and sorts your logs before sending them to storage.
logstash.boss: Logstash processes logs from many sources and sends them to Elasticsearch or other systems.
logstash.sysadmin: Logstash is an open-source pipeline that ingests, transforms, and routes logs and metrics from multiple inputs to outputs like Elasticsearch, S3, or Kafka.
logstash.use_case: Using Logstash to enrich logs with geo-IP data before storing them in Elasticsearch.

elasticsearch.eli5: A powerful digital librarian that can search through tons of info really fast.
elasticsearch.boss: Elasticsearch is a search engine and analytics tool that lets you explore large volumes of data efficiently.
elasticsearch.sysadmin: Elasticsearch is a distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine based on Lucene, used for full-text search, log analysis, and real-time dashboards.
elasticsearch.use_case: Using Elasticsearch to index and search logs collected from servers across your environment.

opentelemetry.eli5: A toolkit that watches your appâ€™s health and how fast it runs.
opentelemetry.boss: OpenTelemetry collects metrics, logs, and traces from your apps so you can monitor performance and errors.
opentelemetry.sysadmin: OpenTelemetry is an open-source observability framework for collecting telemetry data (metrics, logs, traces) from applications, services, and infrastructure using standardized APIs and SDKs.
opentelemetry.use_case: Instrumenting a Go app with OpenTelemetry to export traces to Grafana Tempo and metrics to Prometheus.

audit logs.eli5: A diary that writes down who did what and when on your system.
audit logs.boss: Audit logs are records of system events and user actions used for security and compliance.
audit logs.sysadmin: Audit logs capture chronological events like logins, config changes, file access, and admin actions to support incident response, compliance, and debugging.
audit logs.use_case: Using audit logs to investigate unauthorized login attempts on a self-hosted server.

systemd.eli5: A chore manager for your Linux computerâ€”it starts everything up in the right order.
systemd.boss: Systemd is a core component in many Linux systems that handles startup, services, and logs.
systemd.sysadmin: Systemd is an init system and service manager for Linux that handles boot sequences, service supervision, timers, sockets, and journaling.
systemd.use_case: Using systemd to manage and restart your Node.js service automatically after a crash.

cron.eli5: A clock that tells your computer when to do stuff automatically.
cron.boss: Cron is a scheduling tool in Unix systems for running scripts and tasks at set times.
cron.sysadmin: Cron is a time-based job scheduler in Unix-like systems that reads crontab files to run shell commands periodically.
cron.use_case: Using cron to back up your MySQL database every night at 2 AM.

timer unit.eli5: A newer version of cron that works better with Linuxâ€™s built-in tools.
timer unit.boss: Timer units are part of systemd that allow you to schedule jobs like cron but with more flexibility.
timer unit.sysadmin: Systemd timer units trigger service units on a defined schedule or delay, offering logging, accuracy, and dependency benefits over traditional cron.
timer unit.use_case: Replacing a cron job with a systemd timer unit to log and manage failed executions.

runbook.eli5: An instruction sheet for fixing or running things when they break.
runbook.boss: A runbook is a documented step-by-step guide for IT teams to handle routine or emergency operations.
runbook.sysadmin: A runbook is an operational guide containing procedures, diagnostics, scripts, and manual recovery steps for systems and servicesâ€”used in automation and incident response.
runbook.use_case: Creating a runbook for restoring a crashed VM, with screenshots and commands included.

schema markup.eli5: Extra code that helps Google understand what your webpage is really about.
schema markup.boss: Schema markup adds context to your website content for search engines to show rich results.
schema markup.sysadmin: Schema markup is structured data in JSON-LD, Microdata, or RDFa formats embedded in web pages to enhance SEO by describing entities, reviews, products, etc.
schema markup.use_case: Adding schema markup to blog posts so Google shows star ratings and author info in search results.

json-ld.eli5: A way to add invisible labels to your website so search engines understand whatâ€™s there.
json-ld.boss: JSON-LD is a format used to insert structured data into websites for better search engine visibility.
json-ld.sysadmin: JSON-LD (JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data) is a structured data format embedded in HTML via `<script>` tags, widely used for schema markup and semantic relationships.
json-ld.use_case: Using JSON-LD to define an organizationâ€™s contact info and logo in a websiteâ€™s head.

canonical url.eli5: Itâ€™s the main version of a webpage, so search engines donâ€™t get confused.
canonical url.boss: A canonical URL tells search engines which version of a page is the official one to avoid SEO duplication.
canonical url.sysadmin: A canonical URL is specified with the `<link rel='canonical'>` tag to prevent duplicate content issues by identifying the preferred version of a page.
canonical url.use_case: Adding canonical URLs to blog archives to ensure search engines index only the main post.

alt text.eli5: A short label that explains what a picture isâ€”just in case it doesnâ€™t show up.
alt text.boss: Alt text describes images so visually impaired users and search engines can understand them.
alt text.sysadmin: Alt text is HTML image metadata (`alt` attribute) used for accessibility, SEO, and fallback display when images fail to load.
alt text.use_case: Writing meaningful alt text for product images so screen readers can describe them to users.

h1 tag.eli5: Itâ€™s the big headline at the top of your webpage.
h1 tag.boss: The H1 tag tells search engines and users what your page is mainly about.
h1 tag.sysadmin: The `<h1>` HTML tag defines the main heading on a webpage, carrying high semantic weight for accessibility and SEO.
h1 tag.use_case: Making sure each page has a single, descriptive H1 tag to improve search engine ranking.

semantic html.eli5: HTML with meaningâ€”so both humans and robots know what each part of the page is.
semantic html.boss: Semantic HTML uses tags that describe content structure, improving SEO and accessibility.
semantic html.sysadmin: Semantic HTML uses meaningful tags like `<article>`, `<section>`, `<nav>`, and `<footer>` to define page layout, helping search engines and assistive tech parse content.
semantic html.use_case: Refactoring a webpage with semantic HTML to enhance screen reader navigation and SEO.

app shell.eli5: The outer frame of a web appâ€”like a storefront that stays put while the inside changes.
app shell.boss: The app shell is the static part of a PWA that loads instantly and gives users a native app feel.
app shell.sysadmin: App shell architecture separates static UI elements from dynamic content, allowing PWAs to cache and quickly render interface elements even while offline.
app shell.use_case: Building a PWA with an app shell to make the core UI load instantly even on slow connections.

sonarr.eli5: A robot helper that finds and downloads your favorite TV shows automatically.
sonarr.boss: Sonarr is a tool that automates the download, organization, and monitoring of TV series using Usenet or torrents.
sonarr.sysadmin: Sonarr is a .NET-based PVR that monitors RSS feeds from indexers, manages TV series, handles failed downloads, and integrates with clients like NZBGet and qBittorrent.
sonarr.use_case: Running Sonarr in Docker to auto-download and rename TV shows with metadata from TheTVDB.

daemonset.eli5: Imagine having a janitor on every floor of a building who does the same job. A DaemonSet makes sure each floor (node) has that janitor (pod) running.
daemonset.boss: A DaemonSet in Kubernetes ensures that a specific pod runs on allâ€”or selectedâ€”nodes in a cluster. It's great for deploying things like log collectors or monitoring agents.
daemonset.sysadmin: DaemonSets are Kubernetes objects that ensure a copy of a pod is running on all (or specified) nodes in the cluster. Commonly used for cluster-wide services like log shipping, monitoring, or networking.
daemonset.use_case: Deploying a node-level monitoring agent like Prometheus Node Exporter across all nodes in a Kubernetes cluster.

statefulset.eli5: Itâ€™s like giving each kid in a classroom their own locker and nametagâ€”so they always get the same seat and spot, no matter what.
statefulset.boss: StatefulSets help run applications in Kubernetes that need stable network IDs and persistent storage, such as databases.
statefulset.sysadmin: StatefulSets manage the deployment and scaling of stateful applications in Kubernetes. Unlike regular pods, they provide consistent naming, persistent volumes, and ordered deployments.
statefulset.use_case: Running a Cassandra cluster where each node must maintain its own identity and storage across restarts.

service.eli5: Itâ€™s like a front desk that tells people where to find the right room, even if the rooms change.
service.boss: In Kubernetes, a Service acts as a stable network endpoint to connect to pods, even when the pod IPs change.
service.sysadmin: A Kubernetes Service provides a persistent IP and DNS name to expose a set of pods, supporting internal or external access with load balancing.
service.use_case: Exposing a backend API to other internal microservices through a ClusterIP service.

ingress.eli5: Think of it like a smart doorman that routes incoming visitors to the right apartment inside a building.
ingress.boss: Ingress in Kubernetes is a way to route external traffic to internal services based on rules like URLs or hostnames.
ingress.sysadmin: Ingress is an API object in Kubernetes that manages external HTTP(S) access to services, with features like path-based routing, TLS termination, and virtual hosting.
ingress.use_case: Using an Ingress controller to expose multiple web apps under different URLs on the same IP address.

loadbalancer.eli5: Like a traffic cop directing cars evenly between open lanes, a load balancer sends visitors to the least busy server.
loadbalancer.boss: A LoadBalancer distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure no one gets overloaded and apps stay available.
loadbalancer.sysadmin: In Kubernetes, a LoadBalancer type service provisions an external IP and forwards traffic to backend pods, often integrating with cloud provider load balancers.
loadbalancer.use_case: Exposing a public-facing website using a Kubernetes LoadBalancer service in AWS that auto-assigns an external IP.

persistent volume.eli5: Like a USB drive that remembers your stuff even if you unplug it and plug it into another computer.
persistent volume.boss: A Persistent Volume (PV) in Kubernetes gives pods durable storage that survives pod restarts or rescheduling.
persistent volume.sysadmin: Persistent Volumes are cluster-wide storage resources provisioned manually or dynamically, abstracting the underlying storage backend and binding to Persistent Volume Claims.
persistent volume.use_case: Provisioning networked storage for a PostgreSQL pod that needs to retain data even after restarts.

configmap.eli5: Like a shared recipe card that tells everyone in the kitchen how to cook somethingâ€”without baking it into the dish.
configmap.boss: ConfigMaps let you keep configuration settings separate from code so you can change behavior without rebuilding containers.
configmap.sysadmin: A ConfigMap is a Kubernetes API object used to store non-sensitive configuration data such as environment variables, CLI arguments, or config files, and inject them into pods.
configmap.use_case: Mounting a custom Nginx config file into a pod using a ConfigMap.

secret.eli5: Like a locked box that holds passwords or keys, only certain people are allowed to open it.
secret.boss: A Secret in Kubernetes safely stores sensitive data like API keys, passwords, and certificates, separate from the app code.
secret.sysadmin: Kubernetes Secrets are base64-encoded key-value pairs designed for securely injecting confidential data into pods via environment variables or mounted files.
secret.use_case: Injecting a TLS certificate into a web server pod using a Kubernetes Secret.

helm.eli5: Like an app store for Kubernetes, Helm helps you install and manage apps with a few commands.
helm.boss: Helm simplifies deploying Kubernetes applications by bundling them into reusable charts and handling configuration with templates.
helm.sysadmin: Helm is a Kubernetes package manager that uses 'charts' to define, install, and upgrade applications. It supports templating and versioning for repeatable deployments.
helm.use_case: Installing Prometheus and Grafana using the Bitnami Helm charts for quick deployment and configuration.

kustomize.eli5: Itâ€™s like using stickers to customize a toyâ€”Kustomize lets you tweak Kubernetes setups without changing the original files.
kustomize.boss: Kustomize enables you to manage Kubernetes manifests without copying files. It lets you layer and customize deployments cleanly.
kustomize.sysadmin: Kustomize is a Kubernetes-native configuration tool that allows you to patch, override, and compose YAML resources declaratively without using templates.
kustomize.use_case: Creating environment-specific Kubernetes deployments (dev, staging, prod) using a common base with Kustomize overlays.

node pool.eli5: Imagine splitting a classroom into different groups, each with different toolsâ€”node pools let you group servers in a similar way.
node pool.boss: A node pool is a set of nodes within a Kubernetes cluster that share the same configuration, such as size, OS, or labels.
node pool.sysadmin: In Kubernetes, a node pool is a subset of nodes managed together, typically with common roles or resource types. It allows for tailored scaling and OS-level configuration per group.
node pool.use_case: Using GPU-enabled node pools for AI workloads while keeping regular web services in general-purpose node pools.

provisioning.eli5: Itâ€™s like setting up a new phone with all your favorite apps and settings before using it.
provisioning.boss: Provisioning prepares IT resourcesâ€”like servers or containersâ€”for use, including installing software and setting configurations.
provisioning.sysadmin: Provisioning refers to the automated setup of infrastructure components, such as virtual machines, containers, or user accounts, with required software and configurations.
provisioning.use_case: Automatically provisioning a VM with the latest Ubuntu image, Docker, and a preloaded web app.

pxe boot.eli5: Like turning on a new computer and it asks the network what it should become.
pxe boot.boss: PXE Boot allows a computer to boot up over a network without needing a local drive, often used in automated deployments.
pxe boot.sysadmin: Preboot Execution Environment (PXE) enables devices to retrieve and boot operating system images over the network, commonly used in OS deployment pipelines.
pxe boot.use_case: Booting diskless workstations in a computer lab using PXE to load Linux images from a deployment server.

kickstart.eli5: Like using a pre-filled form to set up a bunch of computers the same way.
kickstart.boss: Kickstart automates Red Hat-based Linux installs by using pre-written configuration files to speed up deployments.
kickstart.sysadmin: Kickstart is an automated installation method for Red Hat and CentOS, using a script file to define partitions, packages, and post-install commands.
kickstart.use_case: Using Kickstart files to deploy hundreds of CentOS servers with consistent settings in a data center.

preseed.eli5: Like giving instructions ahead of time so your friend can build a LEGO set without asking questions.
preseed.boss: Preseed lets you automate Ubuntu and Debian installs by feeding in answers to all the usual setup prompts.
preseed.sysadmin: Preseed is a Debian-based method for automating OS installations via a config file that pre-answers the installer's questions.
preseed.use_case: Using Preseed to automate Ubuntu server installation for virtual machines in a home lab.

cloud-init.eli5: Like handing a welcome packet to a new employee that tells them exactly how to set up their desk.
cloud-init.boss: Cloud-init configures cloud instances at launchâ€”setting hostnames, SSH keys, and moreâ€”based on predefined scripts.
cloud-init.sysadmin: Cloud-init is a widely used tool for customizing Linux cloud instances during boot with tasks like user creation, software install, and networking setup.
cloud-init.use_case: Spinning up an EC2 instance that automatically installs NGINX and applies security patches using cloud-init.

ignition config.eli5: Like giving a builder a detailed blueprint before they start assembling furniture.
ignition config.boss: Ignition is a config system used during Fedora CoreOS and Flatcar OS boot to set up disks, users, and networking.
ignition config.sysadmin: Ignition configures machines in early boot by writing filesystems, creating users, and setting systemd unitsâ€”mainly for Fedora CoreOS and compatible OSes.
ignition config.use_case: Provisioning a Fedora CoreOS node in a Kubernetes cluster using Ignition to set up systemd units and user accounts.

drift detection.eli5: Like checking if your LEGO tower still looks like the instructions say it should.
drift detection.boss: Drift detection checks if your infrastructure still matches the original configuration or if someone made changes manually.
drift detection.sysadmin: Infrastructure drift detection monitors config management or IaC systems like Terraform to identify divergence between actual and declared system state.
drift detection.use_case: Using drift detection in Terraform Cloud to alert when someone manually modifies a VM outside of code.

declarative infrastructure.eli5: It's like writing a grocery list and having a robot automatically go shop for youâ€”no instructions needed.
declarative infrastructure.boss: Declarative infrastructure describes what your systems should look like, and the tools figure out how to get there.
declarative infrastructure.sysadmin: This is an IaC pattern where infrastructure is defined via desired state files (e.g., Terraform, Kubernetes manifests), allowing automation tools to reconcile real vs expected configuration.
declarative infrastructure.use_case: Defining all infrastructure in Terraform so engineers never have to touch the cloud console manually.

idempotency.eli5: Like pressing a light switch twiceâ€”it wonâ€™t double-turn the lights on, it just keeps the state correct.
idempotency.boss: Idempotency ensures that running the same operation multiple times has the same effect, which is critical in automation.
idempotency.sysadmin: In IaC and APIs, idempotency means repeating an action yields the same system stateâ€”it's crucial for reliable, repeatable operations like provisioning or updates.
idempotency.use_case: Using Ansible playbooks that can run repeatedly without causing unintended changes thanks to idempotency.

state file.eli5: Like a diary that tracks everything youâ€™ve done, so you donâ€™t repeat or mess up the same task twice.
state file.boss: State files record what infrastructure has been deployed, so tools like Terraform know what exists and what needs changing.
state file.sysadmin: Terraformâ€™s state file tracks deployed resources and metadata, enabling plan and apply operations to compare actual infrastructure to the desired state.
state file.use_case: Storing Terraform's state file remotely in an S3 bucket for team collaboration and consistent deployments.

terraform plan.eli5: Itâ€™s like a dry run before rearranging your furnitureâ€”you see what will change before actually doing anything.
terraform plan.boss: Terraform Plan previews what will be added, changed, or destroyed before applying infrastructure changes.
terraform plan.sysadmin: Running `terraform plan` shows a proposed execution plan by comparing the current state file with configuration code, without making actual changes.
terraform plan.use_case: Running `terraform plan` in CI to verify infrastructure changes before approving a pull request.

terraform apply.eli5: Like saying 'make it so' after reviewing your blueprint for building a treehouse.
terraform apply.boss: Terraform Apply executes the infrastructure changes you've approved and defined in code.
terraform apply.sysadmin: `terraform apply` deploys resources as specified in configuration files by updating or creating infrastructure to match the declared state.
terraform apply.use_case: Running `terraform apply` to spin up a new set of EC2 instances after validating the plan output.

inventory file.eli5: Like a contact list that tells your helper robot which devices to talk to and where to find them.
inventory file.boss: An inventory file lists systems and their variables for automation tools like Ansible to manage infrastructure.
inventory file.sysadmin: In Ansible, the inventory file defines managed hosts, groups, and host-specific variables used during playbook execution.
inventory file.use_case: Creating a dynamic inventory file to manage AWS EC2 hosts with Ansible.

role.eli5: It's like assigning chores in a houseâ€”one person does dishes, another takes out trash. A role gives specific tasks.
role.boss: In infrastructure and automation, a role defines a reusable set of tasks or permissions for systems or users.
role.sysadmin: In Ansible, a role is a modular structure that bundles tasks, variables, files, and templates for reusable automation. In IAM, a role defines permissions for users or systems.
role.use_case: Creating an Ansible role that installs and configures NGINX across all web servers.

module.eli5: Think of a LEGO setâ€”each box builds a part of something bigger. A module is that self-contained piece.
module.boss: A module is a reusable package of code or configuration used in infrastructure, automation, or programming to simplify complex systems.
module.sysadmin: In Terraform or Ansible, a module is a collection of files and resources that can be reused to manage infrastructure or configurations across environments.
module.use_case: Using a Terraform module to consistently deploy S3 buckets with versioning and tags across projects.

loki.eli5: Like a notebook that only writes down what you say, not the entire conversationâ€”Loki just stores log lines, not full metrics.
loki.boss: Loki is a log aggregation tool built by Grafana Labs that organizes logs by labels and integrates seamlessly with Grafana dashboards.
loki.sysadmin: Loki is a horizontally scalable log aggregation system that indexes metadata (labels) rather than log content, optimizing storage and performance for observability stacks.
loki.use_case: Using Loki to collect and visualize container logs within a Grafana dashboard for troubleshooting.

alertmanager.eli5: Like a digital smoke alarm that knows who to call when somethingâ€™s wrong.
alertmanager.boss: Alertmanager handles alerts from Prometheus and routes them via email, Slack, or other channels based on rules.
alertmanager.sysadmin: Alertmanager is part of the Prometheus ecosystem and manages alert deduplication, silencing, and notification routing using custom rules.
alertmanager.use_case: Notifying a Slack channel when a Kubernetes pod exceeds CPU thresholds via Alertmanager.

blackbox exporter.eli5: Itâ€™s like a robot that checks if the lights are on in your house from the outsideâ€”without going in.
blackbox exporter.boss: Blackbox Exporter is a Prometheus add-on that checks availability of services (like websites or ports) by probing them externally.
blackbox exporter.sysadmin: Blackbox Exporter enables Prometheus to probe endpoints using HTTP, HTTPS, DNS, TCP, or ICMP, often used for uptime and availability checks.
blackbox exporter.use_case: Monitoring HTTP availability of a web app from multiple locations using Prometheus and Blackbox Exporter.

301 redirect.eli5: Like changing your home address and putting up a sign that says, 'I moved here permanently!'
301 redirect.boss: A 301 Redirect tells browsers and search engines that a webpage has permanently moved to a new URL.
301 redirect.sysadmin: A 301 status code is an HTTP response that permanently redirects traffic from one URL to another, maintaining SEO rankings and avoiding broken links.
301 redirect.use_case: Redirecting traffic from an old blog post URL to its updated version using a 301 rule in Nginx.

302 redirect.eli5: Like leaving a sticky note saying, 'Iâ€™m not home, but check this place for now!'
302 redirect.boss: A 302 Redirect is used when a webpage is temporarily moved and will eventually return to its original location.
302 redirect.sysadmin: The 302 status code performs a temporary HTTP redirect, useful when content is temporarily unavailable at its usual URL.
302 redirect.use_case: Redirecting traffic to a maintenance page while the main site is undergoing updates using a 302 rule.

404 not found.eli5: Itâ€™s like knocking on a door that doesnâ€™t existâ€”nobodyâ€™s home, and the house might not be either.
404 not found.boss: A 404 Not Found error means the server couldnâ€™t find the requested resource, like a broken link or deleted page.
404 not found.sysadmin: HTTP 404 is a client-side error response indicating the server cannot locate the requested URL. It often appears when URLs are mistyped or content has been removed.
404 not found.use_case: Serving a custom 404 error page when a user visits a non-existent product URL on an e-commerce site.

403 forbidden.eli5: Like showing up at a party but the bouncer says, 'Youâ€™re not on the list.'
403 forbidden.boss: A 403 Forbidden error means the server understood the request but refuses to allow accessâ€”often due to permissions.
403 forbidden.sysadmin: HTTP 403 is a status code indicating the resource is restricted and the user does not have authorization to access it, despite a valid request.
403 forbidden.use_case: Blocking access to an admin area from unauthorized IPs and returning a 403 error.

500 internal server error.eli5: Like a vending machine saying 'something broke inside, sorry!'
500 internal server error.boss: A 500 Internal Server Error means something went wrong on the server, but it doesnâ€™t tell you what exactly.
500 internal server error.sysadmin: An HTTP 500 error is a generic server error indicating an unhandled condition in the backend application, such as misconfigurations or runtime exceptions.
500 internal server error.use_case: Investigating a 500 error caused by a PHP application misconfiguring database credentials.

seo.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting up signs and lights so more people notice your lemonade stand on the street.
seo.boss: SEO (Search Engine Optimization) improves how well your site ranks in search engines so customers can find you more easily.
seo.sysadmin: SEO involves optimizing website structure, content, and metadata to improve visibility in search engine result pages (SERPs).
seo.use_case: Improving page speed and adding structured data to boost SEO rankings on Google.

meta tags.eli5: Theyâ€™re like invisible labels on a webpage that help search engines and social media understand what it's about.
meta tags.boss: Meta tags provide descriptive info about a webpageâ€”like its title, description, and social media preview settings.
meta tags.sysadmin: Meta tags are snippets of HTML inside a webpage's head element that define metadata for SEO, sharing, and browser behavior.
meta tags.use_case: Adding meta tags to improve how a webpage appears when shared on Facebook or Twitter.

meta title.eli5: Like the title of a bookâ€”it tells you what the page is about before you open it.
