meta title.boss: A meta title is what appears as the clickable headline in search engine results, critical for SEO.
meta title.sysadmin: The meta title is an HTML element that defines the page title shown on browser tabs and SERPs. Itâ€™s one of the most important on-page SEO elements.
meta title.use_case: Optimizing meta titles with target keywords to improve click-through rates from Google search results.

meta description.eli5: Itâ€™s like a short summary on the back of a bookâ€”it helps readers decide if they want to read it.
meta description.boss: The meta description gives a brief summary of the pageâ€™s content, often shown in search results to attract clicks.
meta description.sysadmin: An HTML meta tag that provides a description of a web page, influencing how search engines display results and impacting SEO click-through rates.
meta description.use_case: Writing compelling meta descriptions to entice users to click on blog posts in search results.

open graph.eli5: Itâ€™s like adding a photo, title, and summary to a party inviteâ€”so when people see it online, they want to click.
open graph.boss: Open Graph tags let you control how your webpage appears when shared on social media platforms like Facebook or LinkedIn.
open graph.sysadmin: Open Graph is a protocol used via meta tags in HTML to define rich previews (image, title, description) when web pages are shared on social networks.
open graph.use_case: Adding Open Graph tags to control preview images and titles when blog articles are shared on LinkedIn.

twitter card.eli5: Itâ€™s like dressing up your tweet with a picture and title to make it more exciting when someone shares a link.
twitter card.boss: Twitter Cards allow your website to display rich media previews in tweets, improving engagement and click-throughs.
twitter card.sysadmin: Twitter Card meta tags define how a shared link appears on Twitter, including summary, image, and video previews.
twitter card.use_case: Adding a Twitter Card to ensure blog post previews show a large image and description on Twitter.

cls.eli5: Itâ€™s like a webpage jumping around while loadingâ€”annoying and confusing!
cls.boss: Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) measures how much content unexpectedly shifts as a page loadsâ€”important for user experience.
cls.sysadmin: CLS is a Core Web Vital metric that quantifies visual stability by measuring layout shifts that occur during page load.
cls.use_case: Reducing CLS by reserving space for images and ads so content doesn't jump during page load.

ttfb.eli5: Itâ€™s like waiting at a restaurantâ€”you want the waiter to show up fast, not stare at an empty table.
ttfb.boss: Time to First Byte (TTFB) measures how quickly a server responds to a browserâ€™s requestâ€”itâ€™s key for website performance.
ttfb.sysadmin: TTFB is a web performance metric measuring the time between a clientâ€™s HTTP request and the first byte received from the server.
ttfb.use_case: Improving TTFB by enabling caching and reducing server response time in a WordPress site.

tti.eli5: Itâ€™s like when a game loads and finally lets you press 'Start'â€”thatâ€™s TTI.
tti.boss: Time to Interactive (TTI) measures how long it takes for a webpage to become fully usable for the visitor.
tti.sysadmin: TTI is a web performance metric that tracks when a page becomes reliably interactiveâ€”i.e., no long tasks block input response.
tti.use_case: Using Lighthouse to analyze and reduce TTI on a single-page app by deferring non-critical scripts.

web security.eli5: Itâ€™s like adding locks, cameras, and guards to your digital houseâ€”so no one breaks in.
web security.boss: Web security protects websites from attacks like hacking, data theft, and malware, ensuring user safety and trust.
web security.sysadmin: Web security involves applying technologies and best practices like TLS, secure headers, input validation, and access controls to safeguard web applications.
web security.use_case: Enabling HTTPS and setting security headers to prevent XSS and clickjacking on a login page.

content security policy.eli5: Itâ€™s like telling your webpage, 'Only trust food from this kitchenâ€”no outside snacks allowed.'
content security policy.boss: A Content Security Policy (CSP) tells browsers which content is safe to load, helping block attacks like XSS.
content security policy.sysadmin: CSP is a web security standard that restricts which sources are allowed for scripts, styles, images, and other resources, mitigating injection threats.
content security policy.use_case: Implementing CSP to prevent inline scripts from executing on a financial dashboard site.

xss.eli5: Like someone sneaking graffiti onto your whiteboardâ€”except itâ€™s malicious code on your website.
xss.boss: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) is a security vulnerability where attackers inject malicious scripts into trusted websites.
xss.sysadmin: XSS allows attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript in usersâ€™ browsers by exploiting unsanitized user inputs, leading to session theft or redirection.
xss.use_case: Sanitizing form inputs on a contact page to prevent stored XSS payloads from executing.

harvester.eli5: Itâ€™s like a farmerâ€™s all-in-one machineâ€”but instead of crops, it manages virtual machines and containers.
harvester.boss: Harvester is an open-source hyperconverged infrastructure (HCI) platform that combines virtualization with Kubernetes.
harvester.sysadmin: Harvester uses KubeVirt and Longhorn to manage VMs and container workloads in a Kubernetes-native environment, ideal for hybrid infrastructure.
harvester.use_case: Deploying Harvester to run virtual machines and containers side-by-side on edge servers with centralized Kubernetes management.

netbios.eli5: Itâ€™s like shouting someoneâ€™s name across a room so you can find them in a crowdâ€”but on a network.
netbios.boss: NetBIOS helps computers on a local network identify and connect with each other by name rather than IP.
netbios.sysadmin: NetBIOS (Network Basic Input/Output System) is a legacy protocol that enables applications on different computers to communicate within a LAN using names, typically associated with SMB and Windows networking.
netbios.use_case: Accessing a shared Windows folder on the network using a computer name resolved through NetBIOS.
